Clear bright golden vessel with a gentle haze, on top is a creamy white head that was initially bubbled but settled into a relatively well lasting head. The flavour is incredibly moreish! Subtle but yet still very interesting, as a blond you expect typical flavours but instead you have a great structure with overall savoury delight! Flavours of gentle bitterness, cereals, hops, yeast, soft spices, malts, lots of grains/cereals in the back and a lasting but subtle savoury grains and hop aftertaste very similar to a witbier. The beer is smooth, silky, full and perfectly carbonated making it ever so refreshing, it has everything you expect it to in terms of mouthfeel. Extremely good beer, as much as I dont like agreeing to typical hypes, this beer really makes it hard to defy my mind. As with all Westvleteren beers, the availability and price tag really breaks my heart, if you can get some, make sure you do!

Bottle. Hazy yellow body, tall head. Aroma is citric with a small hint of yeast. Sweet and lightly spicy/lemony taste. A bit like a witbier. Crisp carbonation. Medium hoppy finish. Would be a fine session beer but surely not for the absurd grey market price one must pay outside Belgium to see what the hype is about...

Hazy yellow, white head. Yeasty, fruity head with spicy notes. Taste is citrus, malt, spicy sharpness and a sweetish hoppy-bitter finish. Seems fairly simple at first, but reveals its complexity gradually. Nice and refreshing.

Bottle. Hazy orange with a creamy and frothy head. Aroma is bready malt, herbal hops, yeast, some straw, lots of apricots, less orange, some faint leather and an intense though not sharp spiciness (coriander, cloves). Medium carbonation, medium body, perfectly balanced and strong aroma, taste is light sourish with a medium bitterness. Velvety mouthfeel, very fruity, less spicy flavour, fruity aftertaste. Delightful.

Bottle. Poured into original Westvleteren goblet. Clear golden colour when poured without the yeast sediment, gets cloudy when sediment gets poured in. Beautifull creamy white head that builds above the rim of the glass. Aroma of grains, lemon, orange and coriander. Bit like a Belgian Witbier. Incredibly flavourfull, a bit bitter but most of all spicey and balanced. The lemon is really present on the surface and you can find the spiceyness on the background. Really good beer, will definitely pick this up again.

Si presenta nel bicchiere con un colore chiaro e opalescente.Profumo agrumato e di spezie.schiuma bianca fine e poco persistente.Al palato sinceramente oltre al contrasto tra la vena fruttata citrica e il leggero amaro di luppolo non mi colpisce molto altro. Un pó deluso,forse troppe aspettative.Mi riservo un secondo assaggio altrimenti direi che come blonde trappista cè di meglio ...

Bottle, brought home from Belgium where it was gifted by my new friend Mathieu. Poured into my .3L tulip. 

Appearance: Gold and partially cloudy. Lots of bubbles cascading through the body and up to the half inch thick head. 

Smell: Not the most overwhelming array of aromas, but the yeast is definitely there. Citrus and wild fields. 

Taste: Excellent. Peppery and wild and funky and refreshing. Another review mentioned a hint of Orval, and Id say thats pretty spot on. The floral components from the hops have a nice balance. I get a little bit of the pine and dryness, but only as a compliment to the base of the beer (which is the yeasty profile.) The back end suitably lingers for a bit, begging me to take another sip.

Mouthfeel: Effervescent and crisp. 

Overall: I could drink a lot of this. Well worth seeking out. Especially if youre going to go through the trouble of tracking down its older brothers.

Bottle dated 17-12-10.  Pours a slightly cloudy gold with a nice fluffy white head.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma of florals, yeast, citrus, and spices.  Taste is a nice balance of florals, spices, citrus, yeast, and a bit of hops.  A truly superior blond.  Rating # 800

Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a nice-sized white head.  Nose is belgian yeast and citrus.  Tastes of belgian yeast, lemon peel, and a bit of spice.  Really good for a belgian blond, but this is a style with which one can only do so much.  The monks have done all they can.

[Rated 05/31/2010] Westvleteren 1/3: Bottle. Pours muddy apple-colored with thick white head. Aroma is of wheat, honey and fruit (did I get apples?). Flavor is of honey and wheat and is very light for the amount of alcohol that it packs. Maybe a little sour too. Very nice. I am eager to try the bottles of its 2 bigger brothers.

#1233
Gelber Trappist mit feinporiger Schaumkrone; hopfiges Aroma mit Zitronengras; im Antrunk wiederum zitronig, ohne süß zu sein, der Hopfen übernimmt schnell das Kommando und geht in einen mittellangen Abgang über. Ungewöhnlich, aber eine absolut leckere Hopfennote!
My dad brought this back from Belgium on a recent trip.  Pours golden with a faint but frothy head.  Flavors are a hint of sweet banana, apricot, and bread.

330ml bottle from Cracked Kettle

Pours light yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma has notes of yeast, fruits, spices, malts and earthy notes. Taste is quite fruity with notes of malts and spices. Finish is quite fruity and slightly bitter with dry notes. Carbonated and medium bodied. Okay, quite well balanced.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a slightly hazy yellow colour with a small white head. Aroma of dried fruits, hay, urinal cake and barnyard. Flavour pale malts, barnyard, dried fruits and citrus. Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel and a dry, fruity finish. Weird urinal cake notes ruin this.

Fles 33cl.
Kleur: Lichtgeel met een enorme witte romige schuimkraag die lang blijft staan. Ziet er mooi uit.
Geur: Hop en fruit.
Smaak: Fris en fruitig. Nasmaak is erg scherp. Licht troebel en veel koolzuur. Prikkelend op de tong.
Ik denk dat de verwachting hoger was dan de daadwerkelijke smaak.
Lekker blond bier maar niet bovengemiddeld.

Location: Bottle from St. Sixtusabdij, 12/18/11, Rating # 2000, Just like Y2k, the world will not come to an end as I rate this one.  Ive been saving this one for a while, it was purchased in the summer of 10, and I thought rating 2000 would be a great time to break it out.  (I actually enjoyed one at In de Vrede - where I had all 3 of their beers, but this rating is based on the at-home bottle experience.)


Aroma: The nose has some fruity, spice, and Belgian yeast aromas to it, with clove and floral notes

Appearance: This one pours a cloudy golden-orange color with a small, fizzy white head and medium lace

Flavor: Execellently balanced taste made up of the spice, yeast, floral and fruit flavors, nice hop presence

Palate: The body is medium here, it has a really nice mouthfeel, and a tingly, somewhat dry, hop finish to it

Overall Impression: 
I remeber the sheer enjoyment of drinking this one (and the 8 and 12) in Westvleteren, and I wondered if this beer would live up to my lofty memories.  I poured it into one of my Westvleteren glass, because it wouldnt make sense to drink it anything.  It really does live up to the hype.  An excellent, complex Blond Ale.  The components just all really work well together to show what this style has the capability to be.  A great offering, and a wonderful way to tick off my 2000th rating!

33cl Bottle.  Appearance is hazy, orange color with pillowy, off-white head.  Aroma is sweet and with substantial orange and other citrus as well as doughy yeast.  Taste is also marked by the citrus flavors although the complexity slowly comes forth with hay, floral hops, and leathery yeast notes all coming to bear.  Palate is medium-bodied, clean and smooth texture, delicate and soft carbonation, and a long, somewhat sour finish.  Excellent beer from the masters.

Awesome Belgian blond ale, straw & hazy golden color, soft & fluffy white head, banana, yeast & clove in the nose, yeasty flavors that also included banana & a hint of corriander, very smooth & very drinkable, spicy & yeasty finish, awesome blond, another great beer from Westvleteren
pours a hazy light blond with a massive white bubbly head. thanks matinus for the bottle

Bottle at Haggertys Fantasy Tasting. 2003 Vintage. Clear light pale gold with a pale lager head. Potent fresh feed lot nose and some funk. Light sweet flavor. Medium body, nil carb, and a syrupy butterscotch finish. Past its prime but happy to try. Thanks Chris.

Brownish hayish colour, well carbonated with lots of yeast floating around. Perfect white head. Sweet sour smell with a typical W. Vleteren bitterness. Reminds me of Orval. Quite dry and watery with an interesting evolution towards fruity sweetness. Lightly alcoholic bitter-sourness.

Yeasty creamy nose in the bottle when opened and when poured it also took on a slight banana sweetness. Superficiailly looks like a pilsner though  without much beading. The head also remained modest.
Very clean and very pure taste with a heavish start followed by a light smooth cream middle before ending complex, herbally and long. Concludes with a single point of carbonation. 
Requires a ear standing before it gains it appetising maturity and composure.  Gentle and humane.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2016 330ml bottles [i.a. due to bartlebiers amicability]. Cloudy, deep golden / brass colour with average to huge, fluffy, creamy, mostly lasting, white head, opulent lacings. Intense, fruity, wheaty and oaty aroma, notes of apple, pear, berries, a touch of liquorice, cherry, plum. Taste is identically fruity with notes of apple, pear, green and yellow berries, even cherry and a touch of plum, peppery spicy yeasty overtones. Super soft, smooth and silky palate, creamy texture, gentle carbonation. A unique plethora of subtle flavours, thereby highly drinkable. Close to perfection.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 Bottle, 6 months old. Much more like a saison, with straw and light barnyard, smooth, well balanced with a nice bitterness and saison flavour. Much better then the last bottle. 

Bottle. Straw yellow with a white head. Grains, yeast, sugar, very light, fruity. Above average carbonation, somewhat sweet, mild, dry on the finish. Ok but probably my least favourite. 6/3/5/3/10

33 cL glass at In de Vrede.  Cloudy blond, with a big head in a Westvleteren glass.  Pleasant, hoppy, bitter blond/wit.  Smells of hops and slightly floral.  Alright but not in the same class as its Westvleteren sibblings.  Might have got one from a not so good batch.
A hazy golden yellow beer with a small airy head. Aroma is fruity and belgian yeast. Taste is also fruity, with citric notes, and spicy. Some balanced bitterness. Medium body and.

Light misty gold pour white fluffy head medium size spice and yeast the first aromas fruit hops citrus lemon medium carbonation candy grain some sourness for taste floral the flavours lemon orange floral spicy taste herb flavour finish the aftertaste hoppy yeast balance barley good sweetness light sour note and bitter good to drink

In bottiglia al Gambrinus di Bruges; per me, la migliore birra al mondo. Secca, floreale, dissetante, un finale amaro fantastico. Da bere a litri. Restasse solo una birra al mondo, vorrei fosse questa.

Bottle 2007 ed, courtesy Travlr. Pour is murky blonde with a gigantic white head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is spicy/fruity yeast, hay, stone, light floral hops. Taste is great: fruity/frunky yeast, light sweetness, herbal notes. Very dry, oily texture, light bodied.

(330ml bottle best by 3-12 thanks to bu11zeye) opaque gold with soapy long-lasting film of head. Nose of corn, florals, and candi sugar. Taste of Belgian yeast, dry grain, creamy, oily body, candi sugar and a bit spicy. Drinkable!
Soft white head it would be a great patio beer and has great lacing. Saison IPA funk and some hops. Flavour is short and thin in the middle. DV rocks on this.

Bottle - 330ml. Hazy golden body with a thin white foamy/creamy head. Fresh hoppy aroma with floral, herbal, and honeyish hints. Its sharp hoppy taste carries herbal and coriander notes. Ends witha long bitter/herbal finish. Very well done.

Pours golden and a bit hazy with a one finger head. Lively carbonation visible in the glass.

Aroma is really spicey with a mild barnyard note, hay. 

Taste is unlike any other blond ive had. Mouthfeel comes of kind of light and thin, folloved by nice spicey bitterness. Then there are really earthy notes in it. The beer is carbonated and not at all refreshing as a blond often is.

Overall a different type of beer from what i would have guessed it to be.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 It may pale compared to its siblings (literally), but I consider Blond to be a world-class brew on its own. The nose strikes with plenty of citrusy, spicy, and fruity notes hinting at generous use of yeast and fresh hops, all sustained by a firm, grainy malt backbone. The taste is bitter, sour, and to a lesser degree sweet, with a strong hop and yeast presence. The aftertaste is sweet and fruity, all in all extremely pleasant. Absolutely outstanding. I wish I had regular access to this beautiful concoction.

Sampled at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2011. September 2, 2011

An older bottle for sure. This wasnt fresh at all so dont consider this rating just. Aroma of sweet oatmeal, hay. Light fruit notes most mostly just old and dusty. The taste is still balanced and quite all right, slightly sweet with some apple and hay notes.
Hazy yellow color with good medium white head. Super fruity aroma. Very good blond flavor i.

Bottle courtesy of James shared w Andy James and Streets. Golden pour with medium fluffy head. Grassy, wheaty arome and similar taste, but with minimal bitterness and some sweetness. Luscious and full. Not much aftertaste. Very drinkable. Awesome blond.
Courtesy of James.  Hay and florals... Very soft and delicate not tinny or annoying like other blondes can be.. great blond lots of appreciation for this.
Bottle. Hazy yellow appearance. A nice belgian ale, but not spectacular. A little sweet, a little bitter. Not a strong flavour or aroma, but refreshing and nice.

Bottle at In de Vrede. Hazy golden yellow in colour with minimal head. Aroma is of citrus and hay. Taste is of citrus and grains with a degree of bitterness that lingers in the aftertaste. Not as much character as the Abbeys other beers.
Hazy dark yellow with a lasting white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and yeasty. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 010610
Bottle at "in de Vrede, Westvleteren": Hazy yellow coloured brew with an full well balanced sweetbitter taste.

Yellow golden hazy beer with nice smoothy head.Orange,fress grape leaves,ale yeast,some spices,reminds me both english and belgian ale and german pilsner.nice palate,pleasant bitter long lasting finsh.Thanks to my friend alexis for this beer.

pretty sure this was an 09 bottle as thats what the cap said. very good beer. not the first time ive had it, and def not the last. almost like a saison and an american pale mix. pours crisp gold with a stark white head that leaves some spotting and lacing, some chunks since i didnt stop pouring quite soon enough, only a few lil floaters though. even after almost 2 years the taste is crisp and refreshing, moderately hoppy, great carbonation. the most interesting part about this brew is the finish and aftertaste, which im noticed more on this aged bottle, but the house yeast really comes through and ties it together in the end. gives it a full, velvety mouthfeel and earthy, much more substantial aftertaste, which reminds you of the 8 and 12 and gives you a warming feeling not merited by a crisp 5.8% light ale. although not initally a 9 when it hits your tongue, i gave it 9 on taste due to the aweosme evolution and aftertaste on the palate. delicious stuff, unique, i would definitely drink this a lot if it were readily available and fresh.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow color with a frothy bright white head. Aroma is of lighter fruits, like apple, pear, white grapes, some spice, along with subtle funk and breadiness. Flavor is again of the lighter fruits with more of a peppery spice note, along with flavors of funk, hay, apple, pear, white grapes and a subtle tartness. The body is light with a powdery dry mouthfeel. Overall a solid Trappist Single, but as with the other Trappist Singles, nothing really impressive.

A - An exquisite looking Belgian Pale Ale. The appearance is exactly what you would expect a blonde to be. There is an orange-yellow look to this beer with a white head (about 1/4 of a finger of head with this beer on a fairly aggressive pour). Color is very reminiscent of champagne with carbonation trailing up the sides of the snifter glass. 

S - a very complex smell that you would usually find with other brands quadrupels. You can really smell dark fruits in this one. Some yeast and cellar funk (others will call this barnyard funk, but I have had occasion to smell this particular scent before and it was in a cellar). Faintly sweet smelling as well. 

T - Very good for a belgian pale ale. If I was going for a pale ale, this would be my choice (although this style of beer isnt my overall favorite). Around 40 degrees drinking temperature, the dark fruits dominate the taste. You can also taste the yeast in there as well. A slight tinge of sweetness, but nothing you wouldnt notice without really looking for it. As the beer warms up, the dark fruits come forward even more and the beer becomes even smoother. A real pleasant surprise. 

M - very smooth mouthfeel to this beer. Wow, is this smooth. You can feel the carbonation as you swish it around your mouth and cannot really feel the booziness of this beer until you let it sit your stomach for a while. 

O - While the not the overall best beer that I have ever had, this beer is near the top. Top in its style that I have had. Its just very smooth overall and very drinkable. I was very pleasantly surprised to note some dark fruits in this beer as I would with quadrupels. Just a testament to the genius of the monks of the St. Sixtus Abbey.

Bottled from De Gekraakte Ketel. Orange color with medium white long lasting head. Aroma of orange, spices, some floral notes. Taste, grapefruit,  yeast, floral hops. Nice spicy bitter finish. Soft, but nice.
Not bad at all, perhaps even better then their other beers which to me arent that exceptional. This one has got a nice aroma and a nice lightly bitter taste with an average carbonation.

head: large, white, fluffy 
colour: yellow, slightly hazy 
smell: soury, yeasty, citric, hops , doughy 
taste: start is bubblegumy hopy , bitter and green herbs , overall is bitter yeasty with a slightly sweet malty undernote, then comes in some slight boozyness with a subtle hint of sweetness that reminds me of bubblegum/almunds, end is pilsner in taste , dry and with a grassy aftertaste , not that bad !

Herb-fruchtiger Antrunk. Dezent hefiger Mittelteil mit leichter Herbe, spritzig, etwas säuerlich-ins Bittere gehend. Herberer Nachgeschmack, weniger hefig, dafür deutlich malziger, was sich weiter steigert. Vollmundiges und leckeres Bier. 	 
Test vom 24.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,11,12,12,-,11 - 11,31

Bottle shared at the May Santa Cruz tasting. Pours a hazy straw color with a lacy white ring of foam. Aroma is phenolic and ashy with accents of pale malts and yeast. Kinda cigarettey in a way. Flavor is much better. Dry pale malts provide a nice background for the ludicrous hop bitterness. Ive had less bitter IPAs. This is awesome. Perfect hoppiness for a Belgian golden ale. So so dry but quenching and fulfilling. Bitter, pale and delicious.

pours hazy light orange with a thick, lumpy white head and plenty of lacing.  Beautiful, unique sweet aroma of tart, fruity candy.  theres notes of strawberry, peach and cherry.  taste is lovely consisting of a tacky yeast character, some rigid hops reminiscent of Orval as well as some orange peel.  Theres a sourness that I wouldnt have expected given the aroma but the dichotomy is pleasing.  finish is bitter citrus.  This beer really lasts on your palate.  Impressive for a beer that is less than 6% abv.  Refreshing without being thin and sour without  being off-putting at all.  This a beautiful beer.

I liked this a lot, its a blond beer, there is a "haze" in the glass but the beer looks very taste and has a strong aroma. The taste is smooth and refined, reminding of Westmalle blond but i do think this is slightly better even if I could not compare the two side by side.
Spicy and fruity aromas.  Smooth easy drinking.  Fruit and spice flavors.  Overall one of the best blonds Ive tasted.
Bottle at Kulminator.  Pours cloudy golden with small white head.  Aroma is soft, yeasty and slightly musty.  Flavor is citrus, bitter hops and a little bread.  Medium carbonation.

Had this at Bryans tasting party. Poured a hazy golden yellow into a Stone tasting glass with an fluffy white head. Bready nose. A lighter color and flavor profile, which seems like a perfect summer brew. Flavors of light malts and fruits, with a  slightly sweet spice layered in. Smooth finish. Refreshingly good stuff.

11.2 oz bottle.  About time Ive rated this one as i have had it several times.  Pours a grayish golden yellow with a medium sized white head.  Aroma of light bubble gum, wheat, lemon and yeast.  Taste of bubble gum, lemon, yeast and wheat.  Nice and pleasant.

This one was a long time in coming.  Pours a hazy yellow with a white head.  Nose is sweet malt, earthy, grassy hops, a bit of sweetness, and a bit of mustiness.  Flavor is similar- nice sweet quality about it followed by some earthy hop bitterness, finishing with some mustiness.  Very enjoyable Belgian session beer.

Slightly unclear golden beer, white head. Very fruity aroma, malts, honey, Belgian yeast. Flavour of fresh malts, nice dose of hops, quite fruity, notes of yeast. Very dry. Smooth, sweetish dry finish.
(bottle @ In de Vrede)
Bottle. Color cloudy yellow with medium head. Aroma spicy, yeast, honey, fruit. Taste sweet, yeast, honey, light bitter.

Pours a cloudy yellow body with a small fizzy white head.  Aroma is herbal, spicy, woody, and grassy with a hint of butterscotch.  The mouthfeel is medium in body and light in warmth.  It has a mixture of subtle flavors: grass, wood, hay, and banana.

Bevuta recentemente in una splendida birreria nel mugello, ho trovato la Blond di St. Sixtus, davvero meravigliosa. Colore dorato, e nettare al naso, frutta e fiori sono miracolosi. Al palato poi è indimenticabile...La belgian ale numero 1 al mondo.

33cL bottle from specialty shop in Brussels. Pours a golden pear with a bone-white head that gradually simmers away. Smells of malted barley predominantly -- very fresh and crisp. Flavor-packed for a blond -- some sweet barley notes that balance perfectly with slight hop bitterness (both in the foreground) along with some yeast notes and a slight wheat taste that permeates through one layer of the taste. Very dry. Finishes very smoothly on a sweet, grainy note. This is the best blond ale I have ever had.

Bottle at In de Vrede. It pours hazy straw yellow, with a thick fluffy white head and low to moderate carbonation. The nose is white bread, yeast, grapefruit, yellow plum, lemon and honey-suckle. The taste is: bread, yeast, honey, grapefruit, tangy lemon and some soap, with a very long bitter finish. It has a foamy mouth-feel and a satisfying hop-bite. Not my favourite style, but I was impressed with the quality of this one.

I had luck and bought all 3 kinds in abbey, very strong nice aroma, like spring meadow, lot of fruit aroma, hazy, pale, rocky head, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, nice refreshable taste, medium body but fuul tasty, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish, good balanced,
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: Wish I could drink this every day like the monks... Big white head and hazy golden color. Big carbonation with continuing bubbles. Aroma is complex with faint brett/dry yeast character and subtle noble hops. Some delicate stone fruitiness also. Flavor mirrors aroma with light malt balanced with lingering bitterness. Very complex and supremely balanced!

Bottle graciously shared by a friend for my 2500th rating. Clear gold pour with a few chunks and a huge white head. Aroma is esters with banana, honey, citrus and pepper notes. Honey hits the palate first, then pepper and banana before finishing with a grapefruit bitterness that does not taste like it comes from hops.

Pours yellow, cloudy, small head. Aroma of honey, malt and yeast. Flavor is malty, slightest hint of bitterness, spices. Finish is really enjoyable, spicy.Low carbonation, smooth mouthfeel. Overall a really enjoyable beer.

The beer pours a light to medium cloudy gold. The head is white rises about a finger but is gone quickly. The lacing is light, not much there.

The aroma is outstanding. It is honey and tart and with hops. Its really nice and crisp and brings you in right away.

The taste is really good, but a notch below the flavor as it doesnt carry over the same flavors. Its little sweet with some hops, reminds me a tripel but a better version.

The mouthfeel is surprsing good and this is very drinkable

Alright folks, to all of you who love the 12, the 8/BLonde is AMAZING.  I loved it.  It had a sour flavor with some sweet wheat attached.  I loved it,  If I could have gotten 10 crates to bring home I would have in a heartbeat.  Its wonderful stuff.  It was just amazingly unique beer.  I would not pay tons for it if I could get it in the USA, but its still great and worth a try for sure.

06/08/11 Date on the cap.  Courtesy of megriggs and shared with Armin.  Thanks!  Nice hazy straw pour with a bone white head and slightly chunky lacing.   Aroma is yeast forward, with some nice white grapes.  Very nice!  Taste is somewhat disappointing after the aroma...on its way out perhaps?  More belgian yeast, a hint of spicyness and some interesting esters.  Flavors are subdued and muddled.  Fairly dry finish.  Not a bad beer,but would love to try this one right off the bottling line!

Bottle, thanks Caleb! Date says 6,8,11. Pours very hazy yellow, nice white head. Aroma is nice biscuit, flowery, some grass. Taste is a bit downhill, notes of some cardboard come through, but overall has nice malt and hop notes.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2013 Bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels. Sweet flowery yeasty aroma. Very cloudy pale golden yellow colour with a long lasting foamy head. Sweet flowery oaty flavour. Dry aftertaste. Second time tasted. Not as good as I remember it.

Bottle looks great as all the Westys, beer in the glass very zippy, huge head. Starts mild, but not washy, modest fruity like lemon, fine hoppy-grasy notes in the background. Modest sweet. Well balanced finish. A great beer!

Bottle at the 5th Annual Richmond Industry Gathering on 11/28/2010. Slightly hazy white body with a small white head. Earthy and spicy aroma. Spicy and floral flavor. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.
Smell of hops and citrus. Taste is well balanced but has a great hoppy flavour without the extra bitterness. Tastes very rich. Great beer.
nice beer for a warm summer day.spicy hops, grass, notes of citrus with a nicely balanced bitterness. Relatively high on carbonation. Great for the style

I opened this up to celebrate my last day at work - onwards, upwards!  It pours a hazy almost grayish-yellow with a tight traditional head which is easily reinvigorated with a swirl.  How wonderful this aroma is, so superbly floral, fresh and evocative (the old wine term "terroir" applies).  Here are fields in summer, hay stacked high in barns and flowers in bloom.  But under this, anchoring it to the earth, is the yeast.  And it is the yeast that first impresses on the palate, being fruity and pleasingly doughy.  This balances out the hops and gives added depth to an otherwise mostly dry beer.  Its exceedingly rounded and so very drinkable.  The hop aromas carry through and develop with the yeast to end on a perfumed finish.  Of course one has to address the allure of Westvleteren and I can hardly add anything new to the debate, only to say that amidst the hype this beer remains humble.  And I love it for it.

One of the classics. It pours hazy golden with a nice, foamy header. The header really sticks on the glass. Spicy aroma, good hops, hints of citrus and breadlike ingredients. Well hidden alcohol and hoppy aftertaste. Carbonation is subtle. I certainly recommend this beer to everyone!
Bottle shared at Mikeys tasting. Pours golden blond. Fluffy white head. Nose of yeast, grassy hops and lemon zest. Taste of lemongrass, dry hops, zest and yeast.

330ml bottle from Gambrinus in London. pours slightly hazed golden with a lasting white head. hoppy aroma with pils malt body and some funky rustic barnyard elements. flavour starts hoppy, the malt is lean and crisp, the funkiness is there but its subtle. crazy drinkable. best session beer on the planet.

Bottle 330 ml  
Aroma  slight yeasty  hop feel  with short citric note , green apple , floral good hops.
 Appearance  amber gold with light fizzy top. Fairly low carbonation. 3+
Flavor and Palate : medium full bodied ale. Sweet malty base with feel of earth and green apple, some alcohol , almond. Dried fruity finish with feel of hops.Nice.
12 oz. bottle.  Poured a straw color with a nice white head.  I get brett.  This tastes like a classic belgian blonde that is complex but yet smooth.  Very good beer.

Date on the cap is  28/2/09. Pours a hazy golden color, small dense white head with lots of big chunks floating around. Aroma has a spicy noble hops note with a grassy hops presence later. Lots of grainy pils malt, hefty yeasty presence and a honey presence like fresh honey combs from the bee farms. Flavor has a strong grassy noble hops flavor up front, mild pils middle, strong yeasty presence, straw and not too sweet. Textures encompass a wide range of feelings from the highly carbonation feeling, modest body to the very dry, tongue punching ending. Overall a great brew. Aroma is top notch and the flavor is much more focused on the graininess. Very well balanced and smooth.
lots of bananas an estry a touch of Brett. Light, definitely a bit funky with honey,  wow, not what I was expected. Def different.  More I drink the more I like.

Spicy, hoppy, aroma with noticeable notes from the yeast.  Cloudy straw color with a thick head.  Hops and spice notes in the flavor, fruit, yeast, pretty complex.  Fairly high carbonation, smooth and easy drinking.  Really great blond ale, refreshing and drinkable.

Into the glass pours a very strong foaming beer, which shows clear and golden yellow. The beer smells like banana and hoppy. The bombastic beginning part is hoppy, with good yeasty nuances. The aftertaste is also shown dominant hoppy, very fresh and natural! The center part is clearly bitter. The banana flavor is present but the fresh, aromatic hops plays the main role! A real tip of beer, which develops his full (hop-rich) aromas until the finish!!

Bottle, By @ Beermania in Brussels: Hazy, creamy white head. Aroma had a "light" touch of bananna,fruits, citrus. Flavor was fruity, citrus, sweet maltynes. Medium fruity body and a  medium citrus /bitter finish. Nice!

Slightly hazy deep gold pour with a lot of carbonation and a big noisy white head.  Nose is peachy and apricotty fruit, funky yeast, spice, hops.  Tastes pale malty, very spicy, with a complex dry yet funky and yeasty fruity complexity.  It took me 10 years to find this, and it was worth the wait.

Hazy pale orange body, with a big white long lasting head and amazing lacing. Aroma is full of fruits, spices and can smell the yeast, some wood and smoke tones as well. The palate is full with an amazing velvet texture and soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet and bitter dry, orange and pepper, and long lasting. Definetely worth a try.

330 ml bottle in Germany, very much thanks to Steptin for this one. Hazy yellow color with huge creamy/foamy white head. Smooth hoppiness and spices in aroma. Bitter dry hoppiness in flavor. Some spices too. Long-lasting hoppy palte. No hoppy overdose. There is way too much hipe about beers from Westvleteren

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 Strong, foamy head, cloudy body. Quite fresh aroma with apple, wheat, but some darker tones of cinnamon, coriander and nutmeg. Loads of flavour. Citrus first but quickly more pronounced bitterness. Balanced carbonation. Delicious! (Rating re-indexed)

From notes:

Got this one is a past trade with masterhomebrewer. Thanks again man! Ive had the other two Westies still being brewed so Im psyched to try this one.

Pours a hazy dark golden yellow color with slight orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy white head. Very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves large splotches of soapy lacing left behind.

Spicy aroma with zesty pepper notes as ell as a blast of crisp light fruit, bready yeast, subtle hops and sweet alcohol. Im picking up hints of banana, apple and pear.

Medium bodied and surprisingly hop forward, especially since this bottle has been aged for about four years. Im picking up the zesty, peppery spice that I noticed in the aroma as well the bready yeast and fruit notes, especially apple and pear. The bitterness from the hops is evident throughout but rather than overpowering the other flavors, they compliment them adding complexity and balance. There is slight alcohol sweetness and heat but this beer is still incredibly quaffable.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012 Tasted from a 11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a slightly yellow/orange body thats fairly hazy with a big pearl white colored head.  Zesty, Belgian yeasty, citrusy, bready, cracker, pale malty. Somewhat spicy, Belgian yeasty, lemon citrusy, bready, barnyard, a touch musty, pale malty flavor. Spicy, barnyard, citrusy aftertaste. Tasty Belgian blonde ale.

(Bottle at De Heeren van Liedekercke) The beer poured pale golden and hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had honey, dried coriander and fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied and bit dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, malts, spiciness, hops, mildly honey, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity and bitter. Nice refreshing beer but not anything really special.

Cloudy yellow pour with a huge white head that boasts unbelievable retention and very nice lacing. Musty and full of citrus on the smell for me. The taste is wonderful.  Light Belgian yeasts and spices, citrus and grapefruits.  Nice dry hoppy finish. Light and bubbly. If only I could get more of it!
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 Bottle from Urbains private stash. Pleasant aroma - smooth. Taste is dry, well carbonated, gives a lingering hoppy aftertaste. Nice.

Pours a light, creamy blonde with a nice white head. Smell is quite complex with notes of light fruits, citrus peel, hops, and a bit of bready dough. Taste is quite similar, with some of the drier, white stone fruits taking over a little bit and fading into a nice, hoppy aftertaste. Mouthfeel is quite light and well carbonated with a nice dry finish. Excellent drinkability. Can only dream of sitting in Belgium drinking a few of these.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2010

Pours hazy champagne colored with huge white head leaving pretty lacing. Aroma is very fruity, light body but still heavy hoppy. Sediment aroma is chocolate, caramel, cereal and hay. Flavor is sicy, fruity, a bit sour acidy, hoppy and well balanced. Lean fruity palate. Finishes dry hoppy.

Bottle at the 5th Annual Epic Beer Tasting in Richmond, VA, November 28, 2010. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a medium creamy head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of earthy notes, syrupy fruit notes and a spice, piney note. The taste is beady malts, candi sugar and that same piney note. Medium bodied. 3400th rating!

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a transculent bright yellow with particles that are floating and has a medium bright white head that dissapates quickly.  Aroma is beautiful citrus and some clove and has some lacing.  Taste is floral citrus, slightly tart yeast, some clove, and finishes dry.

Bottle thx to tkrjukoff cons  2010-11-27 Sätila
AR: strong flower, gueze sourness (wee), wild strawberries
AP. champagne, creamy egg white foam
F: great body, medium bitterneess, wee wild strawberrie, champagne yeast, a bit over medium bitterness
Yolk: more body, and sour flavor. Gooseberry
Ce produit difficile a se procurer bénéficie dun coup de coeur de ma part compte tenu de la qualité de la bière et de limage quelle véhicule. I like it!

Transcription of an old BA review from 02-18-2010, with scores adjusted to RB scale. Will re-rate.

BB 20.October 2010, into Orval chalice.
The pour produces luminous snow /egg meringue white head that collapses into solid sheet over the entire surface of hazy straw yellow to extremely pale orange-brown fluid with translucent, almost watery appearance. Swirls wave fabrics of bright lace which is short lived apart from individual patches sliding down the walls.
Aromas are of apples, hops and barn yard funkiness. The mild flavor profile is an interplay of apple tartness and hoppy bitterness enhanced by faint juniper. Slightly astringent.
The light bodied brew with restrained carbonation is thin and shallow and fails to match my mental picture of Westvleteren blond ale. However, the beer is very clean and refreshing so I can easily imagine it being the monks table beer for daily consumption.
Overrated, overpriced and nowhere close to Orval.

Decent beer.  Bottle pours yellow color with huge foamy white head with great lacing.  Aroma light fruits, spices, citrus.  Taste light fruits and spices - really tastes like a somewhat watery tripel.  Alcohol not apparent.  Nice smooth and carbonated palate.  Clean finish with slight bitterness.

Not a bad beer, but really none of the legendary Westvleteren mystique here.

Belgian beers, especially Trappist beers (made by monks) are known for being intense, complex, sippers. But why cant they make a lighter, more direct, and refreshing brew for casual drinking? I guess thats the idea behind Westvleteren Blond. Its got the basic characteristics of the Trappist ales, but without the intensity or prerequisites that come with most beers of the sort.NOTE: Of all the Westvleteren beers, the Blond is not meant to be aged (according to the monasterys website). The bottle I drank was purchased in February of 2009, although the original buyer isnt sure when it was brewed and bottled. Its possible I was not drinking this beer the way it was meant to be served.APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured an 11.2oz bottle into a Trappist chalice. The beer is lively and bubbly with a bright orange/yellow body with tons of tiny Belgian bubbles streaming up from the bottom of the glass. Although the beer is not intended for extended cellaring, it is bottle-conditioned as plenty of yeast can be seen in the bottle and even leaves a brown stain in the otherwise bright white, fluffy, head. The aroma is a little weak. I notice a typical Belgian blond scent not unlike Duvel of light fruit and yeast, but there also seems to be a touch of skunkiness (again, this could be due to the age of my bottle).TASTEWhen drinking a Trappist beer one of the first things you notice is how much flavor they deliver immediately. Westvleteren Blond is a bit different than the others as its flavor doesnt make itself known right away, but shows up in the finish and aftertaste. As it crosses my palate I get hints of fruit and yeast, but its otherwise mild. Whats interesting is that its actually very refreshing while its in my mouth.The majority of the flavor comes on the backend. I notice three distinct green fruits: white grape; Granny Smith apple and green pear. The only caveat is I have to reach for those flavors. Perhaps if I were drinking a fresher bottle these flavors would be more robust and more satisfying. As the beer warms the fruitiness becomes a bit stronger, but the yeast presence becomes drier. Theres a lingering dry bitter aftertaste from this beer, but its easily ignorable.DRINKABILITYAlthough my frame of reference with Trappist beers is rather limited, I would be surprised if I encounter a monks brew lighter and/or more refreshing than Westvleteren Blond. The first few sips have that peppery mouthfeel Belgian beers are known for, but it quickly mellows out and becomes soft and pillowy. The mild palate is certainly refreshing, and at only 5.8% ABV this is practically a "Trappist Lite" brew. If I had the means to buy this beer in bulk I would love to offer it up at summer picnics as I think it would pair well with lighter fare or just work as a great lawnmower beer.FINAL THOUGHTSWhile I wouldnt honestly consider Westvleteren Blond anything mind-blowing, it does impress (and slightly amaze) me that a beer this light and drinkable would be a Trappist brew.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQLZ9Rd8h6Q

Bottle:
Best before: 29-03-2002.
Nice small white foamy head on top of a hazy yellow orange beer.
Smell is mostly honey with some malts and sugars.
Taste is again a lot of honey; malts, light sweet, hint of hops.
Nice bitter but not too heavy. Well balanced, low carbo and a very nice hoppy, flower and dry-ish aftertaste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a dense white head that lasted the entire glass. Aroma- lots of citrus, grapefruit, dust, pine, and slight funk. Intense hallertauer(?) hop aroma. Taste- Light to medium body with HUGE funk and citrusy fruits. Finish - beautiful hop bitterness, crisp, clean, dry and wonderful funk on the back of the tongue. A nearly flawless beer.

Bottle. Large white foamy head over a hazy yellow gold body. Excellent lacing. The beer has a very clear hop aroma and taste-just like taking a handfull of hopbells from the hopfields adjacent to the abbey  in your hand and crushing them, with a subtle bitter sweet finish. Medium bodied, spritzy. Great beer.

Bottle @ In De Vrede, Westvleteren. What a splendid place to enjoy a Westy, right next to the monastery! On the other hand, it is also the ONLY place to (legally) enjoy a Westy served in proper glassware in a pub, so... Regardless, I had been looking forward to this missing link among the Westy family, so expectations were high. Although I must confess I think the style ("blonde") itself has its limitations, this is truly an exemplary specimen of the style. The glass comes with an inch-thick white foamy head, covering a perfect straw golden body. Nose is also extremely pleasant and well-balanced, with honey, tarty yeast, citric notes and hints of floral apricot. The first sip reveals why Westvleteren has been on top of the charts for so long: the blend of flavors, mostly analogue to the aromatic profile, is so smoothly blended that the only discernible flavor is a bitter, grassy hop aftertaste. Otherwise, this is a blended orgasm of the otherwise typical "Belgian blonde" tastes; truly a blissful composition of what the genre has to offer. Major thumbs up once again for the most elusive and exclusive brewery in the world. :-)

Pours a slightly cloudy, soft yellow color with a thick and foamy white head on top. The aroma is a bit understated, but prominent notes of yeast and citrus are still easy to notice. The flavor is bright and cheerful, yet earthy, with a combination of lemony citrus, a mild yeasty twang, and a  dry sweetness. The texture is the best part, though, with an initial effervescent punch to the tip of the tongue that somehow seems to disappear into an unexpected smoothness. It finishes dry and clean, but the result is light-and-airy rather than crisp-and-refreshing.

Cap dated xx.09.05, so, this is a 6 year old bottle. Have had this one fresh before, but tasting an aged one should be interesting. Thanks for a great extra, Greg!

A: The pour is the typical hazy golden straw color with a fluffy white head.

S: The nose is very floral and sweet, very honey-like to be frank. A nice orange note to it as well. A bit of yeast and perhaps some light fruit and spice esters.

T: Honey is definitely the primary flavor here, which is a stark contrast to a fresh bottle. Great honey, orange, and floral sweetness that is quite refreshing, actually.

M: The body is light with a crisp carbonation to it. Quite light on the tongue like you would expect.

D: I think I might actually like this aged version better than the fresh ones that I have tried. A really big difference in terms of flavor, and a beer that you generally would not recommend cellaring for this long, but I think it worked very nicely.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of malt, Belgian yeast, and a hint of fruit.  Poured apple juice/flaxen in color with a large, creamy, dense, slightly rocky, white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny and small-sized particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of Belgian yeast, malt, slight grass, dust, hops, and a hint of grain.  Medium body.  Smooth, then dry texture.  Average to slightly lively carbonation.  Belgian yeast, hops, and malt finish is dry.

I know Im rating this a little high but i really enjoyed this beer and have to say it is probably the most well balanced beer i have tried so far.  Starts off nice and bready with a good pale maltyness and belgian yeasts.  The light flowery hops come in right after and really balances the flavor out.  A buddy of mine called it perfectly drinkable and I have to agree, for a warm summer day this is perfect...if only I was closer to the source!  Light-medium in the mouth and finishes well. I wish i had more than one bottle. Big thanks to my brother for bringing this back for me!

Cette biere offre une belle robe jaune foncee, legerement trouble, une belle mousse blanche fine agreable, qui presage une carbonation bien presente ce que la premiere gorgee confirme. On retrouve des notes typiques de ce genre de biere, cereales, citron, citronelle, un peu gingembre une astringeance un peu the vert qui reste discrete, longue en bouche et rafraichissante. A lodeur cest tres alcoolique avec des notes dherbacees, alcool dailleurs aussi bien present en bouche, une biere de 5.8 tres impressionnante et bien balancee.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Bottle split with pat and vinny. Pours a deep hazy orange beer with nice white head that remains throughout.  Aroma is spicy,  malty, bready, slight saison. Classic Belgian flavors fill the smooth and light Mouthfeel. Great Belgian ale.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Vin. Courtesy of James. Pours a turbid haze blond with a modest, frothy white head. Lacing is nice and slender along the snifter walls. Aroma of fresh, fresh wheat baking in the sun and slight hints of earthy funk, soil, and yest. Not too complex. Flavor follows through on the same wheat and soil notes. Medium to light bodied with a soft, slightly funky palate. Overall, a fantastic, tasty, truly unique drinking experience. Awesome Belgian ale.

Bottle, thanks to fonefan.Pours cloudy yellow with a white head.Aroma dusty malt,cellar,citrus,honey and yeast.Flavor is spicy, sweet malt,cirus and cellar.Medium body ,average carbonation.Dry finish.

Bottle. Very pale, slightly cloudy, yellow pour with a thin white head. Aroma of pineapples, peaches a bit of citrus, trappist yeast (just a tad funky). Taste is very mellow, slightly sweet, yeasty with lots of fruit notes. Palate is superb like most all of the trappist beers. I could drink this forever (becoming a monk? hmmm appealing).

17/12/10 on the cap ..... Lightly cloudy golden pour lots of carbonation and tons of foamy white head aroma of bready malts and fruity yeast orange peel ... taste of fruity yeast zesty citrusy orange and peppery spice with a nice bite to it sweet fruity finish that left a decent amount of lacing ..... such a soft, smooth and clean tasting beer on the palate..... these monks drink well ... definitely worth the price paid
Drank it at the brewery, on a cold, sunny, crisp March day!!  I went to see the monks, they wont let you in, but they are very friendly.  Ill be back for sure.

Light hay pour, head is white and springs back up after a swirl. Aroma is doughy, yeasty, some orange peel, zesty, angel food cake.  Mouthfeel is super effervescent, flavor is citrus zest, dough, plenty of westy yeast, an amazing billowy mouthfeel.  Nice

Slightly hazy yellow pour with a good sized, bubbly white head and tons of yeast sediment. Aroma holds excellent doughy yeast components, along with notes of caramel, angel food cake, Cointreau, orange peel, and sweetbread. Flavor is light, with notes of banana, spice, a touch of peach skin, and more bready yeast. Mouthfeel is light with a beautiful billowy texture. Very drinkable. Awesome for the style.

Hazy peach pour with a lively white froth. The nose is angelfood cake dough, citrus (orange and lemon peel especially), with more yeasty notes in the finish. The flavor is huge banana clove with huge wheat malt and more orange citrus. Yeasty dough charactar is huge. The palate is highly effervescent with a pillowy, soft mouthfeel and a dry crisp finish.
Pours very nice, with a lasting heading. A bit over-carbonated, but still a nice on the tongue. Very floral nose. Tastest of cinammon, coriander, grapefruit, and orange peel.

Onsite at the Abbey St. Sixtus.  

Great example of a Belgian Blond.  A little barnyard-y and spicy/peppery.  Very drinkable and refreshing.  Pours hazy yellow/orange w/ big fluffy white head.  Smells of straw/grass, flavor continues to palate.  Lots of lively bubbles help make this a very nice Blond beer.

Courtesy of some very nice people.  Color is an cloudy yellow with a huge white head.  Aroma is hay and grass.  Taste is tough to pin down.  Maybe some ginger and vanilla and something I just cant put my finger on.  Palate is very crisp and dry.

33 cl bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color with a thick white head which dont last very long. Smells slightly citrusy with orange peel and spice. The taste matches the smell except i get hints of cedar wood and a hoppy slightly bitter finish. plenty of foamy carbonation. Probably the best blonde beer ive ever had.

Bottle.

Pours pale gold with a pillowy white head.

Aroma of hay, grass and wheat.

Dry taste with some grapes, a bit winey. Nice drinkabillity.

Poured honey yellow with a huge, thick white, lacing foam. Apple, grape, cinnamon and coriander in the tarty, almost vinous aroma.  Loads of malts and even more hops. Medium light body, with a bitter, dry aftertaste. Plenty of carbonation. More complexity that one would expect from a blond, overall rich. Refreshing, a truly fine brew.

Drank it @ "In De Vrede", in front of the abbey. Pours a slightly cloudy yellow to almost orange. Thick creamy white head, very little bells. A lot of carbon in the glass. Smells malty, with hints of citrus and koriander. A surprisingly bitter taste, a very pleasant mouth feeling. Turns to fruity and slightly citrus and grapefruit. Aftertaste is bitter spicy and very dry.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2015 Not as in love with this as their other products but this is still very good.  A little citrus-y a little note of grassy-ness, rather yeasty. Serving: Bottle

Bottle.  Golden with a white, permanent head.  Aroma of wildflowers: yeasty with grass and grain.  Strong carbonation, bubbly on the tongue; mid to full body.  Wonderful grain in the flavour with yeast, light spice, grass, dandelion.  A long grassy finish.
Bottle. Yellow, big white head. Hazy. Mild grassy hops in taste. Notes of elder. Some bitterness in aftertaste. Nice champagne-like carbonation. Quite shy but anyway interesting beer.

Un altro gioiello dell abbazia di Sint.Sixtus.Birra dal colore dorato con un perlage molto abbondante con schiuma compatta e cremosa e una buna persistenza.Allaroma sentori di erba fresca con note floreali date dal luppolo.E una birra facilmente bevibile,con una soffice sensazione in bocca data dalla perfetta carbonazione e dal corpo non troppo pesante e con un perfetto equilibrio.Al gusto parte dolcemente maltata per diventare poi secca quando entra in gioco il luppolo.Finisce secca e con una leggera acidità presente.E buonissima.

Thanks sooo much to Blankboy for sharing this gem on the occasion of the birth of my son :-) appearance: light orange, quite cloudy with chunks/floaties in there too. A small white head. Aroma: lots of honey, a little yeast, some good caramel notes too with a tangy, almost citrusness to it too. Flavour: tangy orange, a lovely oakiness too, vanilla, honey, quite a lot going on! Quite yeasty, a peppery property too with a delicious yeasty  finish. Lovely. Thanks Paul.

Poured a hazy yellow color with a thick white head which didnt last very long. Smells slightly citrusy with orange peel.and spice. The taste matches the smell except i get hints of cedar wood and a hoppy slightly bitter finish. plenty of foamy carbonation. Probably the best blonde beer ive ever had.

Tasted at In de Vrede. Yellow, lightly golden coloured. A bit unclear. Big nice hoolding white head that forms a nice cloud while going down. Hoppy, citrus, spiced smell. Sour-sweet hoppy citrus frtuis, spiced good brew. I prefer the 8 and 12, but for sure, this is a good beer. Good spiced and a lightly nice aftertaste. Good balance

Bottle gushed a bit when opened.  Yeast sediment clearly on the bottom.  Stray yellow with a lingering thin white head with aroma of citrus, floral, a little spice.  Dry finish with  more citrus, spice and malt in the taste.  Excellent blonde!

(Old BA rate - bottle)
ight hazy, straw yellow with a fizzier looking frothy white head. Decent head retention. Very mild yeastiness, a bit of sour fruit aromas, and some hay-like aromas. Very mild touch of hop bitterness toward the end. Pretty representative of the style in that there is a wheaty yeastiness, very muted touch of hops, lightish malt presence. Didnt get the sour that was present in the nose. Actually, not overly complex but very nice and refreshing. Ligther/thinner body and a bit of carbonation that tends to be a bit snappier for the style, but still ok IMO.  Really drinkable and refreshing, but since it wasnt overly complex I wasnt coming back expecting my palate to be intrigued with every sip. Overall, this is certainly more than a solid brew, but I have to say not one of the best Belgian Pales that Ive had. I am still more than happy to have tried the ever elusive Westvleterens take on the style.

Hazy pale straw color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, floral, citrus, & spice; Flavor of malt, yeast, hops, citrus (notably orange & lemon), some fruit, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, very good - and unique spicy flavor.

Poured a brown labeless bottle into a Chimay Goblet.

Appearance: rich golden chilly hazy looking beer with a good head. Not as much retention as I thought it would have ( the stemware is probably a factor) but a pretty glass of liquid indeed.

Smell: Nice floral note over a gentle hay grass quality.

Taste: fairly complex for a blond showing hints of hay, wheat, grass, malt, and yeast. A slight hop note as well.

Mouthfeel: Not the smoothest or most creamy blond but an excellent one none the less.

Drinkability: Good

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-30-2008

330 ml bottle - big thanks to phaleslu for the trade a while back; like some other beers Ive traded for, for some reason this just sits and sits in the fridge as it never seems quite like the right moment to crack it open; just finished brewing a belgian blonde myself today, so what the hell?  pale yellow pour with eggy white head reaching the top of my karmeliet glass and resting down slowly; rising tower in the center is the last bit to collapse; earthy lemons, light cloves, white pepper, dry malt, leaves, salt and fresh yeast; just a lovely nose; fresh flowers and creamy yeast; I know this is not fresh (nearly 6 months in my possession alone), but it seems very vibrant to me; mouthfeel is light and silky with a fluffy quality to the texture that is almost creamy; like other trappist beers, I always think that its the water; sugary salt, lemons, yeast, orange peel and dry spice; crisp, clean with lingering sweetness and dry malt coating the teeth; wow, freshness and sweet yeast pops in the mouth going down; light flavor profile, but increasingly complex the more I drink; almost gone and wishing this came in a 750 (or a nebuchadnezzar!!); easily my fav of the Westvleteren beers and one I could drink all day; awesome, awesome beer; sucks that my glass is now empty :(
Pours a nice golden color with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of honey and clove, with hints of banana and spice.  Sweet start with a nice foamy bitter dry finish.  Solid blonde.
Pours a hazy blonde with a white head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is clove and yeast.  Taste is a muted sweetness.  Crisp mouthfeel with a dry finish.

Bottled sample consumed at Cambrinus. Gold in colour with fairly strong carbonation. Aromas are of clover honey, pale malts, and sweet grasses. Honey elements take on a more wildflower character in the mouth, and mix well with clean pale malt flavors and some understated earthy hops, and  yeast derived spiciness. Dry on the palate, with a long savory finish. Very classy stuff.

Pours cloudy straw with a big head. Hints of clove, and a little fruity. Tastes sweet but not to much. Same clove coming through along with the fruity aroma translating to the taste. Great balance. Very drinkable. Good cool/warm spring evening beer. Goes down really good sitting out at the cafe looking over at the monastery.

This must have been a bad batch. My first westvleteren blonde and the nose is of rancid diacetyl! The flavour is also ruined by the diacetyl. Must try again but felt I should add this as for one of the most well reputed breweries in the world there shouldn;t be any bad batches.

Bottle consumed at home from De Struise e-shop. Poured into my Westvleteren glass. Thanks Carlo and Urbs. MASSIVE HEAD. Rediculas scale. Got to wait for this one. A rather earthy smell, malty smell and hey too. Silky smooth down the throat. A real throat penetrator. Awesome palate. Bang on. Top marks there. Dry citrus hops. Caramel; earthy textrure and a little hey. Maybe some clove too. A really good blonde this. Better at the Cafe but need to go back. Cheers Carlo and Urbain. You guys are awesome.

Bouteille de 330 ml offerte en cadeau par BeerBuzzMontreal, merci Denis. Arôme: Légère odeur dagrumes et de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est blonde voilée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes avec une pointe de poire et de poivres. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement citronné. (Rating #3024)

Bottle.

A - Just slightly clouded golden honey color with an average foamy, sudsy very white head with good retention that settles into a nice foamy layer of lacing that sticks to the glass.

S - Nice mix of some grassy and herbal aroma with a vibrant fruity esters aroma, featuring apple, lemon, a touch of orange and pear. Also has a nice spiced aroma in the background with some clove, coriander and a hint of pepperiness. Yeast aromas are also wafting in the background. Very enticing armoa just begging me to take a sip.

T - Didnt quite live up to the smell unfortunately. Good malty and bready taste serves as a base for a nice mix of fruits and grassy/herbal hops. Plenty of apple and pear along with lemon and a touch of orange like citrus. Mixed in with these and really coming out mid-sip is a good spiced flavor with spices similar to the nose. The hop flavors wax and wane throughout the sip, but never get too powerful and only provide a touch of bitterness. Sweet maltiness comes up a bit at the finish. Nice balanced flavors that are just a touch too light for me.

M - Somewhere between medium and light body with a large amount of carbonation. A bit of a spritzy kind of feel with a touch of drying on toward the end. Fairly creamy while drinking it though.

D - Exceptionally drinkable beer. Mouthfeel is very refreshing and easy to drink and the flavors are enjoyable and make me want to drink more (as does the aroma). Could easily drink this anytime and want another one. 

Notes: Best before 06/08/10. Enjoyable beer that was light and refreshing. The taste was a touch too thin/light for my liking, but I think some of that may have been due to the age, which wasnt the freshest but it wasnt too old either (I would really like to try one of these really fresh). Overall a solid beer and very good example of the style. Wonderful smelling and very easy to drink, and refreshing. It gets overshadowed by the other two, but if you have a chance to get this one definitely give it a try.

Thanks to my cousin for cracking open another classic, hard-to-find brew. Love those label-less Westvleteren bottles with the raised ring around the neck.  It looked a little strange, like green-gray water from a city river, but with an attractive head.  Fresh hop aroma.  Smooth, bready, and lightly fruity, with wheat toast and bubble gum in the flavor.  A fine lighter Belgian ale.
Light, musty aroma.  Golden with excellent, fluffy white head.  Overall very light and dry.  Crystal-malty with subtle earthy hoppiness and spice tones.  A bit light but very refreshing.

Bottle: Straight from the brewery to San Salvador thanks to ramenen who shared it with rcasta, rsamayoa and myself. Pours very fizzy with just a slight hint of sweet aromas, taste is dry, little salty. Food Pairing: Pasta with vegetables.
Gracias ramenend con el aleman y el pollo, traida desde la caja de medicinas de lo monjes

humle,lidt honning, citron, Ud.:hvidgul,klar,hvidt tæt,rolig  E.smag:sød lidt,bitter moderat kro: medium, for olie brus:flad 
(33cl f)[home]

An unclear golden beer with a nice white head. The aroma is very clean, grainy, light citrus, and you can smell the sweet nectar from the barley. The taste is very grainy, very clean also. Like pure liquid grains which is what beer is. Very refreshing.

Very excited to try this! Poured into my Chimay Chalice.

A- Body is a very cloudy, translucent golden yellow. Pours with a beautiful creamy 1/2 finger white head that has perfect retention. A white film is left all the way down the glass. When held up to the light one can see that the cloudiness is thick and dynamic with some dark yeast sediment lingering throughout as billowing bubbles rise from the center of the glass.

S- A soft fruity presence is the first thing detected in the nose. The fruitiness is mellow but offers hints of pear, white grape, and exotic fruit. This is accented by a peppery spice and soft floral hops.

T-The flavor upfront is very mild with peppery spice, bubblegum, pear, and exotic fruit all mixing together wonderfully and there is a slight earthy, musty background. A distinctive soft floral hop flavor comes through for the finish along with a mild bready yeast sweetness. The finish is pretty dry and all that lingers is a mild to moderate floral hop bitterness in the back of the palate.

P- Medium to high carbonation and wonderful light to medium weight, smooth, yeasty body.

O- This is a wonderful blonde ale that has a very soft character. Well put together and very drinkable. I would love to try this fresh and would definitely have it again. Now the search is on for Trappist Westvleteren 8. Too bad these are so expensive...

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2009 20:08:47

Bottle from Cracked Kettle I think?  Pours a light yellowish gold with a great big tight sticky shiny pure white head and some streaky lace.  Aroma is herbal earthy mineral, Belgian phenolic yeast, and sea foam, with slight earthy and solvent or musty tones- crackery malts, and a bit of stale oxidized paper- perhaps not as fresh as could be- still has some herbal and grassy hops though.  Flavor is earthy nutty, cracker malts, grass, herbs, earthy and leather, airy phenolic light spicy note on the tongue with a very clean dry crackery malt profile - light grassy hops, herbs, woodsy tones- with hints of woodruff and vanilla, and some slight stale papery malt character. Finish is airy smooth and dry- almost has a marshmallow or creme brulee airiness to it that gives it a very unique mouthfeel.  Smooth and dry finish- still nice even though it isnt as fresh as it should be.

My favorite beer with the "Des Vignes Vent dAnge". What can I say : it is light but tasty, easy to drink but complex, complex but subtle...it smells yeast and citrus. The taste is floral, grassy, fruity and bitter. The perfect blonde (after me:-)

Thanks to GodofThunder.  Pours a cloudy gold with nice white lace.  Good nose with bright malt notes, spice, even some grassy hops.  Very mild but tasty and refreshing flavor.  Malt overpowers the hops though they do come through just a tad in the finish creating an excellent bitter/sweet balance.  So happy I got to try this elusive and very delightful beer.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2010 Usually I am not found of blondes. But this ones marvelous. It has similarities with the other Westvleteren. Especially the nose, maybe due to the yeast. Onctuous and fruity like liqour. The finish is bitter and quite dry. Great blonde

thanks to Godofthunder for sharing this!  Spicy nose, citrus notes with candi sugar.  Pours blonde with a thick white head with a slight haze.  Very spicy, bready, grassy, earthy, somewhat floral, with a very dry finish.  Very nice beer!  A treat to try!!!
33cl bottle. Pours a golden color. Aroma: hops, yeast and a bit fruity. Hoppy flavor with medium bitterness. I expected much more from The Monks.
Shared this one w/SkyCop32. Pours a medium golden yellowish color. Aromas of hops, fruit, yeast and some pepper. Flavors are hoppy, citrus, and a touch of bittersweet dust at the finish.

First tasted 2009-06-06 at In de Vrede at St. Sixtus Abbey, but this rating is based on a bottle I picked up at Bier Tempel in Brussels. 330 mL bottle, expiry 2010-03-31, served in a branded Trappist glass. Pours clear golden with a tall, frothy white head. Head has great retention and great lace. A small amount of fine sediment managed to sneak its way out of the bottle. Aroma is primarily fresh yeast and spice with light malts and floral hops. Flavours of dry malts and spice throughout with bitter hops entering toward the finish. Finish is moderate and bitter. Light in body with a smooth, dry texture and lively carbonation. Overall, a well-constructed light session ale, perfect for a cool summer afternoon. That this is brewed for daily consumption at St. Sixtus makes me think I should have chosen an alternate career! 2010-03-28

Bottle my wife tracked down online for an awesome Christmas present. Pours with a big foamy head, grassy nose with a little sourdough in the aroma. Sharp mouthfeel wakes up the tongue. Nice crisp flavors in this clean, refreshing, peppery brew. This would be an amazing, complex, easy-drinking session beer...if I could get it.
Bottle. Pours slight hazy golden coloured with a big frothy egg white head. Aromas of yeast, fresh citrus fruits, spice and bananas. Flavours of pale malt, yeast, citrus and some spice. Tasty brew.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2011 330mL at In De Vrede at St Sixtus Abbey with elite crew of Urbeer, Travlr, and ofosho. Pours a gorgeous hazy blond with the lacing of God. Beautiful tropical fruits in the aroma along with Kent Goldings hops, loads of florals, orange juice, pineapple, must, and even some light funk. Taste is EKG hops, Fuggles hops, pale malts. Soft carbonation on the palate. 3/15/2010 9/5/7/4/15=4.0330mL 2009 ed thanks to Travlr. As always, a beautiful glowing pour with full sheets of lace. Clove, cinnamon, mild tartness, pineapple and mango dominate aroma and taste with fresh and floral Brett coming through in the nose. Palate is not drained by the Brett and retains a rich, creamy body full of mango sorbet. Really incredible stuff. 7/17/2011 8/5/8/4/16=4.1

Pours a cloudy yellow with a rocky white head. Aroma is amazing. Citrus malt yeast spice. This was nose heaven for sure. Flavor was slightly underwhelming. Citrus notes, but some raw grain weirdess and a little bit of a grainy texture on the palate. Tasty all told though.

Bottle at Ontmoetingscentrum In de Vrede, next to the abbey. Pours a hazy yellow with a thick foamy creamy lacing white head. Aroma is fruity, banana, peach, wheat and with bready yeasts. Flavor is slightly bitter, spicy and fruity. Smooth and creamy texture. Decent lively carbonation. Nice lingering bitter finish. Great blonde.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2010 Bottle @ In de Vrede, served too cold. Hazy yellow pour, thick off white creamy head. Aroma of citrus, banana, yeast, spices, herbs and some sour fruit. Lots of poperingse hop. Flavour is smooth bitter fruit followed by a hint of sweetness.
Very nice beer, Id love to drink this on a hot summer day.
Pours a cloudy dirty yellow with a small pure white head.  Very nice aroma of lemon with a little spice.  Flavor is citrus and dry, and mouthfeel a little grainy.  Nice.

For me the best Westvleteren, although sadly it replaced the Westvleteren 6. Nice hoppy taste, you can actually taste the different hops beeing used one after another. Only tiny downpoint is that for some reason the head did not stay up as long as on the Wv 12 or Wv8. But that could just be me. And ofcourse that they just dont brew this beer often enough...
Bottle. Hazy pale yellow body with medium size white head. Flaovur is sweet, malt and fruit.

33 cl bottle, tasting at Rogers place (12.12.09). Golden yellow color, more and more hazy down the bottle. White head. Aroma fruity, citric and has a bit yeast. Flavor is fruity with some spices. Moderate sweetness. Mild and very fine blond.
caramel, amber, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, lively. nice beer but to old.

Bottle from Secret Santa 09/10.  Bigtime thanks!  Nose has that great trappist yeast character with very subtle grains.  Color is a nice gold yellow.  Flavor was either too subtle for me or maybe the yeast died: shallow, rindy grain, no yeast character to taste, almost a soapiness.  Surprisingly bland and papery.  Glad I had it - suspect this was a bad bottle.
Hazy pale yellow, frothy white head. Aroma of lemon, grass, honey, yeast. Taste is smooth sweet bready grain and farmhouse notes with some citrus hops. Carbonation is smooth, medium but rich body.

Blond with a white head and lasting foam.  Lots of yeast character with generous spice and herbal hops in the aroma.   se sweetness and green hop matter.  Pils malt, a little sweet some herbal hops and light-med bitterness. Quite bready. Nice blond ale with nice malt expression and hops.

Aroma of wheat, yeast, sugar and subtle alocohol.  Big fluffy 2 finger head, tight compact bubbles.  Cloudy, orange-yellow color, speckled with sediment, which I chose to pour.  Taste matches aroma, with additional notes of banana and vanilla.  Smooth mouth feel.  Overall, an excellent blond.
Unfiltered blond beer. Taste is very refreshing with a bitter aftertaste. Aroma is of citrus.

330 ml bottle. Whiteish yellow golden colour. Slight haze. Lots of carbonation. Very tall white fine-laced head that clings to the glass. Sort of citrusy aroma with a crisp yeasty nose. Very delicate. Crisp carbonated pilsener malt flavours. Slightly grainy. Light-bodied. Hops are quite dry and leaves a papery slightly bitter sensation.

(New Years Eve tasting Flight (1 of 3 7:30p)) Westvleteren Blond - Poured huge white snowy head that looks like a fine egg meringue. Slightly off-yellow body. Lots of bubbles coming up from the middle of the glass. Aroma of banana and yeast. Light body. Slight bitterness of hops. Yeast flavor characteristic somewhat grassy. I can see how this could easily be a session beer for the monks in the monastery. Hops linger on palate for a short amount of time. Wish this was regularly available at a less than extorsion price here on the Left Coast. :-)

Pours clear light golden with a white frothy/creamy head. Aroma of clove and fresh white bread. Mellow sweet and bitter flavor followed by a moderately bitter and lightly alcoholic finish. Light to medium bodied. Well balanced.
(Bottle, courtesy of tarjei 12.12.2009)

12oz bottle... Pours a hazy golden hue with a thin milky white head... Aroma of apricot, pear, and lighter fruit. Yeast esthers and sweet tea also prevail... Sweet apricot and yeast flavors that finishes on a dry note. Sweet  and musty.

Wow was really not expecting this from a Blond even a Westy Blond. was sooo nice. dry with fruity and spicy notes all over soo drinkable. aged this for 2 years and had with Fresh Lobster. Best Blond i have ever had!!!

Im thinking about becoming a monk, this blond is one of the best I could even imagine.  Its light in color, and palate, but hoppy and has just the perfect carbonation to support its role as a supremely drinkable, never offensive beer.

Bottle poured a hazy golden yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of straw , spice, pear and light pineapple. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, pear and light spice with a smooth dry finish.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Kicked off a night of drinking with shawnm213 with this, and it didnt disappoint.  Pours a murky gold color with a nice big, even, creamy white head.  Pleasing aroma of yeast, sugar, earthy hops, citrus, straw, herbs, spices (especially clove), biscuit, and melon.  Malty, biscuity, melony flavor, with a nice blend of spices (clove and pepper), earthy notes, hops, and sugar.  A note of citrus shows up late.  Medium bodied, with gentle carbonation.  Very clean, earthy character.  Complex, well-balanced, and tasty.  Ive never had anything better with Blond on the label, even if its called a Belgian Ale here.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 Bottle shared by phaleslu-  thanks peter!  Pours a hazy golden orange with a white fluffy head.  spotty lace.  aroma of banana, peary yeast, cloves, spices, herbs, earth.  flavor is toast, grass, hay, earth.   by far the best blone ale ive ever had.  awesome beer.  really well made.  rerates... three more bottles all awesome.   love this beer.  bright clean creamy grassy wheat.   touch of bubblgum and cloves.   a favorite.

Clear golden color with an enormous ivory-colored rocky head. Good head retention and nice chunky lacings.

A fresh and balanced smell. Malts, wheat crackers, hints of grass, sweet Belgian yeast and mild herbal hop notes.

The taste is actually very full considering the style and level of ABV. Plenty of herbal and spicy notes of hops and yeast on top of a biscuity malts. Grass and some citric notes. Its rather sweet with some complementary bitterness. The finish is surprisingly bitter with a noticeable taste of sweet alcohol. Hints of phenols and white pepper. Refreshing and very easy to drink.

Medium body, medium carbonation. Somewhat oily texture.

A first class easygoing beer. Very flavorful considering the style and strength.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
Very nice blonde, Smells a bit like Westmalle but is a little less tastefull. Aroma is hops, flowers and malts. taste is fine and end with a fine bitter touche of hops.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2013 22nd Febuary 2008 Bottle in the Kulminator. Light floral and dry. Not too fruity. This is an okay beer but I dont understand why people go mad on it other than (perhaps justifiable) reverence overspill from the 8 and the 12. Original Score - 3.031st August 2013Hazy light gold beer,tidy white head. Palate is light and minerally crisp, turning softer and semi dry. The head has a little lemon sherbet and floral hops. Some cream in the pale malt. Dry floral bitterness with a whisper of lemon. Touch of herbal grass. Finishes smooth and semi dry.

Very nice refreshing blond that looks.. Blond with a lovely thick white foam on top. Aroma is sweet malty with refreshing balanced hops. Mouthfeel is fairly lively but not harsh or thin like many other blond ales. Flavour is sweet malty, earthy, slightly biscuity and light hoppy. Very well balanced and refreshing.

Great looking yellow blond beer with a fine carbonation and a nice looking white head. Aroma is refreshing and slight hoppy with a soft pils or Duvel like character. Taste is medium dry, with good refreshing bitters and a nice dry malty mouthfeeling. It has a fine hoppy bitterness in the end
Bottle. Drank it in Brugges. How could I not give the baby brother of the other Westies a perfect score. The best I have had of this "style". If one can find it, drink it.

#300. Bottle from Bier Tempel Brussels. Pours murky cloudy gold - just a monster of a head. I believe the first person to use the term lacing was drinking  a Westy blond. Nose is all kinds of good. Yeasty wheat, white pepper, some earth and sugar. Flavor starts with a citric lemon zest and more of the yeast and then transitions to an earthy, spicy slightly funky taste. Finish is so dry that you nearly forget you just had a swallow. Awesome. I tried to savor it, but it lasted about 5 minutes tops. Great, great stuff.
Murkey golden color, dense head with nice lacing. Lemon/citrus, nutmeg, ginger, wheat and a bitof something I cant place. Smooth hops. Delicious.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a murky pale golden beer with a nicely lasting lacing creamy white head. The aroma is rather inviting with candy sugar, yeast, biscuity pale malt, brown sugar, a lot of spicy, faintly earthy hops, melon, tarragon and maple syrup showing up . Lovely bitterness in the taste. Great biscuity malt profile accompanied by spicy, earthy hops. Crackers, melon, tarragon and candy sugar showing up. Subtle carbonation. Medium bodied. Peppery. Slightly alcoholic on the swallow. Long dry finish which is reminiscent of lemon peel and tarragon. A trappist beer with plenty of charater. Surprisingly bitter.

[330ml bottle that Lee bought back from Belgium - cheers!] Bit of a special one for my 500th rating!  Pours gold with a large, lasting white head. Looks very fizzy. Smells of wheat, with plenty of citrus and a bit of white pepper.  On tasting, the fizziness turns out not to be as aggressive as it looks, but is instead a lovely mouth-coating tingle - similar to Orval, but not quite as good.  Flavourwise, lemon dominates, with wheat and spice in the background.  Its remarkably easy to drink, and I found myself knocking it back in next-to-no time and wanting another.  Its strong for a session beer, but it certainly feels like something Id like to session!  So, potentially it could have been the worlds greatest session beer; however, for me a hint of sourness in the finish stopped it short of true geatness.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2009 [bottle--thanks, fonefan!]
Sweet, estery aroma with pomegranate, lemon, and faint pine accents. Hazy, dull gold under a dense, lasting, white foam. Sweet, slightly sugary malt that well balanced by a delicate, dry bitterness. Some dried fruit notes together with a spicy estery finish. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, bitterness hangs on a bit in the finish.
