Thanks a ton to 17thfloor for sharing this one! Pours a deep hazy soft orange with a billowy white head, Aroma is big plumy, A definite lemon bread character that is soft on the nose but still rich and delightful. A bit of a cheesiness rounds out the balance. Flavor starts with a sharp lemon and hoppy bite before becoming a dry zesty lemon peel tongue turner. The lemon stays through the finish and adds a nice slight tartness that sits and rides in the throat along with a gorgeous yeasty that is so specific that it becomes a dominant feature rather than an accompaniment to the hops. Nice round body and a dryer character. Very tasty and rounded to a perfect balance, very refreshing.

Bottle in de Vrede. Hazy golden body with lasting white head. Aroma has little sourness and very floral hoppiness. Very clear hop aroma with pine scent. Flavor has nice hoppiness in the beginning with bitter pine taste, aftertaste is dry and clear. Very well balanced beer. Mouthfeel is full with lot of freshness. Excellent Beer in every way!

330 cl bottle. In de Vrede, Westvleteren, Belgium. Hazy yellow colour with creamy white small to medium-size head. Smooth hoppiness and spices in aroma. Bitter dry hoppiness in flavour. Some spices too. Long-lasting hoppy aftertaste. No hoppy overdose. Excellent Belgian Ale!

UPDATED: APR 22, 2015 (bottle) hazy golden colour with a frothy white head and a few yeast floaties. aroma of wheat, yeast and banana, slightly tart and musty, with a hint of floral hops and frozen peas. flavour is mostly grainy wheat and yeast, rather chalky, with a touch of alcohol, some thyme and a semi-dry light-bitter finish. full-bodied with lively carbonation.

Rating number 200!!! Hell yeah bitches. Thanks Butters for the hook up on the bottle. Light yellow in color. Cream of lemon. Aroma reminds me of a saison or farmhouse ale. Very clean. Not the sweet blonde I was expecting. This is the kind of beer that you could drink all day. Super clean. Flavors are very elegant, feminine, and relaxed. Rich yeast and bread. Its great. Like a light saison beer meant for everyday consumption. thank you munks.

11.2oz sampled at Butters 1500 / MmmcKays 200 tasting.  For MmmcKays 200th rating.  Pours a small particulate filled gold with thin layer of white head.  Nose is suprisingly tart citrus lemon urinal cake, preparing me for a saison.  Flavor is subtle and elegant vanilla, hops, lemon zest, yeast.  I thought this beer would be overrated, but it is not.  Very good.

Pours a light cloudy straw with wispy white head. Aroma of hay, farmhouse, spice, citrus, grass. Very crisp taste of wheat, lemon, earthiness, yeast, light hops. Really enjoyed this, glad I had the opportunity to taste this extremely rare beer.

Pours a lasting, fizzy, white head with a hazy, straw color body.  Aromas of yeast, dough, anise, zest, vanilla, and grass.  Repeat aroma for flavor, doesnt quite live up tho.  Fizzy, malty body with a dry finish.

Bottle.  Nice yellow gold pour with pretty thick head.  Straw sweetness, light fruit, and earthy yeast.  Flavor is the same, with lemony freshness, a small amount of dark sugar, and same pleasant earthiness.  It was substantially better when it warmed.

Tasted alongside the 8 and the 12 at KC beer bloggers Brew Day 3.0.  Poured into a chalice with enormous, wild head.  Pours a hazy straw yellow with white small-bubbled foam.  This is a very light summery Belgian - light fruits, slightly sweet aroma, and just a touch of witbier spices layered in.

Flavor is very smooth, not too wild on the hops, smooth grain malts, and a bit of yeasty goodness.

At the Vrede. Drank it next to the 12 (and the 8). You cant compare it with the other two. This hints towards Orval, but less fruity: blond, small head, bitter, hoppy, not much alcohol, a little bit fruity at the finish. Nicely refreshing beer.

Bottle at In de Vrede. Hazy yellow with a medium head. Great lacing. Nice color. Aroma is malty and citrusy. Very fresh. Some hops, coriander and fruits. Taste is spicy, malty. Hints of coriander and alcohol but not much. Incredible lacing. Best belgian blond ever.
Bottle thanks to bhops. Hazy gold in color with a small white head. Aroma and taste are very grainy, with some light hops, yeast, and a good amount of spices.

Big thanks to BDR and whoever sent it to him.  Cloudy gold color with a thin head.  Aroma of bananas, wheat, candi sugar and yeast.  Very dry wheat and malt flavor.  Lots of floral and earthy hops, much more than I expected.  Quite tasty.

Bottle at Cafe in de Vrede (yeah!).  Slightly cloudy golden color with a lasting white head.  Aroma of pale malt, honey, yeast, and spices.  Flavor more of the same, somewhat complex and very well-balanced.  Medium bodied and smooth with gentle carbonation.  A phenomenal Belgian blond ale, as good as the style gets.

Unlabelled bottle into chalice glass at Cambrinus in Bruges (recommended If you are in town). A cloudy golden beer with a decent sized foamy white head. Nose is mild honey malts and soft spices. The taste is refreshingly uncomplicated with a sweet grainy malt backbone  giving way to a to a soft spicy hop presence providing a delightful soft bitterness to the finish. Extremely moreish with a medium body and soft carbonation. A great beer.

It poured a hazy golden liquid with a medium sized foam that left no lacing. There was also some yeast in the liquid.

It had a strong smell of citrus, orange, yeast, honey and spices. A fairly promising start.

The first thing I noticed while tasting this beer was that it had some honey in it. Besides that it was very fizzy which hid the flavor. After letting the beer rest for a while some more sides emerged, it had a spicey and dry taste, yet smooth and easy to drink. It had a small body which made it seem a bit watery and boring. But it was still a fairly solid beer even though it couldnt match up to its bigger brothers.

Bottle from Bier Temple. Pours a hazy light gold with a fine white head. Aroma of light spice and light malt. Medium body with lightly frothy carbonation. Flavors of yeast/spice, pale malt and arguably grassy hop. Could be hopperinge hop. Very clean. Very tasty. Almost chewy. Its just plain wonderful.

Bottle Thanks to Sam for another fresh tasty Westvleteren brew. Pours out a straw topped a cream head. Aroma of light spice a nice fresh hop and some sweetness. Tast of a belg yeast a nice spice and some light hops. All around great brew.

33cl bottle from BierTempel in Brussels. Pours a cloudy straw yellow. Aroma is sweet with nice hoppiness and freshness to it. Taste is clean, and very well balanced. Nothing seems to stand out. Sweet notes and bitter with perfect balance.  Nice, long, clean bitter finish. Very enjoyable.
Good taste, but feels weak after sampling Westvleterens other beers. Lemon scent and taste, some complexity, and a great example of a Trappist Blonde.

33cl Bottle. Slightly hazy golden color. Huge foamy white head. Grassy and yeasty aroma. Medium body. Malty taste with lots of grassy hops and a touch of yeast and some distinct fruit. Very unusual and highly drinkable.

My 1st review. Nice pale orangish color with strong smell of Belgian hops, cloves, citrus and a lot of florals. Reminds me of Orval but better. Can easily enjoy a few of these while still enjoying the ale completely.
2008 Bottle - Thanks Sam! - Pours hazy tan with a white head...aroma is spicy lemon, fruit and hop florals...flavour is malty, with an underlying bitterness, pithy with some clove...nice brew...
Hazy orange in colour with thick white head. Citrus lemon aroma hint of clove. Big thick mouth feel, wood clovey flavours.

Flaske: Kæmpe gusher. Flot gul øl med et fint skumhoved. Desværre gjorde gushingen at en masse proteinklumper røg op i øllen. Mærkbar bitter og frisk selvom den har et år på bagen. Virkelig god drikbar sessionbeer.

This beer pours with a massive 3 inch head that slowly settled down to a quarter inch of foam floating on top of my brew, the body of this is a opaque brown with a hint of yellow and small brown flavor nugets floating through out, a very nice looking beer. Yeast and wheat dominate the aroma with a slight sour and banana hiding in the background, this smells very similar to a hefe with out the spice. Just like in the smell wheat and yeast dominate the taste, making this beer very light and refreshing, there is what I think is a very slight grape juice flavor hiding under all the yeast its very hard to pick up. The mouth feel is very soft and powdery, and after taste is very bitter. Im very glad I picked this beer up off of E-Bay because its a once in a life time beer for me, and it wasnt disappointing but it sure didnt wow me for the absurd price I had to pay, so heres hoping the 8, and 12 make it worth the price.

Thanks goes to Brad for selling his soul and crushing those monks wishes by paying an ungodly ammount of cash, which he wired to Belguim (dunce) amongst other things, to get a set of Westys to drink off of some beerpimp on EBay. Poured an amazingly colossal huge white head which ended up looking like a giant nipple. Murky brownish orange and lots o floaties. Awsome lacing...left large remnant rings in the glass. Aromas consisted of slight banana, that hard christmas candy that your Grandma leaves out in the living room, soft lemon, fruity yeasts and a slight spice. A very soft, fresh, complex aroma that takes time to figure out. Tastes pretty mild with lots of yeast, something that seems like wheat, and a very slight citrus note. Dont forget a bit of soapy flavour and some unknown flavour too. Really gassy! Pretty weak on the mouthfeel, but there is a harsh watery bitterness that seems out of place. Soft and smooth. Light to medium bodied. Too watery.

Bottle thanks to bhops. The smell is sweet, fruits, malts, slight spices, and yeast.  The look is orange in color, clearish, and a decent off white head.  The taste is yeast, fruits, spices, and some sweetness.

bottle - Pours hazy blonde and bubbly with a one finger white head.  The bottle was a gusher and I had to be quick to ensure minimal beer loss.  It has a malty aroma with some mild fruit notes.  The flavor is of sweet citrus accented malt and some mild hops that leads a dry, balancing finish.  It has a smooth mouthfeel and is what it intends to be, a good session ale.

The next 8 or so beers were courtesy of pfoxyjohn. A late morning early afternoon tasting in the Barrrrn: Into the glass it pours a bright cloudy golden colour with a fairly large white head. Noticeable tartness or maybe lots of yeast, that could be it. Lemon peel, orange rind on the nose with a very astringent mouthfeel. Has a pleasent carbonation all the way down with thousands of tiny little bubbles dancing around the mouth.
Poured golden yellow, CO2, smooth, sweet, light malt, grainy, little citrus, slight yeasty.
Golden pour with thick white head. Malt and yeast aroma. Nice lacing on the glass. Little spicy aftertaste. Dry malty mouthfeel. Tasty.

Pours straw blond with a three finger frothy head that oddly starts as tight bubbles. Nice lacing sticks around. Nose is sweet with wheat and grain. The flavor is smooth and also a bit sweet with citrus. Quite refreshing with a mildly sweet finish.
bottle thanks to bhops.  poured yellow with no head.  aroma of citrus and banana.  flavor was citrus and banana as well.  light body with low carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of Superdave70. Pale aroma of wheat and spice. Hazy yellow body with good white cramy head and some decent lacing. Flavor started out with a wheat and spicey bittering. But middle o finish bitterness subsided and the cramy texure of head added some fruit cream flavor which was good. Dry on the palate asthespicey bitter that disipated earlier reappears and lingers. Good brew, thanks Dave.

Colore chiaro con buona schiuma molto persistente,aroma di agrumi e un pò erbaceo.Sapore speziato e di agrume molto fresca e piacevole.La migliore insieme alla Orval tra le blonde belghe che abbia mai bevuto.Una delle preferite in generale
Bottle thanks to bhops. Hazy orange color with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus, little bit of spice. Flavor of citrus, wheat, and yeast.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2016 Bottle. Yellow clear body, with a large white head. Aroma is citrus, yeast and spices. Flavor is the same. Blond is not my favourite type of beer. 6,3,6,3,15

RE-RATE:
Clear golden body with a small white head. Citrus, Belgian yeast, some spices, light hops. Good.

Bottle thanks to Cletus, best by April 7 2008, so Im solid. Pours a cloudy orange color with a thick white head. Slight gushing upon open. A nice aroma of fruity apples and citrus, some rich spicy malts also. Of course, lots of that amazing yeast from Westvleteren. The flavor is a pleasing mix of yeast, citrus, wheat and rich malts. A somewhat fizzy and smooth mouthfeel. My expectations were somewhat subdued here, but this beer is exactly what it should be. A very interesting easygoing Trappist brew.

sample at the Ale Atlanta meeting on 4/2/09.  deep yellow / blond in color with some white head... some citrus, yeast and spice notes on the nose... medium body with Belgian yeast and a light bitterness.  overall one of the best Belgian blond ales, extremely smooth and drinkable.  Too bad its so hard to come by.

Bottle 33cl. Pours a golden cloudy brew with a nice fluffy creamy white head. Nose: floral dreid hops, hay, citrus. Taste: Easy drinkable, quenching taste, a bit watery in comparison to orval. Slightly hoppy, fresh. Balanced, malty undertones. Belgian yeast. A very good belgian ale.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2011 26.04.2011, selebrated the birth of my third child with this beer, very tired but again a nice experience. Golden, clear with a huge white head. Hoppy, prune and yeast aroma7. Again fresh and fruity with a malty sence. 12 is the number 1 2.

Bottle. Pours clear, but it goes hazy after a while(what, did I write that? I have to try this another time a little earlier at night), light yello. Aroma; light fruity with a fruity flavor with a lightly bitter end.

This was my first bottle from 2 crates I recently picked up at the abbay. The beer poured a hazy golden color, straw like color. The pour produced a one inch thick head that later gave way to a thick, sticky ring on the edge of the glass. The aroma was pleasing to my nose with a balance of citrus and spice along with a good wheat character and yeast as well. The taste was a very nice mix of the sweet with a good dose of citrus but also a good backbone of hop bitterness. The beer produces a very solid wheat character that is refreshing but makes for a medium bodied beer.

Pours a hazy straw/orange (bottle disturbed in transit) with a thin but very persistant fine white head.
Aroma is quite muted, with a chalky, soft malt note dominating. A slightly herbal hop presence.
Flavours are light, with fine malt (german pils?) and a subtle fruitiness, finishing very dry with a light but discernable bitterness. Light - med carbonation with a med-full creamy mouthfeel.

Not as funky and exciting as the last bottle I had (exp 10/08, tasted 1/09) but showing very good balance and drinkability.

Expiry 18/12/08

Pours a clear bubbly dull blonde with a thin head with decent retention. Sourish yeasty aroma, apples, white sour grape. Tart and tasty, lingering dry finish, quite savory with light witbier character. Great carbonation with a light creaminess with an otherwise crisp body. Tasty and complex - quite enjoyable! Thanks to Jerc for the trade!

Thanks to sirpsycho for the bottle - pours a hazy gold, with a fizzy body, and a foamy, smallish head - bready/yeasty aroma, with some honey sweetness underneath, as well as notes of citrus, melon, and apples - soft, yet full carbonation in the mouth - not nearly as sweet as the aroma suggests - the yeastiness is certainly there, as well as a medium-spicy hop profile, some floral notes, a bit of minerals on the back end - very crisp and easy-drinking, which is what youd expect from this style - some wildflower hints in the finish, too - quite nice.

Pours light hazy golden with a moderate sized white head. Fruity and yeast aroma with citric notes. Flavour is on the sweet side, but not overwhelming, fruits, yeast, hoppy againt the end.Soft carbonation.
Clear golden under a white lasting cap.  Flowery & grassy hoppiness, a very light trace of malt. Fresh, quenching, with a lovely balanced bitterness, perhaps a bit too carbonated.

tasted alongside 8 and 12
hazy golden pour, nice fizzy head
aroma is very yeasty, lemony green apple
flavor is also lemony, with some white wine, somewhat yeasty
very fizzy and astringent texture
very dry
a bit watery

Appearence: Golden semi-cloudy color. Big head, white, some rocky and very lasting.
Aroma: dominated for the pale malts, the yeast and the hops with herbal smells and lightly citric. Notes of bubble gum, grass, grapefruits and flowers of chamomile.
Flavor: pale malts from the start, some ephemeral, with quickly progress of the hops with herbal notes, medium dryness, also lasting and with a "elegant" touch. Fruity reminiscences like grapefruits, unripe pineapple and some of eucalyptus and ruta. The yeast has a harmony presence.
Palate: medium body, silky texture and low carbonation.
Remarks: with the "elegance, harmony and balance" characteristics of the Westy, nice-delicate hoppiness, without high complexity but it exists. Very good blond beer.

Pours a hazy apricot-gold color with a lasting foamy head and lots of yeast floaties.  Aroma of light fruit and berries, malt, yeast and hops.  Flavor is a bit sweet and tart, with under-ripe fruit, lots of yeast and sugar, and a nice hoppy bite on a lingering finish.  Smooth on the palate, with soft carbonation.  Very nice.
Hazy yellow colour with large white head.Taste of yeast and fruits melon and citrus,feels hoppy and smooth,well balanced and fresh mild bitter finish.Really good Blond.
Bottle. Pours a hazy/unclear orange colour with off-wite head. Aroma is hops, yeast, and lots of grassy, fruity notes. Flavor is much of the same with smooth and bitter finish.
33cl bottle thanks to bontus, good blond beer hoppy smooth character, good balance between bitterness

Bottled clear, paler golden with a short-lived cap of white head.  The aroma was nice and spicy with a significant yeasty character (some banana and drier clovey notes).. toffee and bready notes behind.. caramel right at the back.  Quite nice caramelization in the flavor department with semi-sweet bready notes rolling over the edges.. the yeast character rounded it out well with a dry impression on the edges.  Medium-bodied and dry on the palate with great balance between the soft malts and delicate yeast.  Excellent stuff!

Best By Date February 2009, Bottled February of 2006; Sampled November 2008
I didnt even have a slight chance of getting a clear pour.  The full bottle looked quite clear when held up to the light, but as soon as I popped the cap the yeast started to get mixed in to the beer, it even foamed up a bit.  The beer, as it sits in my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip, has a fat two-finger thick, light cream / off-white colored head.  The head is fairly dense and takes quite some time to subside, it forms a varied surface as it does and also leaves some fat lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is a muddy, murky, really down-right ugly, pale tan / amber color, that shows a deeply hazed (cant see through it), more orangish color when held up to the light.  The aroma is quite nice though, vibrant fermentation character, a touch of hops and a solid pale malt / grain character comes through quite nicely in the nose.  Aromatic notes of hay, lemon grass, Meyer lemon zest, a light green-herbal note, distinct star-fruit, a hint of ripe melon, pear, spicy clove, white pepper, a hint of ginger, whole wheat dough, sweet wheat, a touch of honey-like malt, soda crackers, .  The nose is quite vibrant and has me quite pleased to taste the beer.

The beer has a peppery note to it that is a combination of the suspended yeast, the carbonation and the fermentation character.  Soft and doughy feeling up front (can I actually feel the yeast or am I just imagining it), the beer picks up texture from the carbonation as it rolls across the tongue.  The beer finishes with a green hop bitterness and a bit of yeasty astringency.  As the beer warms a bit fruity notes of honeydew, a touch of pear and perhaps some apple start to become noticeable under the more dominant hop and spicy-fermentation notes. This beer is actually fairly hoppy (despite being two and a half years old) with lots of herbal notes, a substantial bitterness throughout the flavor profile and a touch of soft lemon zest citrus character.  Nice and light bodied, makes this quite easy to drink, in fact I wouldnt mind having a couple bottles of this over an afternoon / evening; it is not thin though as it has some texture and body to it.  The malt character, while more supporting, contributes nice bread-like notes, a touch of sweet whole grain, as well as a touch of toasty cracker-like flavors.

The aroma of this beer is quite fantastic, but it needs to really be warmed up for the flavor to start to open up (It started out at 50°F / 10°C so wasnt really cold even).  This is still quite hoppy, and I would really like to try a fresh bottle to really get the most of the hop character.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 Hazy gold, large white head of mini bubbles, ample lacing. Nose of a pilsner with lots of crisp citrus and malt, minor floral, major yeast factor. Flavor is more robust, malt and yeast dominating with a really nice finish in crispy citrus, lemon strong. Palate a little thin. Overall not what I was expecting from this abbey, but it was a pleasant surprise.

Pours a beautiful golden blond. Very bubbly with a tall, foamy white head. Amazing aroma of citrus, grapefruit, bread, and Belgian yeast. The body has an extremely smooth feel. Excellent, smooth flavors of citrus, orange peel, and Belgian yeast. Absolutely delicious.

A high quality ale that is quite tasty and smooth simultaneously. Pours a very cloudy apricot orange with no apparent head. Mostly citrus and apricot on the nose. No spiciness and there is an all-too-apparent lack of complexity here. I cant say Im disappointed; This wouldve been fine if it were from any other brewery or abbey, I just expected it to be a more life-changing experience, this having been my first (in a series of three) from this storied monastery. Overall, and in the grand scheme, quite good.

Dec 22, 2006  
Bottle at home. Another wonderful experience. Very light and sweet. Much less dense in flavour and texture than its darker brethren. Least favourite of the 3 Westies. But, absolutely nothing to complain about.
Rating no. 800.  Bottle. Hazy golden colour with large creamy white mostly lasting head. Fruity aroma with notes of lemon and yeast. Sweet fruity flavor. Oily palate.

Pours a merky golden color. The head foamed up to about a half inch. Aroma of yeast with a hint of citrus. Taste is a little spicy,Hints of citrus, bannana, honey. Nicely carbonated.. 
Thanks to my wife for a great Christmas gift!

aroma is fruity, yeasty, slight orange. appears clear yellow with a white head. flavor is mild, slightly fruity, yeasty, nicely balanced but perhaps a bit watery. still extremely delicious and full of flavor.

Bottle thanks to Bhops. Pours a dark straw color with a big white head. Nose is triscuits and corn chips and pepper. Taste is weak tea, wheat, green pepper, and a slight earthy component with a hint of fruitiness. Odd.

Bottle thanks to Bhops. A gusher. Pours with a large creamy white head and good lacing left by the collapsing head. Clear golden body speckled with small yeasties.  Aroma of corn, corn nuts, astringent malt, alcohol, citrus zest, spices and pepper. Taste is astringent malt and spices, corn nuts, with a lot of barely. Fizzy and astringent mouthfeel.

Thanks to deepsouth for the trade this came in! Bottle no label. Standard with Westvleteren. All info on the cap. Trappist Westvleteren, Bier Blond, Alc. 5.8% Vol.. They should add "God’s Brewery". 18.10.03 printed in dots across the top. AWESOME! Pastel pale orange in color. Poured with 2" of head. Once the head settled this beer kept it’s carbonation and suds the whole time. Left a nice dry coat of foam sticking to the sides. Cloudy like a wit/wheat beer. Smells yeast and a musty yet clean w/ a zesty [citrus] rind. Mellow spice in the backdrop as a subtle touch of heaven. It’s very tripel & wit like in the front with a quick and lasting flavor of spice and orange mixed with a musty hop & fruit accent. This beer is easy to drink with a smoothness I’ve never had before (Westy 12 is next though). The light carbonation level keeps this beer drinkable and smooth through the entire beer. This beer is insanely smooth from the lips, all the way through your mouth and way into your throat. This beer is so good you wish for one more, you crave another after it’s gone. It’s still a Westy though, so in many cases there may not be another [yet]. Too too drinkable! Awesome!

Cloudy golden yellow.  Thick white head.  Malt aroma with lemon.  Lightly spiced (?coriander? ?orange peel?) with sourness, and a slightly bitter finish.  Start with this one before heading to the 12.  A unique brew.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a muddy golden colour with a great size head and good carbonation.
Smell is rather hoppy, can also smell some fruits very vague and also some raisins.
Taste is very fruity, some citrusfruits there but also sweet fruits making it a very good balance.
Very good blond beer, but didn’t expect less from Westvleteren.

11.2oz bottle, from a trade with sirpsycho, thanks Mark. Poured a hazy straw yellow with a nice white head. Yeasty, lemony acidic aroma. Very clean and fresh aroma. The flavor was very flavorful and not overly acidic, very tasty for a blond.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 33cl bottle, marked 28.02.09. Pours hazy pale yellow with a thin, fizzy white head. Smells light and cereal malty sweet. Nothing too crazy but nice. Tastes light and cereal malty with some light, green hop flavors. Overall sweet but with a lingering, slight bitterness. Light body, vibrant carbonation.

I had this at the In de Vrede cafe across the street from the St. Sixtus abbey at Westvleteren immediately after the 12.  And while I expected to be let down, drinking this beer right after the Abt (which I thought was awesome), this beer is still wonderful.

Perfect durable white foam with a dark tinge in the middle.  Hazy yellow color.  Aroma was spicy with the same boiling mash cereal smell that I found so appealing in the 12.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin.  Flavor was malt bitterness with some very light spiciness.  There was a touch of metal, and that boiling mash aroma carried a touch into the flavor.  Mouthfeel was a bit sticky.

A definite step-down from the 12, but definitely not a disappointment.  I would highly recommend this beer.
Great blond from St Sixtus. Light citrusy aroma, clean on the palate, slightly bitter dry finish. Great on a hot summer afternoon or as an appertiff.
Bottle. Poured golden in color with big white head. Aroma is fruity, floral, and citrus. Taste was very light with hops, and citrus. finished a little bitter but tasty.
Bottle from brad! Golden yellow/orange. Good head, good lacing. Aroma is floral. Taste is a dry light hop flavor, not that complex but still a good beer. Thanks brad.

Very exciting to have my first Westvleteren, and eagerly anticipating the next two after this one.  The aroma was a lively blend of citrus hops, particularly grapefruit and some orange, with a touch of candy, and some yeast and wheaty scents too; maybe even a bit floral.  The beer had a cloudy straw color with a huge, foamy white head that head unending retention and a lot of cling.  A nice and sweet citrus-candy taste with some sour effects too; plenty of flavor in this beer.  There was good fizzyness and ample carbonation, but a somewhat lighter body and feel.  Smooth and on the thinner side, slightly wet.  The beer exceeded my expectations, and leaves me eager to try more.
Pour from a bottle revealed golden yellow. Robust white head. Smooth on the palate. Somewhat dry with hop profiles. not terribly complex. Solid blonde.

330ml bottle. Airy, white head, slowly fading. Light yellow body colour with a slight haze. Fresh fruity to the nose with hints of cloves. Refreshing taste of fruits with spiced hops mixed in. Dry bitter endnotes. Soft carbonated.  Gentle in the mouth. Served comfortably chilled (eating and drinking upstairs at Den Tatoverede Enke, Copenhagen (19.09.2008).

Courtesy of Tony @ OTH.
Pours golden with white head.
Aroma, hoppy, floral with some citrus notes.
Taste, hoppy, close to medicinal herbs, sweet with good carbonation.

Very pale yellow as the slight sediment sneaks in a few small particles cloud but do not darken this brew.  Faint white head retains only a ring with lacing clinging the glass.  Nose like a tripel, spicy, musty notes.  Lightly carbonated feel on the palate.  Very light spicy palate is pleasant.  Must and citrus notes finish a yeasty and hoppy spicy beer.  More tripel than blond in my opinion but great nonetheless.

decent, its got some nice malts and some really tropical fruit for the hops flavors. its highly carbonation with many bubbling pricking the beer. 
its not bad.

The aroma is malty with a corn like element and the hops are grassy, basically simple. The appearance is hazy gold with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma with a nice malt hop balance. The palate is thin. Overall it’s pretty good despite being simple.

Bottle at In de Vrede.  I’ve had this a few times and it never dissapoints.  Looks awesome in the glass.  Nice hazy yellow with a medium sized white head.  Aroma is the best, tons of fresh hop aroma, slightly spicy.  The flavor is wonderfull, nice hop bitterness and light mouthfeel that all end nice and dry.  So underrated but I understand why, the other brews are outstanding also.

bottle dated 2-28-08.  hazy golden orange with a gorgeous white thick head.  wonderful nose of coriander and orange peal. flavor with a little wheat-malt sweetness and some discernible hop bitterness and maybe even a little flavor.  the yeast is what ties this ale together and takes it to that next level of blondes.  fruity esters from the yeast mix with the mild malt and hop flavors and add an amazing complexity to such a traditionally mild style.  a dry finish ends an amazing blonde

Thanks Brad!  Really beautiful hazy apricot with a creamy meringue head.  Aroma is yeasty, with an impression of orange and lemon pulp, and some really soft spices.  Interesting yeast interplay is the first thought upon sipping.  Kind of reminiscent of an aged De Dolle offering.  The yeast is too heavy at times for my taste.  Soft lemons creep around, but can’t really shine through the yeast.  There’s a purity and freshness to this brew.  Quite a bit of citrus fruit, like grapefruits, oranges, and lemons.  This is interesting, definitely very good, with a really refreshing quality.

Bottle very generously opened by dewbrewer! Thanks Dan, and Joelle for the opportunity to try this and the Westy 12!

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Smell is light and malty with a strong yeasty nose.  Taste is very lightly hoppy and a bit crisp and fruity and yeasty.  Medium bodied and lightly bubbly mouthfeel.  Nice and enjoyable, but wasnt too blown away by this one.

(Bottle, Akkurat, Stockholm, 5 Sep 2008) Yellow colour, slightly hazy, with a frothy white head. Fruity, spicy, slightly citric nose with notes of lemon, pineapple and spices (coriander, clove?). Fruity, spicy taste with lemon, tropical fruit, clean solid malt and lots of spicy hops in a rather bitter finish. Nice, chewy mouthfeel. Fairly dry with a long, spicy finish. Excellent Belgian blond.

Poured a cloudy apple  juice color. Very light mild nose,a bit on the yeasty side. This is mild and smooth with great carbonation. Really a delicious flavor with a nice malty finish.Delicious beer. What a great everyday beer this would be, if only...

Creamy thiny full lasting white head. Deep golden cloudy colour. Aroma is malty, fruity (apricots, pears) with floral and citrus notes. Flavor is malty too with peel orange, candy and fruity (pears,banana) tones, ending in a hoppy finish.  Medium bodied.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2008 From the bottle at De Vrede, March 2008. This was the best golden light beer I have ever tried. Amazingly complex aroma, perfect balance, great flavor for only 6%. Great fruit, malt, and hops. Citrus, spices, herbs, honey. Wow! I went there expecting much from the 8 and the 12, and was blown away most by this one. 98th percentile but still under-rated: I think this might be the perfect light beer.

Deep golden color with full frothy head. Aroma is of slight yeast, touch of fruit and pinch of hops. Nothing too overwhelming. Pleasantly (mild) yeasty flavor, with citrus notes and a balanced hop finish. Just a remarkably balanced beer that is easy to drink--everything is as it ought to be. Not my favorite style of beer, but the best example of its sort I’ve ever had.

This beer was a bit old (not too old), so it didn’t not have that much hop flavor.
The head is creamy and the beer is golden with some yeast particles. There is a bit of hops in the aroma and some yeast with a bit of caramel. Flavor is bitter with banana notes and spicies and it has a dry finish.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2016 Ra-rate 1/16: Bottle sample at a tasting at Maxs place. Thanks Lior D. Bottle is about 2 years old. Cloudy yellow with a white head. Lovely bretty aroma with sweat, barnyard, fruit (some citrus and more fruits), earth, flowers, yeast. Flavor has light sweetness, yeast, malt, fruitiness, mild spiciness, nice funk, a honey note, and some floral notes. Medium-bodied. Very good. 8/4/7/3/15=3.7

Bottle (thanks Dedollewaitor!). BB 10/03/07. Yellow to pale golden color with a huge slowly-diminishing frothy white head. Very nice slightly funky aroma with flowers, fruits, citrus, some hops, light spiciness and a bit of yeast. A rather dry flavor with a great house character, fruits (quite a bit of citrus - lemon and some grapefruit mostly), some dust and nice earthy bitter hops  as well as light sweeter notes. Medium-bodied. A great characterful Ale. 7/4/8/4/16=3.9

[Archive]

Caramel aroma. Nice head and lace. Not particularly fruity but some hint of banana?
Bottle courtesy of fonefan pours hazy golden with foamy white head. Aroma is yeast. First taste is sweet bread with nice carbonation. Clean dry finish. Very well balanced beer.

Thanks to Marisa for sharing this one after my incessant begging for a full year...  Golden pour with an absolutely snow white pillowy head.  Looked like soft cotton and left beautiful lacing on the glass.  High carbonation and a glowing golden color.  Nose is yeasty and bready.  Quite pleasing.  Very balanced on the palate, not overly sweetened like some blonds tend to be and there is a definite subtle hop spiciness on the finish.  A very good beer - probably suffers from the comparison with its 2 higher ABV siblings at the same brewery - and one not to be missed.
33cl, exclusive brewery, from the brewery, easy to drink, balanced, not complex, clear, good head, good brew

Bottle shared by dragonstout. At 5 a.m. no less. Who starts drinking at 5 a.m.??? Murky golden pour. Sweet bread like aroma. Taste was a bit hoppy up front, with some fruit, and a spice on the back end that reminded me of fresh ground black pepper. Very good. I enjoyed the spicey kick on the end. Thanks Brian!!!!

What a great way to start the day.Shared with BeerVirgin.Pours a nice cloudy golden color almost like an unfiltered wheat.Has great lacing on the edges of the glass as well as the bottom.Flavor was a mild amount of hops with some graininees and fruit.This was blended well making it enjoyable.Finished of with a nice spicy bite.

Bottle.  I’ve been saving this one for my 50th rating!  Huge thanks for Ben for bringing this one back for me!  Pours hazy, pale yellow with a frothy white head that shows nice lacing.  Aroma is crisp, fruity, and a touch of malts.  Great beer, there’s a lot going on with the taste, it’s fruity with a hoppy touch and a lightly bitter aftertaste.  Wheat, fruit, and something sweet, maybe honey?  It manages to do everything without being overwhelming.  It’s easy to see why this beer gets the rating it does.

Bottle from trade.  Pours a hazy light straw color, with a thin white pillow of foam on top.  Rousing produces a thicker even layer that stays for a while.  Looks nice.  Aroma is of mild sweet malts, a suggestion of spice, and a light yeast presence.  The taste is subdued, a smooth malt mix sits nicely on a yeasty twang.  Subtle but very enjoyable.

Bottle @ home. Hazy pale golden colour, thick white head. Aroma of hops, malts and some yeast. Taste is soft malty, a little zest, nice hoppy and dry bitter finish. Very crisp overall. I love this style.

Trappist beers being my favourite beer type, I had been trying to get hold of Westvleteren for a long time. I finally found all three of them - not cheap though.
Appearance: Pale yellow. Nice amount of head. Cloudy. Champagne-like bubbles.
Aroma: Hopsy. Bit of fruit. Yeast.
Taste: Hops, fruit and malt. Complex. Bitter aftertaste.
Info: 330ml bottle, 16/6-2006, 126/300, 67/500

Wow!  A delicious blond beer: Well-balanced, a bit spicy and hoppy up front, nice mid-palate with great texture and dandelion or wild clover flavors, smooth aftertaste with lingering spicy malt and hops.  Very nice, and well worth tracking down.
bottle courtesy of bhops.  murky blond yellow pour.  spicy, malty scent with notes of esters.  nice thickness with a very good spice flavor.

A bright, almost radiant blonde (in full sunlight), color and appearance were impressive. Creamy head, with a warm aroma... wildflowers?, the regions hops, and a toasted barley scent all made an appearance. Flavor was medium-sweet with a blend of fresh fruits and a noted fresh wheat. Sunny finish, mild aftertaste which shifts from medium-sweet to drier hops. [From "In de Vrede" cafe, Westvleteren, Belgium.]

Blond beer slighly hazy beer with a small white creamy head. Fruity and spicy aroma. Very similar to Westmalle tripel but that is not really surprising as they share the same yeast. A nice mild bitterness in the mouth that lasts a long time. Also in the taste I find similarities with Westmalle tripel. More than excellent beer. Even more, I like this one more than the 12!
Hugely satisfying blond ale with long-lasting mild bitterness making this beer perfect for heat.  Easily as impressive as the 12, just not as overwhelming.

Pours a beautiful hazy golden straw with a two finger fluffy white head.  Retention and lacing are very good.  Smell is earthy with lots of spices and a strong citrus hop presence, mainly lemons.  There is also a slightly sweet bready malt undertone to the aroma.  Taste pops with the lemon up front which gives way to the sweet wheat flavor before finishing with a very crisp light finish.  There is a spiciness that remains throughout.  The mouthfeel is medium to light bodied and seriously crisp.  Drinkability is great with this one and I could drink this all day and night on a hot summer day.

Bottled(330ml). -Courtesy of heavy (huge thanks!!!), shared with him and Doggythedog.
Hazy golden/yellow coloured, medium to big white head, pleasant light fruity spicy nose. Malty, very yeasty and light fruity taste with notes of herbs and spices and rather bitter finish. Quite unusual blond but to be honest, Ive expected (much) better from Westvleteren.

07/06 0.33 l bottle from belgianshop.com. Poured murky golden body with big white head. Somehow salty aroma, with yeast in form of orange in the background. Flavor is better, but still not what I want and used to, strange bitterness, even could be related to cardboard, with malty fruitiness only acting the background. Slightly thin bodied as well. Still, it had pretty long, bitterish finish. Dont get why this is the most expensive of the 3 active Westies, besides I had many much better blonds.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2008 A very beautiful hazy golden yellow colored beer, with a thick white foamed head, which stays for a while, and then leaving a beautiful lace on the glass. The aroma is nice bitter with some fruity tones. The taste is very nice bitter with tones of grapes in the back. A very good refreshing beer. I think maybe a littlle underrated in opposition of the 8 and 12 of Westvleteren.

Sweet, yeasty aroma. What surprised me was the carbonation in the middle of my palate as oposed to right up front. Slightly thin mouthfeel, dosent take away from the beer in the least. Light, floral, sweet, crisp and refreshing, hops present on the back end. The ultimate blonde. Wow.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 bottle courtesy of the grimreeser. Pours a hazy orange with a beutiful big white head.  Aroma of belgian yeast, spice, lemon, orange rind and a bit of woody cellar.  The taste is just like the aroma.  Everything mixes so well with nothing overwelming.  Its a bit thin, but I thank that is why i like it even more.  Reminds me of calabaza blanca that way.

2004 Vintage... Probably the best looking head Ive seen from a Blonde beer, Duvels head is exagerrated IMO. The fluffly head disappears slowly but remains throughout the whole experience. Lemon flavors are definitely there, but so soft like lace lingering. This tastes like no blonde Ive ever had and Im a Quad fan... Im already in love with Westvleterens dark beers, ironic that this beer will feel the same love as well... Try all Westvleterens! Amazing stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 Bottle thanks to Greig! Pours an opaque orangey yellow with a fluffy white head. Nose is slightly woody with sweet lemons. Palate is lovely it has a real sofness to it that makes it very easy to drink. Flavours are complex with nuances of earthiness, seville oranges and hints of spice that are really well balanced with the late woody hoppiness. This is and X factor beer!

Bottle shared with and courtesy of heavy (a huge, HUGE thanks!) Man I was happy to try this and the Extra. Poured a nice, very murky yellow colour with a huge white head that went away slowly. A fine agrumey nose, ever so slightly funky. Quite yeasty. The taste was odd in a good way.. brett? Hmm... definitely a bit funky and not a typical blond. The nice malt plays second fiddle to the grapefruity hopiness. A bit funky. Extremely well balanced and all in all a great beer.

[1171-20080302] Bottle. Aroma has a bit of citrusy grain and hoppy bitterness. Hazy, orange brown body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Boozy flavour is well-balanced with notes of woody citrus hops and leafy florality. Medium body is smooth but rough around the edges. Impressively made.
(@ In De Vrede; Westvleteren, BE)

0.33L bottle from Bier Tempel, Brussels.  

Pours an orange shade of blonde, pure white and very fluffy head which lasts ages.  

Taste is citrus and hops and bloody nice.  Easily the best blonde beer that Ive tried.  Worth the hassle of picking one up.

Bottle. Pours unclear orange with a fine creamy white lasting head & lacings. Aroma & taste is of yeast, mild spices & orange fruits. Like said - mildly spiced & delicious. Medium body & carbonation. A fine little brother to the elder sisters! :-)

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2010 Bottle. A hazy medium yellow beer with a large, frothy, lacing, nostly lasting white head. The aroma is lightly malty, moderately hoppy and lightly yeasty. There are notes of grain/bread, grass, flowers, herbs, lemon, some spices, perhaps a hint of mint. The flavour is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately sour, lightly to moderately bitter. Very slick texture and wonderfully balanced. Medium body, lively carbonation, dry and very long finish with medium bitterness (maybe something more). This is the kind of product I would suggest to people who are not into beer yet, because of its huge drinkability, the cleanness, the harmony. Everyone could love this kind of stuff. Awesome
On tap at In De Vrede. Blond with a good sized white head. Aroma of citrus and light grain. Decent flavor, a light bitterness to finish which lingers a little.

Bottle, from overseas trade.  Hazy orange pour into my glass.  Aroma is bubblegum, belgain yeast, cinnamon spice, and candi sugar.  Flavor is all that to a lesser extent then the aroma.  A truely fantastic blond!

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 At In De Vrede, April 2008. Although Id tried the Westvleteren beers plenty of times in the past, Id not rated them as Id steered clear since they got rare and expensive. A trip to the monastery was an ideal opportunity to put that right. Hazy blonde. Fruity but dry with a strong tangy citrus and spicy aftertaste. Not the big hitter of the Westvleteren crew but very refreshing.
Smagt 3/5 2008, hos Hamann. De kan det der ølbrygning de munke. denne er mild rund og let at drikke, man bare hælder ned - dejligt.

Bottle shared at the PP Bottle Shop by wetherel. Thanks John, Ive been trying to rate this for so long! Upon pouring, a vegetable aroma almost made me think it was spoiled. However, as the head dissipated and the body cleaned up, the scent faded. Whew. Ended up pretty enjoyable. White, white gold color with good lacing. Sweet pear and cut grass with grains in the nose, followed by white grape and hay flavors. A slight nuance of wood as well. It still retains a bit of that tingly Westvleteren mouth-feel like its brethren, only a bit thinner. Refreshing and crisp. Not bad!

the beer poured a cloudy yellow with about a quarter inch of head. the beer is highly carbonated with little to no lacing.

the smell is large on the cereal and citrus end with some fruity and floral undertones.

the taste is a bit bitter, but the bitterness fades fast. i taste a bit of spice and floweriness as well. i notice it also to be a bit peppery. overall, the balance of this beer is nice.

the mouthfeel of this beer is highly carbonated and fluffy, like rose petals.

this beer is lighter tasting that i expected. its a very drinkable beer. would be awesome to have it just laying around to session.

Tap at  In De Vrede. Pours with a light yellow color and  afrothy head with nice lacing. Aromas of lemon and orange. Flavor was surprisingly hoppy, lots of fruit and quite effervescent. Fairly bitter finish, I was really surprised how hoppy it was.

I knew this one was supposed to be the less spectacular of the beers from them, and...it was.  Pours a cloudy blond with a thick white head.  Weird aroma, a little citrus, but also something kind of funky.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Nice lemon notes.  Solid, but I think it is easy to get similar beers that taste just as good.

Went to the abbey today to pick up two cases of no. 8, so while I was there I went to In De Vrede and picked up a few Blondes. No twelves today :( BBE 02/2009
My first rating, so forgive me... Aroma: lemon and a hint of apples. Color between golden and amber, a bit hazy - but that might be my pouring. Beautyful full white foam. More bitter than expected, but thats a definate plus. Medium bodied and quite smooth with a bitter finish. Lots of hops here!

Bottle bbe 07/2007. Light golden yellow with fizzy pale head. Honey, pears and malts on the nose. More like a kellerbier than belgian ale! Flavor is lightly malty with dry hayish hops and bitterness. Slightly grapefruity bitter and grainy finish. Medium bodied, quite smooth palate. I guess the bottle age has taken its toll. To be ra-rated, fresh.

In De Vrede cafe. Delicate fresh aroma, orange blossoms, roses. Brisk noble hop bitterness, fresh delicate malt sweetness with a citrus edge. Bright carbonation, clean finish. This really is an impressive beer, and though it gets much less attention than the 8 and 12, it feels like it is crafted with every bit as much care. If those three were my house beers, this would be the one I drank the most of.

Bottle sampled from the Mad_Indian. Pours pale golden with a good size foamy white head. Aroma of caramel, lemon, citrus, and spices. the flavor is sweet, lemon, citrus, pepper, floral hops are present. Good body and mouthfeel. Great brew.

Pours a hazy, light golden body.  A foamy, pure white head leaves minimal, spotty lacing in its wake.  The aroma shows lemongrass, pale caramel malts, biscuit, honey, and lightly peppery, floral hops.  Smells very light, fresh, and clean.  Flavors continue this theme, with light, toasty, honey-glazed bread, light caramel, mild floral hops, and herbal tea notes all dancing delicately on the palate.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied, smooth and creamy, going down very easily.  Simple and complex at the same time.  This is just a straightforward, incredibly well crafted brew.  I could drink this all summer long.

The month on the bottle cap has worn off, but it was produced on the 29th of some month in 2001, making this one 7 years old. Aroma is very light, with mostly orange and lemon notes with a good deal of bread. Head is lacking. Predominately orange in spice in the flavor, with a slight flowery background. Surprisingly a good amount of hops in this one. So to sum up this rating in two words: orange rind. Orange as its the predominate flavor, and rind because of the lighter, hoppier, more citrus-bite characteristic of this one. This is undoubtedly a great beer, and would love to rate a much fresher one at some point.

This is an outstanding blond.  I ordered from Belgium and I am glad I did.  Not as good as its big brothers, but very good anyway.  Cloudy color, with a nice foamy head.  Citrus and yeast notes on the palate.  Good fruit flavors and a tiny bit of hops to balance.  Yum!

Ive a bit of luck, i could taste the beers of Abdij St. Sixtus...Hazy golden color under a delisicious foamy white head... In the glass of the abbey... Beautiful appearance. In the aroma are some spice, fruity citrus perfume with a bit of hop. The texture of the beer is complex with a strong hop taste, a thick body with spicey aromas. Nice mouthfeel. And this is the easiest beer of the monks...

Bottle. Poured a beautiful blond straw color with a huge head. Aroma is subtle but pleasing, citrus and fresh green grass. Very easy drinking with a soft herbal note, with fresh bread and hint of lemon and pear.

Pours a hazy lemon color with a white head.  Coriander,  orange peal,  flower,  citrus lemons in the aroma and flavor.  Some funk earth,  spiciness in the flavor.  Very clean finish with a nice snappy mouth feel.
I must have gotten two skunked bottles in a row because I couldnt even drink this.  It tasted like manure and hay.  I will rerate once I get ahold of a good bottle.

Thanks to Yesper, JK, hellomynameis. The beer was cloudy gold with a moderate amount of head. I got spices, honey, grains, and fruit in the aroma. The flavor was sweet, grainy, and hoppy. It had a mild hop finish.

A wonderful birthday treat for me sent from a friend from Belgium. Enjoyed in the Westvleteren glass he sent as well.  Waited to get this at the right temperature high marks for the aroma as well as appearance. Not as flavorful as the other Westvleteren beers more of the citrus taste comes through on this wonderful brew. Such a pity one can not get this or any of the  Westvleteren  brews easily, perhaps that is the charm. They rank as my favorites. Happy birthday to me.

heather wheat and a mild tough of corieander. this beer has a floral brightness and a nice un even head, the color is akin to a cloudy light cider with haze and tiny but active bubbles.  it is at once silky and citric with and ultra fresh wheat flavor.  the purity and quility of the components is clear.  accross from the abby

Clear yellow pour with a gigantic, foamy white head.  Lemony, yeasty aroma with a slight hint of bread, pepper, grass and spice. Light, tart fruits and citrus make most of the body of the flavor with a slightly sweet, yeasty, peppery finish with just a hint of spice.  Medium body, dry finish and lots of carbonation.  I usually find the Blond styles to be a bit boring, but this has some nice layers of complexity to it.

11.2 oz bottle-no date code. Trade w/daknole. Poured a light golden, cloudy color w/a slight white foamty head & good lacing. Citrus aroma. Crisp Blond Belgian flavor kind of heavy on grapefruit & citrus. Traces of grass & straw, w/a little bit of figs. Long dry finish. Good solid brew; I wouldnt seek it out like a Westy 12, but enjoyable. Gotta get an 8 next-thanks for the trade!

Big thanks to Oldsmar Tap House owner Tony for popping open the rare elixir. Pours pale dull gold with slight haze. The bright white head faded to a ring within a minute or two. The aroma is fairly mild with a mixture of faint pale malt sweetness, lightly roasted malts that play against mild yeastiness. Behind that I get some fresh bright citrus hops along with just a hint of dates and prunes. The taste is light and refreshing starting with a quick hit of mild malty sweetness followed by a growing tart bitterness mixed with light yeasty spice. Midway the bitterness peaks with notes of citrus. This isnt an overly bitter beer but has a solid hop taste. At the finish mild pale malt sweetness surfaces before a mild tartness joins in. Great refreshing brew that will work great in hot weather.
Yellow with a huge head. Flowery and hoppy aroma with a surprisingly bitter flavour for a blond. It has notes of grass, straw, fruits and a bit of caramel. It ends dry and is light bodied.

Fredagsbaren på biologi, Aarhus
Bottled
Good bitterness and yeast character
Dry and fruit notes

A really nice cloudy golden color, with a surprising citrus aroma which reminded me alot more of a white beer then a blond.  The flavor was crisp, but refreshing none the less.  However it was finish that really struck me because it is remarkably bitter.  I relize that this beer is classified as a blond but, for sure, it isnt.  Leave it to those monks to produce another dynamite product that would appear to those who like their beer a litte bit lighter.  Cheers.
Again another no logo bottle, Very nice nice head, dirty blonde amazing color, Spicy taste, Different from other trapist beers. Another nice Belgium beer.

bottle and glass thanks to xnoxhatex. Muchos gracias for this gem. murky pale yellow with healthy white head. slightly soured wheat, grass, faint lemon and muscat on the nose. Nose seems a little understated. Flavor is surprisingly herbal and spicey. Mint, sage, grass, alfalfa, touch of underlying sweetness to balance a bit. Wonderfully bitter hops mingle with sharp bubbles to excite the palate. Ends slightly dry and bitter with a slight resinous coating on the tongue. So unique and wonderful.

Bottle at Haket 2008-02-08. Clear amber with a light head. Just as westy 8 this one reminds me of apple cider. Fruits (red apples is what comes to my mind) in aroma. Taste is malty and some fruit. Dry mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 In Cafe and In De Vrede may 07... alongside there pate ... Clowdy!! Yelllow ... light belgian hop nose ... mellow hop resins ... lots of flavour ... flowery hop ... juicy ...  Huge thanks to Joris for this TK2  at home 20/03/08 ...Crisp clear light orange ... light belgian nose ... juicy and fruity... little yeasty  ... flowery subtle and  balanced.
 Bottle at home ... Aug 2012 bottle drunk Oct 2012 ... golden amber ...soft vegative light lemon nose ...soft floral lemon ... soft fruits ... vegative... not as good as ive had before 3.0

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2009 33cl bottle from the monastary.  Pours a hazy head with about a finger-height of white foam that lasts the entire session and a golden color. Aroma is spicy. Notes of apples, clove, grass and hops. Flavour is a bit wheaty and bitter. Notes of apples, spices and yeast. It has a lingering aftertaste. A very nice beer for the summer evenings.

A big thanks goes out to leftmindedrighty for this opportunity to sample such a fine brew 
The classic Westvleteren bottle poured into my chalice produced a good fingers worth of white fluffy head that turns into a thick lace that last till the end. The body on it is a hazy (I swirled the yeast) apricot color with fine yeast particles floating through out 

The aromas of bananas, yeast, grass and hops come through wonderfully. There is also some spice to it cloves and pepper 

Flavors of yeast and pepper, along with its almost earthiness of the other spices hit me first. Then other flavors, sweetness of fruit and a dryness of some hops in the end. Yes complex is a good word for this beer.

Light and smooth mouthfeel with a light crispness due to the carbonation would sum this up

Now let me say it is very drinkable. And I love to have it again . Due to its rarity and price I dont think Ill be having many more though. If I lived in close to the monastery it would be a great session beer. So I guess Ill stick with my Orval the next time I need a fix 
Thanks again Aaron

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2009 [rated 3.10.08] Thanks xnoxhatex for the brew and the glass! Pours cloudy golden with some large bubbles and a frothy white small head.  Strong fruit and yeast aroma.  Sweet yeasty and slightly apple flavor, with some grassy hop bitterness on the finish.  Really smooth and clean.  The malt is almost candy like.  Very smooth fluffy body.   I like it a lot better than Orval. 8.4.9.5.18  [wow I cant believe I really wrote that last statement hahaha]

[rated from the cafe in March 2009, and again 10.6..09]  Aroma is super plumy Westveleteren distinctive yeast, sweet and crisp, lemon, noble hops, wonderful.  Flavor and body follows, super crisp and flavorful, a delight.  The yeast is absolutely unmistakable and ever remarkable.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2008 A candy sweet, fruit nose, banana, peppery yeast, grass notes. Flavor is fruity, bready. Also a lot of organic hoppy bitterness than I was expecting. A nice surprise considering its a blonde. A dry finish lingers on the back of the tongue. A very good Belgian, and very refreshing. A hot summer day would make this.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Pours a hazy straw color with a white head.    Lots of yeast and grain on the nose.  A little tart spice with a wee bit of bitterness that finishes dry and hoppy.  Nice beer, comparable to a light Orval.

Rating #600. Bottle from stoutlover72, thanks Garrett. Pours a slight hazy golden orange with a large creamy bright white head and tons of lacing. Complex aroma with a lot of earthiness,  white pepper, grass, yeast, bread possibly some fruit. Medium bodied with lots of dryness on the finish. Flavor is loaded with spicyness, yeast, bread and earth. Good beer but its like going to a minor league game when you want to see the real team. I really neeed to try the 12.

Bottle from ebay purchase.Sampled with Paulie Walnuts. Pours a hazy blond color. Bready banana aroma with a lemon finish. Flavor was pretty much the same with a sweet hoppy finish. It was pretty good.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle courtesy Tony at Oldsmar Tap House. Thanks! Pours a hazy blonde, with a thin watery head. Nice wet lacing sticks to the glass. Aromas of grassy wheat, Belgian yeast, slight clove, and some ripe cider. Spicy wheat flavors, clove, grain. Very light flavored. Bitter hop after-taste. Epitome of the style. Bitter finish, very drinkable. Wont see too many of these, definitely enjoyed it.
Bottle. Pours a hazy gold, big white head. Aroma is grassy with a touch of fruit in the background. Flavor is malt, spice and grass. A little sharp on the finish.

Very pale blond lively body, topped by a modest head of foam. Barnyard apple/hay aroma which I maybe wasnt expecting. Spicy saaz-like hops, completely dry and slightly yeasty. In fact, much like a very high quality pilsner. Fantastically drinkable beer whose beauty lies in its simplicity and austere European hops. Totally dug this.

0.33 l bottle. Golden color with good lasting head. Fruity, orangey, slightly peppery and clovey aroma with notes of herbal hops. Crisp, dry and refreshing flavor with tart fruit, grapefruit, herbal hops and pepper. Firm bitter finish. Very complex for its strength.

Bottle, cap marked 12.08.05. I think I got this from Belgianshop a few years ago. Poured yellow-golden, with an initially huge, frothy, white head, that declined to a moderate sized cap. Aroma is primarily sweet, with malt and an almost honey-like character, along with some yeast and spice. Mild hop bitterness throughout palate, with some spice and tropical fruit. More complex than it gets credit for.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2008 Bottle from fone fan in December 2007.   Opened at PP bottle shop for Brad and Sean.  I wasnt  expecting much from this beer, since it was shipped for a long distance, probably encountering some heat along the way.  I imagined lighter beers dont like this.  I was pleasantly surprized.  Yellow color.  Maybe a hint cloudy.  Triple aroma, reminds me some of the new LA Carnevale.  Is that corriander or just the yeast giving it that characteristic Belgian aroma.  Mellow bitterness.  Super easy to drink.  Yum! 8,3,8,4,18:4.1
Rerate:  Tried at PP bottle shop. Did a side-by-side of Rochefort 6 and Westy 6. I like Rochefort 6 better this time, but my memory of Westy 6 is better.  Light amber color. Fruitier than Westy 6.  Malty. Some caramelization. Nice. 7,3,8,4,17:3.9

Woo hoo rating 100. Lucky enough to score one at the Manchester winter ales festival thanks to Winn. Got that unmistakeable westy yeasty typey tastey. Great stuff, if it wasnt so hard to get hold of Id love to drink this regularly. So good it can replace food till you fall over. Then you better eat.

330 ml bottle from a trade with Papsoe.  Pours a hazy, yellowish gold with a thin white head, which lingered to produce good lacing.  Smell is yeast and some lemon with  hint of alcohol.  Taste is very much the yeast and lemon that the nose picked up.  Mouthfeel is medium and tangy with carbonation and a dry aftertaste.

Bottle, Cambrinus, Brugge. Cloudy blonde, thin off-white head. Fruity lemony, smooth but robust, hazy hops. Really hoppy, but smooth and a bit quenching. Some dark fruit, raspberry, but fresh grass and lemon dominates. Clean and smooth on palate. Lingering bitterness. Lots of grapefruit. Very good.

Rating #600 Bottle, dated 05.06.08, courtesy of theisti. Thanks a ton for this generous gift, Tim. Poured carefully into a trappist glass, it appears a clear light gold with a frothy white head that deposits delicate lace on the glass. The nose is bright and yeasty with fruity esters and a touch of candy sugar ending with a slightly spicy alcohol note (odd for a beer at this ABV). Light bodied with soft, tongue-tickling carbonation, it ends with a fairly dry finish. The flavor is dominated by the complex yeast strain that fronts the profile: lightly fruity, dry and spicy, its a bit like a light-bodied saison. A well made and tasty brew. Thanks again, Tim!

UPDATED: APR 2, 2009 Thanks Jason.  The beer pours to a flat golden straw body with tons of super tiny particulate with a lively white head. The aroma is candied pineapples and simple pale malts mixed with interesting Belgian yeasts.  The flavors include bitter hops, Belgian yeasts, and pineapples.  Medium velvety texture. 8, 3, 7, 4, 14 = 3.6

Apparently I tried this twice.  I think this bottle was many years old.  Pours to a blonde body with a very thin white head.  The aroma is sweetly caramelized and has that typical Westy yeast.  The flavor has a significant kettle caramelization.  Theres a lot of subtleties going on.  Deep caramel.  Nice light yeast.  The palate is crisp and is medium light bodied.

Cloudy sample from a bottle shared by Jason.  Sugary pineapple cake in the aroma.   The flavor is a more intense version of the aroma - bitter green hops and esters make up the pineapple aspect with a very clean pale malt base.  Good stuff.

Drank at the Gollem in Amsterdam.  Pours a cloudy bright orange color that leaves a small off-white head. Lacing is minimial. Aroma is a light sweetness with some spicy yeast notes. Flavor is "fresh" tasting, like springtime, whatever that means. Very good bitter bite on the swallow. Nice sweetness with a excellent yeast notes. Body is medium and lively in the mouth.

From a 330mL Bottle.  Obtained in a trade with afatty 9/30/07.  Pours a hazy dandelion gold color with a thick, two finger froth of tight buttled, white head.  Lightly sweet, bready malt aromas waft from the glass softly, with touches of vanilla nougat, teething biscuit, clean bread yeast, and a wonderful kiss of herbal hops.  Nothing over the top, but all the dimensions are perfectly balanced.  Light bodied, mildly carbonated mouthfeel with a soft, supple texture.  This manages to maintain a soft velvety texture while keeping the body light.  The carbonation level helps at this, holding itself at a level where the head is held high, but the bubbles dont scrub abrasively on the palate.  Clean, bready malt flavors with a gentle biscuity yeast that contributes minimal esters and no detectable phenols to my palate.  Wonderfully hoppy, with a crisp floral flavor that is heavy on the flavor but light on the bitterness.  This is the perfect sessionable Belgian blond ale.  Thanks, Glenn!

11.2 fl oz bottle thanks to a trade with ygtbsm.  Pours a clear gold yellow with a medium white head.  Nose is yeasty and spicy with citrus and grains dominating.  Similar flavors.  Spritzy carbonation.  Lemony light malts touch of grain.  Slight yeast spice.  Finishes dry.  It doesnt live up to its big brother, but decent.
Hazy golden colored brew. Yeasty and a bit fruity, citric, lemon. Grassy hoppy flavor. Nice one.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 (Re-rate, 21/04/08- previously 3.6) Nose of lime juice freshness, sherbet, barnyard, pigshit. Stings with hop pellet bitterness. Herbal grassy hop as in an unfiltered helles. Lime-like citrussy dryness, wild yeast, manure, wheat and lingering biscuit. Silky to the point of stillness, but not quite. GRASS. How did I miss that before? Not as a hop metaphor, but a real tangible mouthful, with roots and little clods of soil still attached. Clean but filthy dirty. This beer has more barnyard, yeasty edge and hop spike to it than Orval these days, and bottle by bottle has become a favourite of mine. Spiky, zesty, agricultural  XX shandy.


(old rate- what was I on???)....Tasted this with heavy flu at In De Vrede, and was convinced it was bound for my top 5 it seemed so aromatically hoppy, and was the only one of the Holy Trinity I could really taste. On second impression, back home and with my tasting faculties 100% restored, it seems a whole lot more restrained and, well....ordinary. Pours pale hazy gold with a pillowy white head. Aromas lemony, citric and grassy and leaning into witbier territory. There are also some nutty/vegetable/wheaty notes wafting about, not completely unlike an really adjuncty lager. Just a sniff of something dry, biting and herbal that sets it apart. But blindfolded, I might have mistook it for an unspicy wit brewed with a high proportion of unmalted barley. Its that lemony. Flavour bites with English golden ale citrussy/grassy hops and background biscuity malts. Soap and citrus to the fore. Needs plumping up a bit as it leaves a bit of a watery impression on the palate. Dry, hoppily bitter, pleasantly lemony Trappist sessions. But it cant touch Orval.

Bottled 330 ml.
hazed golden color.
BlondeBest blonde Trappist.
Hops, bitter. Wow !
Bit yeasty.
Nice.

33 cl bottle.  Just hazed gold with a frothy white head.  Nose is yeasty, creamy lemon and some faint floral.  Medium carb, body medium light.  Taste is simple yeasty honey caramel with a nice bitter bite.  Nothing spectacular but i could easily drink this every day.
The flavor is initial sweet like other Westvleteren, but it has long bitter finish. It has a medium body and a good mouthfeel. The aroma is fruity and hoppy, dominated by raw vegetables and grass.

Bottle. A littly cloudy yellow colour with mostly lasting creamy white head. Flowers, fruit esters and hops in the aroma. Flavor is slightly sweet but is soon corrected by hops and acids. A bit astrigent on the palate. Average finish with fruits and green spices. Well made blond/belgian ale.

Had this one while sitting in the sun on a beautiful day at In De Vrede while waiting to pick up my two cases of Westvleteren 8 from the Abbey. Id already had the 8 and the 12 and since it was hot out, the Blonde was the obvious choice. I dont know when it was bottled but Id guess it was less than a month old.

It has a pale straw colored cloudy body with a one inch white head initially that fell fairly quickly. It smells very yeasty and malty with some fruitiness that reminds me a bit of a hefe with some banana and maybe apple. The flavor is not at all what I would have expected, but it is indeed good. It was much hoppier than I would have expected with both hop bitterness and flavor. It had a bit of spiciness to it as well and then finished with a malty finish. I think I got some noble hop aroma in there but I could be wrong. It is fairly light bodied. It could have been the situation, but it seemed like the perfect summer drink.

Pours a bright shade of blond, fairly transparent. Fluffy white head and lacing.  Big complex nose with hints of fruity esters, bread, and lemon zest.  Flavor very similar. Coriander,& orange up front slight hop flavor on the finish.

12 ounce bottle from theisti
Pours crystal clear bright blond, with a fluffy snow white head.
The nose is quite floral and dusty.
The flavor is mostly clean, but theres the slightest bit of tartness in the finish.
Light body.  Highly carbonated.  Dry finish.
Good to know the the monks are drink well, even while mowing the lawn.  Thanks Tim.

This one came a long way, so it was with reservations I cracked this one open.  Still, looks lovely.  Pours a very light golden with vague orange tones, like hazy grapefruit juice, not too much for a head but slowly a solid soapy film appeared and covered the beer, leaving tiny blobs of lacing.  The nose is flowery and delicate, with some lemongrass, some slight hay, rich yet light sweet malts, and some tempered fruity esters thrown in for good measure.  On the palate the beer seems to simply disappear, very smooth and drinkable, everything seems in near perfect harmony.  Very versatile, starting lemony and grassy before the light malts come in to balance a very mild yet observable leafy hop finish.  Super drinkable, which is sad since this is the only one of these I have.

Bottle at Kulminator.  How do you improve upon a blond ale?  Let those monks at Westvleteren make it, thats how.  After a couple solid days of 8s and 12s, I was pleased to see the Blond at Kulminator.  Needing to complete the trifecta, I was pleased.  Light, fruity and perfectly balanced.  This could be my session ale if the monks werent so stingy about it. (For the record, I think those monks, and what theyre doing, is awesome.  I just want more beer because I am selfish and like their beer.)

330ml bottle. Shared by Matty - cheers - youre a saint!
Light cloudy wheat-beer appearance. Very tight, creamy textured, white head. Perfumed floral aroma (alas we used the wrong type of glass that didnt flatter the aroma). Mellow floral light fruity taste - slightly appley, but not sweetly so. In fact, it fills in with a dry and sharp hoppy middle taste which stays for the finish which was long but quite subtle. Slightly soapy from the yeast/hop combo, which was the only downside from an otherwise an excellent high quality and delicate brew.

Garrafa, em Bruges (BEL), em novembro de 2007. Dourada clara, com creme branco consistente e persistente. Notas de limão siciliano e azeitona. Carbonatação média. Suave. Blonde diferente das demais. Tem personalidade, mas nada de complexo. Boa drinkability.

Bottle sampled with Fatphil and Anna- Golden in appearance which is slightly hazy. The aroma is very inviting indeed  and is sweet, blossomy with a hint of peaches and citrus.  Peaches and hints of apples in the sweetish taste which is hoppy with citrus and peaches becoming more evident in the delicious aftertaste. The appearance was different when I had it in the past and affects my mark slightly but  it did not have an adverse effect on the taste. Superb.

Pours a cloudy, dull golden color with a thin white head that has good retention.  The aroma is muddled, though somewhat bitey with a spice note and alcohol.  The flavor is dominated by a woodiness that underlies exotic spices.  Its difficult to pinpoint exactly what they are.  Perhaps there are notes of white pepper, lemon, rosemary, and others.  There is also a bitterness from the hops that is reminiscent of a Saaz based German pilsener.  Very complex... theres a lot going on here.  The mouthfeel is also incredible.  While it borders on overcarbonated, there is a silkiness of the micro bubbles that surrounds your tongue and feels very luxurious.  While this beer is classified as a Belgian Ale, it is definitely a bender (though BAs are a pretty wide, vague category).  Overall Im not sure what I was expecting, but its just pretty good.
Another brew from Jespr. sampled with the rest of the Minnesota Crew. Wow, this thing was very nasty. More like a lemony soured pilsner that a Begian Ale.

My first rating. 6 bottles thanks to my dad. Bottle from the fridge. Poured into Westvleteren glass, appearance like witbier, nice head. Immediate smell of yeast and citrus. Aroma of citrus, herbs. Some bitterness like Orval or Hoegaarden Grand Cru. Very refreshing.  Can be drunk easily.

(Thanks to radiomgb.)  330 mL bottle.  Translucent blonde in colour with a nice head.  The strong aroma consists of citrus (lemon), alcohol, and some spice.  The flavour is solidly malty, but also spicy and sharply bitter.  Complex and well balanced.  Nicely bitter finish.  Dry.  Thanks again, Jeff.

0.33l - Poured a bright brassy/gold that seemed to glow from within.  Light head, fabulous lace.  Nose of toasted white bread.  Hoppy on the palate at first, fading to honey and finishing with a seltzerlike fizzyness.

Made this my #1000 ,because Westy 12 was #100 for me,plus this brew represents the great time I had at this years Oktoberfest in Munich. This beer was sent to meby a good English doctor I met in Munich. He stopped at the Abbey and picked me up some bottles on the way back to England. As far as the brew itself, the sweet garden aroma of gentle fruits, grain malts and a quick hit of floral hops  distinguishes the beautiful and near flawless aroma, taste is a light mix of lemony ,lime citrus fruit and slightly acedic tart fruit,with just the most pleasant of smooth finishes,as satisfying a beer under 6% that I have ever had. Lord ,we thank Thee for these wonderful monks at St. Sixtus
gold blond coloured body with a white head a hoppy yeasty aroma a little fruity yeasty taste and a  average bitter finich

The Blond opens with a yeasty aroma followed by wheat, clove, and Noble hop notes.  It pours more like an unfiltered lager than a weizen with subdued carbonation.  The flavor resembles a weizen with marked yeast notes and some residual sweetness.  In my opinion the yeastiness detracts from the palate, although the mouthfeel is very malty.  I prefer Orval in this style, with Chimay Blanche a close second.

Thanks to Drewbeerme. A very mellow take on a Belgian Ale. Everything is well mixed and no vegetable taste is desernalble like most Belgians. Its hay and citric with some yeast and cream. Not my favorite style, and i can imagine what a trip this bottle took and still its very good. Lots of lively carbonation and very murky and dirty. I would love to have some of this on tap!

Bottle at In de Vrede, Westvleteren. One of my favourite beers in the world. Hazy golden blond colour, with tight white head. Hoppy citric creamy nose with yeastiness. Fullish in mouth iwth tart drying lemony citrus finish. Refreshing and wonderful. Had to re-rate again. Excellent yeasty/hoppy/citrus nose with grapefruit. Cant express what a good blond this is!

Bottle (33 cl) from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmark. Hazy deep golden with a small but longlasting head. Complex earthy and yeasty aroma with light herbal hops. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation. Very fry with a long moderately bitter finish.

Sampled at Westvleteren cafe, alongside her sister beers. Killer! As big as can be for a beer with less than 6%. Unbelievable complexity. Dry. Finely hopped. Pine, esters in nose. Finely honed. Soft mouthfeel.

Bottle, thanks to dra19. This one pours a cloudy golden yellow with big, fluffy white head. The aroma is like freshly baked bread, pineapple, lemon, and lots of smooth yeasty tones. The flavor has a mellow graininess to it at first. But then a lemony acidity cuts through it a bit, bringing with it some fruity tones like banana, pineapple, plum, and some dark tart tones. The fruitiness is kind of hard to describe; it isnt like the overt esters in many beers. It is very subtle. There is a blanket of warm earthiness that lies over the whole mouth. Very pleasant. It brightens up a bit in the finish, with some orangey citrus notes. This is a very enjoyable beer.

Yesper, JK, hellomynameis  and others put together one hell of a sampler for us.  Perhaps not what I was expecting, but a very drinkable beer nonetheless.  Light grainty aroma with some wheaty tones.  Solid grainy malt body with light hops and a very smooth finish.
Pours a hazy golden yellow.  Aromas of citrus, passion fruit and a special yeast that is unfamiliar to me.  Flavor is spicey and dry.  A very fine Begian blonde.
Poured. Pours a light gold with white head. Aroma is citric. Taste was very very hoppy with some spice. Long finish. Smooth
Pours light gold with a white head.  Aroma is lemony, grassy, and really reminded me of Pine-sol.  Taste was very hoppy, with some slight spice that didnt really mesh well.

Bottle from Papsoe, sampled with Zinister.  Thanks!Pours cloudy yellow with a nice head and an aroma of Spring lemon, strawberry, and Sprite.  Tingly lemon and coriander flavors with a subtle Pilsner finish.  Coating mouthfeel.  Pretty good; very refreshing.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Wow again tasted at the Trapist festivall in Niel. A not so strong trapist beer but heavenly good tasting

If the good brothers are guilty of any sin, it is of sloth: they make only enough of this delightful beer to fund their abbey, whereas with a little more work, they could bring even more joy to the world.

Simply put: the best blond you will ever have (even if youre Joe DiMaggio).
Unclear hazy yellow with medium white head. Hoppy aroma with some fruits. Not your common trappist with a hoppy flavor. Dont get the fuss about this one...

Sampled from the Yespr collection, shared at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a clear light golden blonde brew with a creamy white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma of light white bread, some tropical fruits, honey and a touch of yeast funk. Taste is light bodied, smooth, creamy with a spiced tropical fruit with light bread flavor. Finish is semi-sweet at first and then a light mild bitterness.

Hellomynameis and I disagreed on this one.  It wasnt what I expected but I enjoyed it very much.  It reminded me of Orval.  Abundant hops in the aroma, like a saison.
