Gold in color and even for a bottle that I understand to be quite old, well carbonated and no oxidation.  Flavor has Belgian yeast, salt, light malt with just a little sweetness.  A dry finish and overall a refreshing beer.

light clear golden colour with a bit of a stark white head. The nose is hoppy and spicy. The flavour was both surprising and dissapointing. Lots of hops was very surprising but the flavour was aweful.

Thanks to Yesper for hooking us up.  Pours a nice cloudy straw golden yellow.  Nice spicy nose with hints of tropical fruit and citrus.  Kinda dissapointing flavor, but a nice balanced creamines and spiciness, as well as a nice biscuity maltiness.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Bought @ Wohlenbergs, Sønderborg. Pours a wonderfully clear golden. A wonderful array of bubbles reaching upwards like metal shards to the end of a magnete. Beautiful creamy white head, like whipped egg-whites. It stays and stays. Aroma is softly fruity, some pineapple and yeast. There is a feeling of barn in there mixed with a little soft spicyness, mostly coriander and vanilla. Wonderful creamyness. Flavour is great as well, very complex. Sweet at first with a very prominent malt character. Then it turns dry and frankly a little hoppy bitter (surprised me). The spices mix up nicely at the end. Wonderful, like a low-alcohol Houblon IPA :o)

Bottle at yesprs place. Cloudy orange. Soft fruity and yeasty aroma, with some spices. The flavour is sweet and pleasant with spices, malt, some yeast and a bit os sourness. Thank you Jesper for sharing a bottle of this tasty brew.

Thanks to Papsoe (via Kaggie97/Zinister trade) for this one. Pours a very nice straw yellow color...cloudy. Nice thick white initial head, that turns into a thin white head. Bright meyer lemons with big yeast nose. Crisp, yeasty flavors with some lemon and oddly, white pepper. Very nice. Thanks Papsoe.

Golden, a bit hazy and with a big white head. Quite floral and fruity aroma, also quite spicy. The most prominent taste is bitterness, I was suprised about how bitter it was (although I might have killed some of the other more fruity notes by drinking it to cold). It it lasts too! But make no mistakes, there absolutley is spice and fruit in threre as well. Vinious I guess. The palate is dry, dusty even. Westvletern sure is great, but it does it live up to the hype? Maybe not so sure.

A torrent of bubbles in a fuzzy medium gold ale. A large head that took up half the glass. Bright white in color and diminished as a tiny plateau in the glass. Dusty smell. Smells slightly sour and dusty. Some indescribable fruit an peppery bitterness. Leaves your tongue and cheeks feeling tingly.  The palate definately doesnt feel the way it looks. Prickly but not very heavily carbonated. The palatte let it down some but Id definitely have this daily if it was widely available. The lacing was a beautiful firey pattern too.
bottle was out-dated by 5 months...a cloudy yellow beer with a white head...earthy yeasty aroma that reminded me of the smell of the air in watou.  delicate malty sweetness balanced with hops.

Thanks MikeTD bringing this straight back from Belgium. Hazy blonde, medium white head. Aroma is biscuity and banana. Flavor is funky, grainy, biscuits, lemon, banana. Not a whole lot going on. Its pretty much a belgian version of a lager. Noble hops are definitely their, but not much else going on. But just cause its Westy doesnt mean its all mighty.

Bottle from theisti (I believe as Secret Santa, muchos gracious). 700th Rating split with a friend.Appearance: Pours with the most thick golden color, so much light, yet so little clarity.  A strong medium sized head with a very sticky lacing.Aroma: Strong with coriander-like yeastiness, Very spicy, yet airy, brisk feel, stings the nose a bit. Some muted floral and honey aspects as well.Flavor: Taste is light sweetness, think lemon with the citrus.  Lots if herbal-yeastiness.  Some light esters and a very organic-earthy feel throughout.Mouthfeel: Very presently felt on the cheeks and a full medium body, yet there are light carbonation spikes on the cheeks. Very nice dichotomy.Extras: Leaves a long light herbal aftertaste. Bottle cap is 05 08 09 I believe, very hard to read.  Really surprised how nice this is, thickness of the beer made me think it would weight in at a higher abv. I also want to add Tims sentiments when he wrote "There is something delicious about this beer that just hangs in your mind."  330ml bottle, Hobgoblin tulip glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 My 700th!!:  Pours a hazy golden color with a big fluffy white head.  Aroma is spicy, herbal, citrus, and some honey.  Flavor is very spicy, herbs, a hint of honey, with a light bitter finish.
2/24/05 330ml. Belgianshop. Golden with massive white head. Citrussy, grassy aroma. A little thin on the palate but with nice bitterness and refreshing taste.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 tasting night 2 days ago. rating on an overall beer.  nice easy drinking belgian ale.  kind of expecting more from this, but its good at what it does.  very good. rating this on a belgian ale scale vs. other belgians would make it one of the best.
Bottle sampled with a few friends.  Pours a nice golden color with a big creamy head.  Sweet aroma with some spice and bread.  Flavor of fruit, malt, spice, with some hops.  Great beer for its style.
UPDATED: APR 22, 2012 Aroma is malty and yeasty. Texture is very smooth and soft, almost creamy feel. Its well blanced. Quite dry with a light hop bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Name: blond - green cap
Date: April 21, 2003
Mode: Bottle
Source: Belgian Shop
Appearance: hazy yellow, big creamy white head
Aroma: sweet spicy malt aroma
Flavor: light bitter flavor, lot of peppery spicyness, the beer is light, but its all about the spices
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Score: *** /4

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours a cloudy gold-amber with a thick head that settles into a nice thin lace that stays with the beer. Delicate aroma of banana, cloves, and gentle malts. Medium body, high carbonation, sits well on the palate. Sweet, as the Belgian Trappist and Abbey styles are known to be.

Bottle from fonefan. Hazy, pale body with a large white, fluffy head, lasting. The aroma is lightly sweet, honey, dusty, light banana, peach and bread. The flavor is lightly sweet, herbal, floral, honey, bread and light banana. Medium body is very soft with light, tight carbonation and a lightly bitter end. Superb. I could drink these all day.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2014 pours a hazy gold.  medium sized white creamy head that lasts throughout the beer.  aroma has notes of banana, grainy pale malt, and pineapple.  medium bodied.  bitter.  herbal.  dry.  flavor has notes of hops, pineapple, and pale malt.  cereal finish. Initial Rating Date: 8/16/2007 6:40:48 PM 

Re-rate after 7 years.  probably not the best beer to age.  It was the worst of the three after the aging.  turned into oxidized honey.  dark gold appearance with small white head.  honey, caramel, malty, faint pineapple. not dry.
Poured a honey color with white head. Had a bunch of "stuff" floating around. Aroma of fruit and some hops. Nice flavor of fruit, hops, sweet malt, and finished kind of spicy. Very smooth.
chiara buona schiuma molto persistente aromi erbacei lieviti in bocca fresca decisamente luppolata molto piacevole

Westvleteren 2007, I had this beer right at the abbey restaurant. Cloudy gold appearance with very thin head..Not overly flavourful with lightly bitter hops and light malt, but a great palate. Refreshing beer, but nothing to go out of your way to try.

Bottle sampled with a friend who brought it back from Europe.  Overall, strongly reminded me of a saison.  Aroma was spicy with hints of herbs.  Beer poured a hazy deep straw color with a persistent, finely beaded while head.  Flavor was spicy with hints of light malt, but nothing out of the ordinary.  Both my friend and I compared it to Leffe in some ways, Saison Dupont in others.  Significant bittering hops  pushed the balance in the finish towards the hopping and I was surprised at how assertively hopped the beer was for bittering.  The mouthfeel was rich with a silkiness that was very pleasant, although the body of the beer was light due to the moderately high carbonation level.  Enjoyed the beer, would be nice everyday drinker if it were around, but Id probably opt for a Sasison Dupont rather than seeking this Blonde out.
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 33cl. bottle.  Bottle cap is 05 08 09 I believe, very hard to read.  That would make this about 11 months old.  Pour is a hazy straw yellow with a fair amount of carbonation.  There is a nice full, white head.  Aroma is sour yeast and earthiness.  Taste is very smooth, with some nice wheaty-grassy-earthiness and and a tangy sweetness (not that it tastes like Tang, more that it has a tang that is sweet). There is pretty much none of the sourness from the original aroma.  The body is medium with a very clean citrus aftertaste.  There was more complexity in this than I was expecting.  This would be a great everyday beer if it was more available.  Is it worth dropping $    on www.   .com?  For me, it certainly was.  Is it worth dropping $    on www.   .com again?  Not sure.  I will say 10 minutes after finishing this I wanted another one.  There is something delicious about this beer that just hangs in your mind.  A year later, and I am still thinking about this beer.  The answer is YES, worth dropping $ again.

Bottle from the_epeeist. I dont know if this wasnt cellared well or what. Cap is dated for 10/07, so I guess this is about one year old. Beautiful pour, super cloudy off-yellow with a lovely foam cap. Aroma is grainy, husky, slight dough. Kind of herbal flavor, husky wheat, perhaps a touch of barnyardy brett/hay. The slightest hint of fruit in the finish. Harsh. Simply not that enjoyable. This bottle must be no good, considering how every other review mentions fruit and I got almost none. Ill be in Belgium in a few months, so Ill give it another shot there.

In de Vrede, Westvleteren, Belgium. Wonderful Blonde, fruity in the accurate, much damson plum, crystallized fruits, floral point soft and cooling.............................In de Vrede, Westvleteren, Belgium. Blonde maravilhosa, frutada no ponto exato, muito damasco, frutas cristalizadas, floral suave e refrescante.

The Dan Journal #91.  Tasted 6/25/2007.  330ml bottle.  Slightly bubbling golden honey hue.  Finger width of off-white head.  Wheaty citrus honey aromas.  Medium bodied with smooth wheats, sharp citrus and tart fruits.  Vanilla start and a honey finish.  This is a huge medium bodied style.  Slightly granular.  Another wonderful offering!

[Shared with Troels and Godfather.]
Hazy light golden look with a great aroma of yeast and fruits. Flavor is fresh, dry, bitter, woody and strawy and soft in a sharp way. Nice!

Courtesy shrubber85.  Pours a very cloudy light orange color, with a small bubbly white head.  Very fruity aroma.  Nice pineapple, candy sugar, yeast, and grapefruit smells.  The taste has a little bitter grapefruit to it, that was pleasant and unexpected.  Definitely has a profound yeast presence.  Nice drinking blonde, full flavored.  Solid, but youd expect it coming from these guys.

Courtesy mgumby10, thanks!!!!  Color is a murky, cloudy yellow.  Aroma is the fruitiest non-fruit beer aroma I have ever come across.  Redolent of fresh pressed cider, with some stonefruit and tropical undertones.  Flavor is slightly biiter with a bit of that fruity aroma coming through.  Very good.

Bottle @ In De Vrede, along with a cheese plate and some Croque Monsieur.  This was the last Westvleteren I tasted, and while it is the worst of their ales it is my favorite Belgian blonde ale.  Appearance is a perfect golden-orange color.  Aroma is slightly citrus with spicy notes thrown in.  The mouthfeel is smooth and subtly complex, with the citrus notes coming out to shine at the end of the beer.  Another good job by the monks.

Good beer, I enjoyed the fact that I was drinking a beer from Westvleteren more than I enjoyed the actual beer.  Ive had beer with much higher alcohol go down smoother than this one, but Im still looking forward to trying the 8 and 12.  This beer is definately over hyped because of the Westvleteren name.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2013 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 6/9/200733 cl bottle, BB 11.08. Clear pale golden color, big white head. Fresh citrus and yeast scent, also spicy. Yeasty spicy taste, rather powerful. Smooth but still medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Slightly metallic but mostly spicy and yeast aftertaste.6/4/6/3/13=3.2Second rating33 cl bottle at Haket, Göteborg on February 8, 2008.BB 2010Clear golden color, white fast dissapearing head. Initially quite hoppy scent, followed by sweet malt, then spice and yeast. Lots of esters and phenoles. Hoppy herbal and floral taste with some pommerance (Seville oranges) and spices. Very fresh and summery, herbal and bitter aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with some fizzy, spritzy notes. Medium high, rather dry, bitterness. Quite dry bitter finish with herbal and spicy hints that linger.8/3/8/3/15=3.7RerateBottle, thanks to Ingo! BB (perhaps) 04.08.13 (difficult to read on the cap). Price tag reads  8.50, was purchased at De Molen. Sampled on November 25, 2013.Hazy blonde color, fluffy lasting white head. Sweet, sugary, light brett and funk scent. Herbal, floral, sweet, perfume, fruity taste. Hibiscus, herbal aftertaste, a bit soapy. Fizzy mouthfeel, very low bitterness.Likely not supposed to be this way, but it works! Bottle was not gushing, but was rising fairly well in the bottle when opened.7/3/7/2/14=3.3

Appearance: Pours a beaming straw-colored body with a bright white, head.

Smell: Aroma is chock full of vibrant fruity esters as well as some faintly grassy, citrus notes.

Taste: Skillfully crafted, this beer is rich and full of flavor. Initial tartness gives way to a light malty, slightly bready sweetness. Also there is the pronounced taste of peaches and oranges - like an albariño, but with a more pronounced, sharper carbonation. Finishes dry with just a touch of spiciness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied and is quite crisp, marked by a constant, but fine champange-like carbonation.

Drinkability: Outstanding. This beer is the greatest invention since wood.

Brown bottle, 330 ml, 2-year old, Trappist tasting at my place, savoured on March 9 2007; eye: nice creamy head, unfiltered apple, opaque, no effervescence; nose: peach, maderized, lightly stale, hay, grainy malt, wort, apple, light Madeira; mouth: light alcohol, a hint of fruit, light Madeira, finale is somewhat dry in grainy corn, creamy texture, medium body, lightly astringent, texture is also grainy

FRANÇAIS 

Bouteille brune, 330 ml, 2 ans dâge, soirée Trappiste chez nous, savourée le 9 mars 2007; oeil : belle mousse crémeuse, pomme non filtrée opaque, pas deffervescence; nez : pêche, madérisé, légèrement éventée, foin, malt granuleux, moût, pomme, léger madère; bouche : léger alcool, petite pointe fruitée, léger madère, finale un peu sèche en maïs granuleux, texture crémeuse, corps moyen, légère astringence, texture aussi granuleuse

Bottle courtesy after4ever. Thanks Tom! Pours a clear bright gold with a huge white head. Great malty aroma with a lightly flowery fruit note behind it. Light body and carbonation. Taste of biscuit, yeast, malt, and a touch of fruit. Crisp and lightly bitter finish.

330. Pours murky golden coppery amber with humongous thick bubbly white head. Plenty of clingy lace, though its very intermittent. Big nose of grass and straw. Tiny bit of funk in there too. Moderate body and carb, but the attack is flavorful enough to be fairly forceful even so.. Mid-palate has some more of the grass and straw, along with some earthy, and herbally bitter hops that carry through to a nice lingering finish. Delectable. Thanks, Maria!

33 cl bottle courtesy fonefan, cap dated 29.04.07. Hazy pale yellow gold with a fully lasting rich creamy and frothy white head. Yeasty, light perfume, fruity, and lightly candyish aroma. Crisp biscuity malt flavours with a floral, perfumed, orange blossom and herbal bitter finish. Medium to full bodied, soft but dry and refreshing mouthfeel. Like a "Duvel Light" or even Orval minus the brett. Very good stuff.
Smelt of mandarin and Belgium yeast. Cloudy and amber gold in colour. Big orange\lemon peel bite combined with the flavour of Belgium yeast.

Bottle @ In de Vrede, Westvleteren.  Dense and creamy two finger head over a slight hazy, peach-colored body. Pleasant fruit aromas; tropical, yellow apples, melon, sweet citrus and banana-split. Lots of floral hops and some yeasty notes. Taste is very well balanced, both mellow and crisp, with a soft maltiness, and a light astringent fruity flavor. Mild bittering hops with a fruity acidity throughout  the finish. Smooth and refreshing. An excellent Blonde!
Hazy blond with a white head. An aroma of wheat, spice and yeast. A fresh flavor with notes of oak, yeast and spice.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 Partly cloudy dark-blonde body with lots of small particles.  Initially large white head with medium retention.  Thanks to red éric for parting with one.  Bottle is a few years old.  Most attractive feature to me is the countryside wild yeast flavour that I usually get from some of my favourite funky Wallonian blondes (Rulles Blonde, Fantôme Saison, etc.).  Cheesy, bubble-gum, vanilla ice-cream and everything Floral hops that are more aromatic (garden flowers/lavender) than tasty.  Superb chewy/doughy mouthfeel.  Surprisingly not-intense (almost delicate) given its reputation.  Definitely one Id like to have again side-by-side with some of the aforementioned beers but unfortunately nowadays it is as hard to find as a humanitarian at a Republican Party Convention.

Bottle courtesy of shrubber85, thanks again! Hazy yellow orange pour with a bone white head. Aroma of yeast, lemon/lemon zest, light pale malt and candied fruit.Flavor of spices, lemon zest, yeast, pale malts and candied fruit. Lively carbonation, medium/light body with a malty/dry finish.
One of my all time Faves.   Shared with many great friends - Ian and my Dad on one special occasion!       Great sesh beer, I just wish I had more... mind its 40miles.   Next week then....

Belgian beer festival Brussels 2006: I cant believe I got my hands on a bottle, felt pretty lucky. Perfect champagne yeast/ fizz, nice fruity great mouthfeal, I agree about the dryness, I like it. really refreshing

Bottle at Kulminator. Hazy golden with a beautiful, big white head. Fruity aroma with hints of spicy hops. Good bitterness with harmonious fruit and grassy flavours. Dry mouthfeel. Reminds me very much of a Hommelbier and that is not a bad thing.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2008 11.2oz bottle. big thanks to JB175 for trading this. pours hazy yellow with huge fluffy head. nose has a strange combination of cloves, citrus, yeast, pepper, B.O., and medicine, kinda stinky. flavor follows the nose into a pretty unappealing mothy, grainy, dirty, cloves, pepper, hay, sugar, and toffee. it tastes sorta strange how all the components for a funky belgian ale are here but it still doesnt balance together well and tastes off. mouthfeel is nice, smooth, and creamy.as i drink it the flavors start to seem more together but still, i was really surprised i didnt like this that much.3.6. 

4/6/08, sampled at a WLV tasting. now i get this beer. wonderfully hoppy grassy herbal and floral. tastes clean, refreshing, and fresh. a wonderful belgian ale.4.0.

The Westvleteren Blonde pours a couldy straw colr with a thin tight head that leaves abeautiful lace on the glass as you drink.  My first impression, when pulled beneath my nose my is the scent of yeast, cloves and slightly peppery. The first taste is plum and then clove. The carbonation is not overtly effervescent but assertive. 
Definately not over the top this beer is a refined gentleman.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of gputy. Pours a fairly bright yellow with a thin, but frothy, white head.  Nose of yeast, pepper, and perhaps white grapes..   Flavor is slightly hoppy, with the yeast from the nose, as well as a sweetness.  Very smooth mouthfeel  - not too light, not too heavy; just right.

Thanks once again Maria for the trade. What a difference between this and the other 2. Aroma was all grass. I didnt get the concept of "grass" in beer until this. Tasted and smelled like I just cut the lawn. A little hop in the after taste. While the 8 and 12 are at the top of their game, the blond leaves a lot to be desired.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I dont imagine this beer would travel very well. Had this at the abbey cafe and it was hoppy fresh and flavourful and the second best beer I had when I was in Belgium. Page 496 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer guide.

Bottle at Waagstuk, Antwerpen. Golden body, medium white creamy head, very small particles. Honey, flowers, sugar, fruits, funky yeast in the aroma. Light hop bitter and sweet flavour, more light hoppy finish. Delicious.

Rating #300
330 ml brown bottle. Gift from a friend. 
Hazy golden with a thin but lasting head.
Streams of tiny champagne like bubbles rise from various parts of the glass.

Sweet citrus nose,  lightly floral, maybe some apple. 

Flavor is citrusy, doughy, a little spicy a little sweet.
Leaves a tingle on the lips. 
Finish is long and refreshingly bitter with a sweet fruitiness rolled up inside.
I wish I had more.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2008 Lovely gold with a fat, creamy head. Nose of lemon, honey, fresh and grassy hops. Flavor has citrus notes, nicely dry and good bitterness. refreshing. Faintly lambic-like musty tones much appreciated. Barely a drop of sweetness to be found. Justly famous. Probably my favorite blonde in the country, it grows on me more each time I try it.

Drunk at One Pint Pub, Helsinki during the Belgian beer week 2007. The menu says "6" but the cap is green. Wonderfull balanced flower, grass, hay aroma. Taste very fresh, nice yeasty bitterness. Perfectly balanced. Hazy colour, big white head.
bottle. murky yellow color. yeasty grainy aroma. bitter. some hops. very yeasty and acidy. grainy and strong.

Poured a golden color into a Westvleteren chalice. The head was a thin, white and seem to last a long time. A fair amount of lacing on the glass. Tastes of spices, bread dough, citrus, and coriander. Aroma of fruits. Finish was full with just the right amount of bitterness.  I have been waiting to taste this treat a long time.

Pale yellow with huge white head that lasts a long time. Nice aroma of coriander, citrus and malts.

Taste like a tripple sweet and spicy with some hopps at the end. A nice ale.
Bottle. Dark golden colour with a beige head. Aroma is yeast, sweet, fruit, hop. Flavour is hop, yeast, sweet, fruit, yellow apple, spices.

Beer 7 of Obriens Trappist Tasting 2/3/07.  Green cap, as it has now become Westy 6/blond.  04 bottle.  Poured yellow in color with a lot of carbonation, with a thin white head.  The aroma is quite sweet with lot of ctrus notes.  The taste was really complex, fresh and slightly bitter with a little bit of a sour edge.  Really a stellar brew.

The first time I tasted this was October 30. 2005. The color is amber and the head is moderate, but very lasting. the aroma has notes of hops, fruit and yeast and the mouthfeel is rather oily. The flavour is sweetish with a lot of hops, fruit (apple and a lot of citrus), and it has a pronounced hoppy bitterness, that develops throughout the entire flavour and is strong in the finish. Almost a year later I tasted the next one, and I know for sure, that this was from the same batch as # 1, so its 3½ years by now. It hasnt changed a lot, I think I like it better now, though. I still miss the sweetness, that I find important in a blond, but its as if the hops are less dominant by now. Another factor might be, that I started out knowing, that this wouldnt be sweet, and perhaps that made the difference...

330ml bottle. Hazy orange body with a decent creamy head. Aroma is grassy and floral. Flavor is very harmonic indeed, malty, sweet, a fresh kind of fruit sourness and spicy. A complex and fresh, easy drinkable beer. Not a typical blond, either not exactly what I was expecting from Westvleteren, but a really great beer.

Dated 03 03 06. Bottle from trade with shrubber85. Thanks.  My first Westy. Pour is golden blond with a soapy white head. Aroma is potent with sour apples, white icing cake, dirty citrus hops. Mouthfeel is both bready and creamy. Flavors are overpowered by a whole lotta yeast.  A new flavor that is enjoyable and quite refreshing.  Look forward to tasting the rest of the Westvletren fleet, though I am glad I tried this one first.
very refreshing. lots of floral, and citrus notes to this brew. nice bitterness in the finish. I thoroughly enjoyed this one.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 fairly clear straw colored pour w/ a huge frothy well laced white head nad lots of visable carbonation.  Aroma of light bread dough some light fruits banannas and a touch of black pepper some other light spices as well.  Very mellow and well blended.  Light fluffy palate coats well.  Flavor is a little disapoint some light fruity notes possibly some bananna and hints of bread then a bitter dry grass and metallic component that leaves a not so great aftertaste.  I would much rather have the other westy products, but this aint to shabby.
As the beer warms closer to room temperature more of the spices and peppery notes come through in the flavor and the mettalic taste seems to die down if not dissapear.
I drank this after the 12 and 8, which was probably a mistake.  Spicy yeast, bread, crust, and citrus.

Small white head. Pale yellow body with carbonation. Sweet tropical fruit aroma with slightly metallic hop notes. Not that much aroma. Bitterish fruity taste with metallic hop tinge. Soft, smooth mouthfeel. Dry, bitter metallic aftertaste with flat, almost papery background and peppery notes. Lots of taste, yet still quite light; soft, yet harsh; this is a strange beer. Quite nice. (0.33l bottle.)

Bottle. Tasting 12-01-2007 (Søren, Peter, Carsten). To celebrate my #250. Impressive Belgian Ale I must say. Average creamy white head that was mostly diminishing. Good lacing. Body was cloudy with heavy particles. Kind of light orange color. Aroma was complex with notes of grain, hay, flowers, grass, citrus, orange, sweat, leather, soap, banana, clove and coriander as some of the dominant notes. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with an average bitter-sweet finish. Quit impressive.

Smells and looks just like a wit normally does.  Full mouthfeel.  Light spices and a definite earthy flavor.  You can pick out the yeasty Westy flavor profile in a second.   Spices dont overpower this one, and it is very refreshing.

33 cL bottle. Pours almost white/clear but becomes slightly yellow. Clear fruity aroma with yeast elements. Carbonation as well. Almost no sweetness, has fruit notes, slightly nutty as well. Yeast and citric notes are dominating. Reminded me of Orval without being too similar. Aftertaste is suprisingly bitter, yet not overly dominating.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2008 Bottled. Rating #1500. Ok, so its not the best beer to drink celebrating, but it is a quite good one. Pours unclear, with a lot of carbonation and cloudyness in a pale golden body, topped by a nice, creamy, white head. The aroma is fruity, with hops, medicine-like bitter notes, hints of cellar, spices, yellow apples and some alcohol. Quite complex actually, but yet not one of the best. The same goes for the flavor, which is fruity and sweet, with bitterness, spices, yeast and a dash of alcohol. Medium body and a finish with spices and hops. Funny thinking about the fact that this is the least interesting beer from this brewery, yet so good. Rating: 7-4-7-3-14-3.5. (070103)Bottle. It pours a hazy, yellow-orange body with some floaties and a nice, white head. Grains, pale malt, fruityness and yeast it the aroma. A little spicy note too. Nice sweet and malty flavor with some alcohol notes and a pleasant bitterness. Some herbal notes too. Medium to full body. Bitter, malty and slightly spiced finish. Wondering if I over-rated the beer last time, I did a rerate and found out I didnt. It really is a good beer. Rating unaltered. (080509)

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 (Bottle, BB 28/04/07)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of mustiness, pear, grass, subtle butter, vanilla, toasted grain, and lemon.  Flavor of citrus, spicy yeast, herbs, and grass with a soft mouthfeel.
Pale yellow color.  Excellent fruitiness, (pineapple, pear) blended with yeastiness.  Just a hint of spice and herbal bitterness on the finish.
Body is foggy gold, with a thin white head.  Aroma is of heavy pale malts, pineapple, apple, grapefuit.  Taste has a light hoppiness which is initially followed by grapefruit and light hops.

belgian yeast and some slight spice in the aroma.Pours a murky light gold with a large off white head.Flavors are of yeast light fruit and some hints of spice.This one has some airy carbonation and finishes with some slight spice.
Hazy yellow with nice white head with excellent lacing. Yeast, citrus and hint of flowers Slight bitter finish.

33cl bottle from henrikb, dated 1.03.05.  Pours a pale yellow until I poured the yeast in, and now its a cloudy light brownish yellow.  The head is tight, two fingered, and white.  Looks like it will be staying the duration.  Aroma of cork, powdered sugar, yeast, apricots, pear, a bit of spices and dust.  The flavor is much the same, though doesnt seem quite as good--flavors here seem muted.  There is some lemon and a bit of tart acidity (though the two dont seem related) and a dry lightly bitter finish.    Moderate carbonation, light to medium bodied.  Henrik gave me all three of the Westvleterens, and starting with this one Im fairly excited about the others as well.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a pale lemony yellow w/o the yeast. Turns more tawny yellow after yeast is poured from the bottled. Medium sized snow white, semi creamy froth that reduces at a moderate pace leaving full brewers lace and a full dusty canopy. Not much aroma at all when cold but as she warms it really opens up. Aromas of freshly squeezed citrus and crushed walnuts with the shell. Very interesting indeed. Light nectar w/ ample residual effers. The texture is soft yet fiberous like a cotton ball. Flavors are totally dry w/ delicate nuances of a French Champagne nature. A nice acid componant w/ bright citrus rind and yeast. Weaved in the mix are complexities consisting of walnuts,  muscat, honeydew rind, and a pinch of spicey clove. The finish is bittered from the stone fruit spectrum. Overall: This is a complex brew that drinks better warm. Very complex indeed. Because of its Champagne flavor profile I bet it tastes great w/ a bowl of strawberries. If you love Champagne, you gotta try this brew. Connoisseurs choice!

Bottle; Nose of yeasty breadiness, with light apple, clove, an caramel notes; light but complex aroma, not jumping out at you like the big beers, but there; hazy golden with a big frothy, long-lasting, glass-lacing white head; flavor intially of peppery, spicy, hop bitterness, the hops lasting into a long finish!

What a nice surprise. Both to be given this as a christmas gift and the beer itself. Pale and slightly murky looking with a nice white head. Very nice and complex aroma, dominated by light yeasts (I really dont know how to describe it), some spicyness and a bit of hops.
Very flavourful for the type (blond), coriander, lovely and quite characteristic yeast flavour with a good balance btw. sweet and bitter notes.
Impressive if the alc. content is correct - it does taste of quite a lot more.

Huge fluffy, rocky head.  Beautiful hazy golden color with some light carbonation bubbling up from the bottom of the chalice.  Very spicy, hoppy, fruity aroma with a hints of fruitiness and sugariness.  Huge sweet-but-bitter flavors:  spices (coriander, nutmeg, clove), orange and lemon zest, some slight pepperiness, and a serious dose of hops.  Mouthfeel is a bit sticky, but with some prickliness on the tongue from the carbonation.  Surprisingly dry and bitter hoppy finish.  Amazing.
Bottled. Hazy golden coloured with almost no head. Mild and round. A bit dusty with notes of hops, spices, fruits and yeasts. A bit dry.

451st.  Bottle that I picked up on eBay.  Light golden orange thin white head seems to grow in size as it the glass warms.  The aroma is bready and smells a little like sun dried zest.  Light, dry, citrus finish.  Medium bodied, which is heavy than I expected.  Flavor is very much like a lager, except much better.  King of the Light Trappists!

300th rating - I figured this would be a good time to crack open the first of my Westys.  Light orange-blonde color with a fair amount of yeast and a medium size head.  Aroma of orange and other citrus, yeast, and an almost Pils-like malt.  Taste is heavy with yeast and Belgian malts, with hints of citrus breaking through.  Lighter, but very tasty.  Im glad it made the trip from Europe without any problems - more importantly, the "8" and "12" will be up soon.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2008 Bought and held for approx. 18 months with no noticeable change in flavor.  Light and fruity with easy, clean taste that does not linger.  One of my favorite blonds and an excellent starting point for Trappist biers.

At Tavern de bottleje - Ostende. Slightly hazy copper with a rocky white head. Slight citrus and yeast in the aroma... suprisingly weak, but pretty pleasant all the same. Light, yet balanced body, slightly dry with flavours of citrus, cinnamon and apricot. The finish is also dry. Overall it shows great balance, I was a little disappointed, but in reality its about as much as one could do with the style.

Yellow like Duvel, but not as filtered. Sweet aroma, but the taste is surprisingly bitter and also yeasty.  Ive heard that the recipe for this beer has been changed (to sweeter), with this being the last bottles of the old kind. Date on cap is 11.08.07.
Light golded colored pour with a little haze.  A yeasty, flowery aroma with a slight sweet, bitter finish.  Pretty good.
Poured a blonde amber but a bit hazy with sedement, also had a white bubbly carbonated head. Sweet spicy hoppy like aroma. Flavor was sweet and hoppy metallic grass, did get spicier as it warmed.

Standard Belgian blond in appearance. Slightly more haze than expected and a persistent thin head. Expressive nose of confectionary malts shows ok lift. Palate is more understated, the typical sweetish malts are present but they dont really get out of first gear. In fact the palate is quite dry for the style and is well backed with a little spice and cinnamon. Thinking mans Belgian blond? (e.3.75 @ Afspanning t Waagstuk)

also very good

has the feeling like Leffe but better, also cheaper then the others and not so heave alcohol ... , nice if you dont want to get drunk

SLightly hazy pale yellow/straw liquid sits underneath a bed of frothy white foam. Lemony/citrus aromas give way to subtle spices, mixed with grassy/hay nuances. Very soft and pleasant. Very fruity lemon zest and other citrus flavours. Herbal, with mild bitter hopping, and a touch of mint leaf/fresh grass. Good, and again subtle. Very refreshing lemon/mineral finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Thanks for sharing this rare treat Mr. Horsey!

From a distinctive no labels Westvletern 33 cl. brown bottle with the freshness date on the cap, 11.08.07, sampled at cellar temperature in a Westy chalice a friend gave me last Christmas.

Poured a hazy pale orangey golden with a foamy white head, a small amount of laced sticking.

Aromas of herbal hops, a bit leafy as well and a subtle honey maltiness in the background.

Good even carbonation and a softly crisp, textured, velvety smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel, superb. 

A great tasting blond ale, herbal hops with a touch of tobacco dry leafiness, soft bitterness, a sweet honey grain maltiness that cuts underneath the hops and a dry grainy finish with a lingering herbalness.

An excellent blond ale, easy drinkability, very glad I finally had a chance to try it, well worth it.

drank at In de Verde:  Aroma is very spicy with some hops, and pepper.  lovely blondish orange color.  flavor is herbal, with hops, and some grass.  fruity, but spicy.  Very nice dry finish.  Like all Westvleteren beers, the perfect amount of hops.  perfect palate again.  I love these beers.  Cheers.

Thank you Belgian shop for sending me this. Very good, but quite a straight forward ale, all things considered. Pours a gorgeous almost opaque orange. Fruity spicy esters and hops. Medium bodied with a dry, almost overly dry finish. Very good ale.

Straight out of a fridge at the Bishops Arms in Umeå.

appearence - might have had a touch of chill haze, but a yeasty pale straw yellow colour with a fine head that slowly disappeared, leaving fine lacing that stuck around.

Aroma - Complex, with herby, slightly peppary hints, lemon and honey.

Flavour - the drinking mans trappist - begins with some faint malt and a touch of herbs and phenols, which is all quickly and rather rudely pushed aside by a powerful hoppy finish, with a puckering bitterness that can be felt all the way back home (its a 30 minute walk from the pub). The lack of richness that you usually associate with Belgium beers only makes this example more noteworthy and more drinkable!

Palate - wonderful, tingley carbonation at the tip of the tongue, followed by a smooth middle and a powerful hop kick in the throat at the end. Who said you cant have it all?

Overall - one of the most suprising Trappists Ive drunk to date, not least because this is a beer that you could drink more than one bottle of without being wasteful. Of course youve got to find another bottle first, and when you do be prepared to spend $27.50 to buy it (this is, after all Sweden). But you get the general idea...

12oz bottle courtesy of sk8viking.  Thanks, Rene!  Pours the color of apple juice, golden yellow and clear, slight effervescence from the bottom; white head with good retention and lacing.  The nose is exquisite: vinuous, honey, belgian sugar, and hints of spice.  Medium mouthfeel, slightly viscuous and sugary: plenty of bread and yeast, a touch of honey, spice (reminds me of De Dolles Stille Nacht, upfront); long finish with (interestingly) the sweetness bottoming out - dramatic shift in the finish, ending yeasty and somewhat dry.

Bottle bought at BeerMania, tasted with a Westvleteren glass together the other two :-) It has white foam and hazy, golden colour. Quite dry and a slick feel. Good balance with a long finish. A good belgian blond but the other two are better.

Bottle, shared at The Kulminator and also shared at Waagstuck, Antwerp, Belgium, 05 and 06-10-06. Poured a warm golden colour with a good white head, quite a hoppy nose with some yeast but I felt that the aroma was actually quite delicate. Some light honeylike flavours and a little citrusy fruit and quite crisp, not fantastic but not bad at all.
Bottle. White low but lasting head. Hazy yellow body. Sweet and fruity aroma. Alcohol dominated dry hops flavor
Hazy golden/yellow color with a white head. Yeasty, flowery citrus aroma. This one falls short alittle. Grassy, malt, and spicy flavor. Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle at The Beer Weekend, Brussels. Had high hopes with all the hype of Westvlet. and was not let down. Glad I went for it when I did as I got the last one for the day. Poured a pale cloudy yellow with ample head that left spotty lacing as I dove straight in. Hoppy nose with citrus hints. Grapefruit, coriander and orange notes. So easy to drink, was clean and crisp with good carbonation. Went down a treat with the Chimay cheese selection. Everything you could hope for in a good blonde bier.

Aroma: yeast, coriander, duvelesque, pear, lavender, vaguely liquorice-like, some orange... Appearance: cloudy, greytinted apricot yellow-orange with some white head in an assymetric array. Flavor: pretty dry, hoppy, soft, pinelike, very rustic, not as sweet as expected, good surprise. Palate: rough, smooth but wonderful. Perfect co2.

The aroma of this beer is sweet, lime, honey, plum, fruit cake. As I taste this beer the flavors previously mentioned come out. The honey, bitterness, all are enhanced by the crisp carbonation of this brew. This  is delicious Trappist, one that satisfies with complex flavors and crisp taste.

From the bottle into a shallow chalice @ the Blanche de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belgium. 
Poured a hazy gold, well conditioned as the carbonation was microscopic and slow to release. Head was firm, rocky and held out for the length lacing well. Aroma was fruity, citric - a blend reminiscent of New Zealand and American hop notes - with grapefruit, passionfruit, guava and just a little bready yeast and pale malt to fill it out. Its quite lively in the mouth. Its not harshly carbonated but it does bounce and prickle. Sweet, fruity esters lead it, its yeasty and bready otherwise. Nice ripe grapefruit and lemon, touch of sour malt in back before a dry, scarcely fruity bitter swallow that held little length. As it warms it fills out a little becoming tangy, gammy and slightly herbal. Not much to it, though it is refreshing cold. Glad I got to try it, though it was no showstopper. Rare, but not refined Summer quaffer. The monks ale, so to speak. (33cL, 07/09/07 stamped on the cap)
Bottle. Pours yellow / golden, hazy with a small white head. Smells yeast, malt and grapefruit. Aroma is promising, with yeasts, malt, spice and hop, nice and very complex.

Pours cloudy and light golden with a thin mostly receding white head. Aroma of honey, toasted malts, bread dough, coriander, and saffron. Taste is lightly sweet and yeasty with notes of fruity esters and wheat. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush carbonation. Fruity and refreshing! Well done.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2007 Bottle, 33 cl. This beer leaves a thick white head that drips down the side of the glass. Aroma is sweet, honey, plum, fruit cake. Taste different hops = wunderfull, the honey, bitterness. This is delicious with complex flavors and crisp taste. VERY GREAT BEER !

Courtesy of boboski. Hazy yellow/gold topped by a modest, frothy yet dense, white head. Softly sweet malt, light grains, cardboard, small dose of light fruits, crisp bitterness, light must, and a subtle sourness on the finish. Medium body, balanced. Solid blond.

Pours a slight  hazy golden with a huge  white head.  Aroma is light fruits, apples, pears, candy suga, bit of citrus.  Flavor is sweet, with the light fruits providing most of the flavor.  Mouthfeel is very smooth, finish is decently bitter, well balanced.
plain looking, kinda sweet, some fruit hints.  regular lightish body, low carbonation.

(Bottle at Sint Sixtusabdij) Pours yellow/golden, hazy with a small white head. Smells yeast, malt and grapefruit. Kiwi. A bit alcohol. Lemon. A very fresh smell. Taste: the usual silky & smooth body. A bit of grapefruit and pepper. Malt.  Herbs. perfect carbonation.  A tiny bit dry.Very smooth. Extremely clean with a slight afterbitterness.
Probably one the only belgian beers I had in Belgium that I liked.  Rather sweet and malty, smooth in flavor and texture.  Unfortunately the only Westy I could get my hands on in Belgium.

Very hazy and honey colored.   Aroma was a bit of spice and yeast....candi sugar.  Flavor was similar...a lot more bread and malty sweetness than I would have expected.  Mouthfeel was smooth and quite light.
Gollden colored with thick white head.  yeasty aroma, with some spiciness. pretty good but not a huge fan and feel this was a little over-hyped.

Sampled at In de Vrede. This was the first of the three Westies in front of me and needless to say, expectations were sky high. Colour is hazy gold. Nose is promising, with yeasts, malt, spice and hop..very complex. Taste is pure bliss and if by some horrible and unforeseen accident I would have spilled the remaining two Westies before me, Id still been a very happy man.

Smoke-tented blonde; light, almost imperceptible scent of malt--perfect effervescence. There must be a German influence here, because it tastes like a mild hefeweizen, with no bite, with a slight lemony flavor. Overall, Id say its almost too smooth, rendering it characterless in flavor yet brilliant in blandness (if that makes sense).

Finishing the holy trinity. Poured a hazy golden body with a fairly large head, good but not great lacing. Aroma is spicy, peppery with notes of their sugar and yeast. Some bitterness. Flavor is a little more pronounced, but still had a watery finish near the end. It was like a bad RR Damnation to me. Not impressed.

Bottle: 3 for 3! Cloudy orange gold pour, with a big white rocky head. Some Sediment, and some nice lacing. Aroma, had some spice, yeast, and some light floral hops. Flavor was a little bready, with some spice in there, and a light crisp hoppiness. I hate that I paid as much as I did for this, but at least I got to try it.

Double thanks here to kp for breaking it out and one to Beercellar2 for making me try it. A hazy golden pour that reeks of fruit and yeast. A flavor of light fruit and much yeast. Much lighter carbonation than I expected. A beer I never thought I would see much less try. Thanks guys.
Poured a hazy pale yellow color with a medium but quickly dissolving white head.  The aroma was fruity and suggary with notes of apples.  The flavor was yeasty, sweet and floral.  Lively mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Poured into my new Westy glass.  Cloudy golden/straw color.  Thick bubbly head.  Very yeasty aroma, with a dash of spices (coriander?).  Good bit of yeastiness in flavor, along with some mustiness, spices and a little hoppy bitternmess.  Decent mouthfeel.  Overall, I was somewhat under-whelmed.  Perhaps I am not a blond fan or perhaps it was the hype.

Bottle into Westy glass, Heeren van Liedekerke.  Golden yellow and almost clear in the glass, visibly effervescent, with a creamy small bubbled head thats thick and clings to the side.  Duvelish smell, yeasty, with banana and light fluffy bread.  The smell also has a strong strain of herbs and spices (ginger, coriander).  Light and lilting on the tongue, some watermelon and malt ride the refreshing body.  Only after the swallow does this get serious, with noble hops at great strong level drying out the finish (and some black pepper too).  Thick wall of lace everywhere, with a bit of the 3D effect I saw in the J & J Blauw.  Soft carbonation dominates the mouthfeel, filling the mouth with soft foam that tickles the tongue and keeps the beer delicate before the nicely delicate and dry finish.  Racing is quick and belies the effervescent upward tension in the beer.  Although the flavor doesnt dominate the experience (which is usually my preference), this was obviously crafted with a look toward the feel and the softness; in that regard, it is incredibly well done.

Bottle from Beermania, Brussels.  Yeast coating interior bottle.  Looks wicked for a blonde like that.  Extremely pale straw golden blond, yet hazy, so the overall appearance is of a heady wheat beer with a big puffy white head.  Smells like a wheatfield with occassional peachtrees in a big loaf of religious challah bread.  Taste is tangy and more like a lemon rind than any other beer Ive had before.  As it finishes, it tastes like grass.  Its surprisingly exciting compared to its style and "statistical" evaluation next to its brothers.  It is clear that very personal care went into the making of this beer and it is certainly a beer to keep other blonde beers who have lost their soul awake at night.  This is no super sweet, coriander heavy beer, though both those subject will become evident upon some of your tastes of this beer, but other times it will taste rather different and always provide a pleasing complement to what you are contemlating or experiencing.  It deserves a higher rating for being exemplary, top of its class.
Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow colour. Fantastic powerfull complex aroma. Honey hints. Flavor outstanding. Very bitter long finish. Creamy palate. A really fantastic beer.

For my first passage at the eminent abbey of St. Sixtus, I settled to stop by the controversial In de Vrede, and see what the fuss is about. Sitting myself at one of the large tables, I ordered the Blond and a side of cheese. To my right a lone smoker sat with his beer, while the two noisy families on my right were enjoying a meal with theirs. I must say these are rather poor conditions for such a ceremonial event, but I took my chance anyway. Poured and slipped under my nose in an instant, the beer was topped of a beautiful white foam that slowly diminished leaving a sticky lace evenly across the surface. Below, a rather sickly looking liquid gravitated in the glass, an ochre tint that seemed somehow unappealing, perhaps due to the sooty grey table it was sitting on. As I brought the chalice to my nose, the only smell I could sense came from the miasma crowding the room. With effort, I began to detect light estery notes, bubble gum and banana especially, followed by pepper, chalk and cream. A refreshing fragrance but somewhat bland, I must concede. The strong tingling of carbonation first collides with the tongue, but subsequently reveals a spicy flavor of pepper and coriander mixed with mango and wheat. Again, a lack of depth surprises me, as the finishing bitterness of Belgian hops strikes my palate. I consciously make an effort to perceive the subtleties, but cant, and end my glass in a quaff. This one deserves another chance.

Thanks to egajdzis for this 04 vintage...
Appears a light yellow with a small white head that fades into a mild cap and thin collar. Streaks of lacing are left around the glass.
Smell is of light fruit, mild yeast, white bread, light caramel malt with some pilsner-esque aromas, along with an tiny herbal spiceyness.
Taste is of the above mentioned aromas...perhaps a slight drop from the anticipated flavor not quite living up to the smell.
Mouthfeel is crisp, dry, with a very subdued sugar taste in the swallow.

Bottle at DØE get-together. Light pilsner-yellow color. Hoppy smell, a sweet, hoppy, pebery taste. Not that interesting.
Maybe i am no blond-fan.

Nr. 2 i rækken er denne.
Vi er uden i noget som absolut ikke smager mig. Kedelig sprøjt.
Sød og gæret, tisgul i farven.

Jeg har lovet Rene at give det en chance, men der er dog grænser.

Men den gode stemning breder sig om bordet.......
UPDATED: MAR 27, 2015 Hoppy, biscuit-y, fresh, herbal, grassy. Vibrant carbonation, sweetness and acid well-matched. From bottle at Westvleteren.
Really smooth, with light flavors of spice, fruit and a very slight medicine taste. As it warmed more citrus flavor was noticed. Very good and refreshing. Too bad this is so hard to get.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 Re-rate, 10/07, courtesy of Robert at SL. A bit different of an experience, this time coming off almost like an imperial pilsner, good grainey and bready elements underneath it all, but a grassy dry hoppy finish was very clear and memorable, more distinct than anything spicey about it. Lighter fruits took a lesser role this time around too. A fun experience, much thanks to Robert! Original rating: This one poured the usual golden murky color. The mouthfeel was more carbonated and the body lighter than the other Westvleteren brews. The aroma was yeasty and mild (not strong). There was a bitterness to this beer that was really enjoyable. The finish was dry and peppery with an orange peel / zest flavor present from start to finish of each sip. This beer exceeded my expectations, while the "8" mildly disappointed.

Hazy/cloudy yellow beer topped by a thick moussy head.  Head keeps growing up over the edge of my Westy tulip without ever spilling over.  Aroma is quite light and dusty, some nice spicy wheaty character, sweet peachiness, a bit of clove and a perfume and cologne aroma.  Flavour is surprisingly subtle, but good.  Wheaty body and flavour, soft textured but full-bodied.  Peach sweetness, with some dusty, yeasty notes.  Lingering spicy finish, soft wheat and some herbal minty hop flavour.  Honeyish malt and light bitterness.  Nice beer.

bottle thanks to blankboy.  Hazy pale yellow pour with a nice foamy head.  Aromas were bright citrus and pepper.  Flavor was more malty than the aromas.  The light crisp citrus was still there as was the pepper.  Some additional spice through the middle.  Hoppy bite on the finish.  Very nice beer

Hazy yellow colour with a large head with nice lacing. The aroma is malty, with notes of wheat citurs, bread and tapicoa. Flavour is complex with lots of belgian yeast, malts and spice with even some sourness. Nice dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a golden-orange and a large, rocky white head. The aroma has lots of spice, yeasty cookies, and bread. Light bread starts out and the hops follow. Medium carbonation. Yeast length is significant as it gives a good amount of body and there is surprisiingly a lot of hop flavour and bitterness; oranges are resultant and are quite flavourful. There is also some fruit in the way of pears and apples. Excellent and great to drink in all aspects. 


Had this at the Kulminator on May 17, 2006.
Pale amber. Nice complex aroma -- hops and yeast and a bit nutty (?!). Fresh. Stands out among blondes, but definitely overrated.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Large white head with a cloudy, golden body. Fruit aroma. Complex fruit flavour with an unusual hopppy bitterness for a blonde. Bitter finish. Reminds me of Orval but with more dimensions. Its very enjoyable.

Blonde beer - large head but very airy with loads of bubbles -- the head reduces over 1-2 minutes to thin foam. Smells something like lemon meringue pie, lke Hoegaarden with lempn, but without the added lemon. Creamy drinking experience with a fresh citrus taste. Solid wheat undertones but not overpowering. Excellent beer expecially for warmish weather. Like the other westvleteren beers it is an unmarked bottle but this time with a raised ridge around the neck reading trappistenbier.
Bottle. Beautiful head, color. Not a whole lot of aroma. Good flavor gets better as beer warms.
light golden with white head. Very fine balance between spices and fruits. bitterness and hops. Very complex and brilliant blond. Long lasting finish!

Bottle. Nice lasting head. Color is light golden and a bit hazy. Aroma is fruit and hops. Taste is not as sweet and fruity as a regular blonde (to my disappointment) but way more bitter and hoppy. Sediments left in bottle. Really good mouthfeel. Having tasted the 8 and 12 from westvleteren - this was a major disappointment.
Cloudy yellow colour with a thick white creamy fully lasting head. Sweet aroma of yeast, hops and fruits. Powerful bitter sweet flavour. Long lasting finish.

Props to gputty for the hookup. Hazy yellow gold with a medium white head. Lots of particulate settling in the glass. Nose is sweet - tapioca, yeast, maybe a hint of rice pudding. Some coriander and wheatlike notes. Light, sweet, yeasty flavor, mild tropical fruit notes. Creamy, but lively body.

From bottle.  Pours a dull, cloudy yellow with thin white head and floaties.  Nose is yeasty and bread like with light fruits underneath, banana and pineapple.  Flavor is light and refreshing, a bit dry and follows the nose.

Beautifully golden with a huge white head, stays long and leaves laces; Huge fresh deep complex nose. Lots of hop, but also some hidden sweetness, like raisins; Super, super well balanced body, it is a very little watery, with a small to medium carbonation; The finish has more or less the same notes as the nose, a little more hop though. It has a super nice bitterness that starts a little late, is a very little watery, but lasts very long.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Aged 2 years-----Pours a golden hue with a frothy white head.  Aromas of coriander and little citrus and a some hops???? A little skunky as well... 
Mouth feel is medium bodied with flavors of spice, orange peel,  some lemon,  and a light sourness.   Very complex for such a light brew.  This is not nearly as good as when I had it fresh from the restaurant by the brewery...  but still amazing for the style

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a big white head. Aroma is hoppy with citrus  not so powerful. Flavour is lightly sweet and hoppy with a somewhat bitter finish. Slight notes of yeast. Easy to drink. 28-01-06.

Note: This beer has been aged for 2 years.

This beer pours a cloudy, yeast filled dirty blonde. It leaves a thick white head that drips down the side of the glass. The aroma of this beer is sweet, lime, honey, plum, fruit cake. As I taste this beer the flavors previously mentioned come out. The lemon rind, honey, bitterness, all are enhanced by the crisp carbonation of this brew. This belgian is delicious one that satisfies with complex flavors and crisp taste.

Bottle: Pours a hazy golden yellow with a frothy white head that laces my trappist glass very good after diminishing. Aroma is pear with a complex yeast flavor that leaves a light bitter finish. Smooth and delicious!

Courtesy of Tom at Monks Cafe.

I told him I hadnt had this Westy and he brought a bottle up. Aroma is very yeasty with lots of spice notes. Cloudy light yellow/orange with a huge frothed up head. Flavor is fruity (pear and apple) and yeasty with just a kiss of bitterness in the finish.

Pours a hazy yellow, slightly orange, with a bright white creamy head. Aroma is sweet malt, coconut, spearmint, and pomes. A huge yeasty undertone. Flavor is light candy sweet malt, some light fruits, pear, and a gentle crisp hop bitterness. Finishes with a slight lemon tinge. Lively carbonation, soft in the mouth.

Bottled from Madsberg! Pours a very clidy oraneg color with an active bright white head. Lots of bubbles ensue. Nose is coconut, spearmint, thyme, lightly yeasty. Taste is a nice malt up front, with some light citrus notes following, more of the pineapple and lemon notes, as well as some very fresh outdoorsy and floral notes.

2 bottles shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry and me. Pours a hazy gold with a huge foamy white head. Lovely aroma of yeast, fruit, spices and some hops. Belgian Blondes are not my favourite style of beer so I was quite pleased with the flavour, its quite complex and delicious. It starts yeasty followed by some citrus, malt and spices and ends with a nice hoppy bitterness. As with all Westy beers, each sip is slightly different then the last and a treat for the mouth. Very smooth and creamy. Medium bodied. Fantastic!

Bottles shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev & jerc - courtesy of blankboy & HogTownHarry. Many, many thanks to Paul and Harry for sharing two bottles of this rare treat with us. Hazy gold with a medium white head and lots of chunky floaties. Aroma is funky and fruity, with some fermented peach & apricot notes, and a surprising bit of hoppiness. Flavour is very nice - subtle, but very well constructed, with notes of spice, yeast, orange and malt, leading to a dry, refreshing finish. As much as I like the Trappist beers, I generally cant imagine drinking more than one in a sitting, but this would be a killer patio beer!

Pours cloudy yellow hay, straw with a tall foamy, creamy white head and thick creamy lacing.  Banana and light malt and yeast (wheat) aroma, faint citrus hop nose, lemony.  Yeasty wheat and sour hop, light malt flavor, bananas with a metallic finish.  Light bodied and creamy palate.

Bottle at Bier Cirkus. Hazy blond ale with a ultra resilient white head, and beuatiful lacings. Wonderful sweet vanilla, hops and candy in aroma. Wonderfully creamy mouthfeel, with hops and sweet candy sugar coming out beutifully, and perfumey hops covering all the inside of my mouth. Complex bodied. mmmmm...delicious.

A huge thanks to Hogtown Harry and Blankboy for sharing these rare and expensive treats.  Shared with them and GregClow and Jerc.  Dark murky yellow, frothy white head which lead to great lacing - nice.  Soft yeast aroma, slightly floral, subtle and understated, but really nice as well. Really unique taste - soft malt, yeast, and a very unique hop(s) - very dry.  This all gives way to some citrus.  Very interesting.  This is probably as flavourful as a Belgian blonde can get.  I really enjoyed this one and its understated excellence.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 2008-03-02. Hazy pastel gold amber body with a modest creamy white head that fades leaving lovely lacing on teh glass. Sweet male malt at first, bitter hops take over and linger long into the finish. (7+) Mild aroma, sweet yeasty notes, very mild floral. Smooth average palate, pleasantly carbonated. (3+) 7/4/7/3+/16-17 - 3.9Bottle at In De Vrede Cafe, Westvleteren

December 2005. Golden yellow with a decent sized creamy white head that fades slightly. Sweetish, triple like aroma with floral herbal hops over top, and touch of yeast. Fairly complex aroma. Flavour has a sweet foundation, but it is eclipsed by dry hoppy moderate bitterness. Medium palate (3+) Dry lingering aftertaste. Intriguing, but not something I would drink often. 8/4/7/4/15 - 3.8 Tasting at HogTownHarrys

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 Bottle (2x330ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc, tupalev - two bottles courtesy of myself and blankboy.  Poured slightly hazy bronze with a huge lasting white foamy head with sticky lacing, fair amount of sediment at bottom of the bottle.  Plenty of ashy-herbal-spicy bitter sharpness in the aroma (hey - actual hops?), gentle caramel malt emerges, plenty of yeastiness, smells stronger than 5.8% abv - very complex blond.  Taste isnt quite as balanced - a little bitter-harsh and a touch sour - still very nice, but the spice doesnt follow through as much.  Mouthfeel quite bitter, lively and dry - overall a terrific blond, but the 8 and 12 are hands and fists above it.  Recommended.

The Green Cap is a bit hoppy and bitter for my taste; could it have been inspired by their brethern at Orval? Either way, the Green is a characterful beer whic even a hopophobe such as myself can enjoy.

Bottled.
Cloudy yellow coloured with a medium sized lacing white head.
Sweet candylike fruity aroma with notes of grapefruit, pine needles, hops and spices.
Fruity flavour of grapefruit and pine needles with notes of hops and spices.

Bottled. Hazy pale apricotty orange/yellow colour with huge, longlasting foamish bubbly head, lacing. Spices, herbs, yeast and wheat in aroma. Also some hints of fruits and flowers. Flavour of herbs, fruit with flowery hoppish hints. Some wheat, caramel and grassyness in flavour too. A bit "soapish" at some point too. Sweetish bitter aftertaste at first, which then turns into smooth hops, and lasts long. Very well done brew! Rich carbonation, but not disturbing, makes palate quite pleasant.
Blond colour, rather small, diminishing head. Some yeast in the aroma, herby taste, licht bitter and sweet finishing touch.
It is yeasty and unfuiltered, the color is light. Tastes like a wheat beer, neither sour or sweet. Aftertaste of yeast on the tongue.

Hazy yellow colour. Big long lasting head. Aroma of hops, yeast and spices. Dry and smooth malty flavor and also in the background spices and floral hops. 
Finish off with a nice bitterness. A very easy drinking beer.

Lightly cloudy dark straw colored brew with a moderate white head. Light fruit and mint in the aroma. In interesting aroma that pull you back. Dry, yet firm malt flavors abound mixing with a hops, spice and herb backdrop. Heather and golden rod, mix with mint and saffron. A belgian pils that goes beyond the ordinary. Crisp for an ale. A brew I have been longing to try for some time, and glad to say I was not disappointed. Thanks to ImtheOptimator and jjpm74 for the samples. Greatly appreciated.

From the bottle this pours a clear golden color with a tall white head, but as you get near the bottom you get some more particles. This was a really nice beer all around, i wasnt so fond of it as we started, a kinda funky earthy note clashed with the fruitiness of the ale, but the more i drank the more they worked together. Well hopped and balanced out perfectly with just a light spicing in the finish.
33 cl bottle. Yeast in bottom. Some unclear golden colour with a nice head. Very hoppy aroma of flower. A very hoppy Belgium ale both in flavour and in finish.

Welcome #300!  Couldnt bring myself to open the 12, Ill wait till the next milestone.  Pours a light hazy orange with just a bit of carbonation and a huge foamy white head.  The aroma is candy sugar, Belgian yeast, spices (like pepper and cardamom) and a light sweetness.  Nice.  The flavor was spicy (did not take a guess as to which ones) and stereotypically Belgian.  Green pepper in there, a bit of soap.  Smooth medium body.  I really did not care for this.  I drank it slowly to note flavor changes as it warmed but I just found this unenjoyable.  Maybe beer 400 will be better.
Golden beer with white foam. Aroma is medium dry and fruity flowery and fresh hoppy. The taste is dry, fresh, blond malty and refreshing hoppy. The finale is dry, fruity and slight bitter.

11.2 oz bottle.  Poured a hazy orange with a finger sized fluffy white head.  Ive havent seen a head like this on a low ABV beer in a long time, VERY creamy after sitting for a minute or two.  Aroma is very enticing, as I can smell it from about two feet away.  Fruity esters, floral hops, spices, slightly yeasty, grassy meadows, and a touch of malt.  Flavor is citrusy and lightly malty, very well balanced in bitterness as well.  Soft and somewhat thin on the palate.  Leaves a soft fruity finish with just enough bitterness to keep you wanting another sip.  I see why the monks drink this as their everyday beer, if I had access Id drink alot more of this.  A definate classic example of the style.

Exciting beading going on in my glass...now THATS what Im talkin about!  Sweet fruity/yeasty/honey flavors all well balanced with a sweet malt base.  Sweet, but not cloying in any way.  Mild hop bitterness in the clean, crisp finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2006 Something to look at, a slightly hazy yellow with intense beading and a dense, creamy white head.  The aroma is a sweet light malt with pomes and cherries and a strong yeasty undertone.  Very soft in the mouth, but the lively carbonation is quite evident.  The flavor is a light, candy sweet malt blended with apples and pears, yeast and gentle hop bitterness.  The finish is pretty clean, leaving a hint of a honey, fruity sweetness on the tongue.  This is a very, very good beer, but not an excellent one.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Shop, Verviers, Belgium<font size=-1>

Aroma: candy, pear and sharp apples. Appearance: cloudy orange, large fluffuly head with great lacing. Flavour: pear sharp hops, light malt. Palate: thin well carbonated lingering bitterness. Great stuff!

If this were anything but a Westvleteren the reviews would be higher, since it is an amazing beer by anyone elses standards.  Beautiful huge head of foam on a cloudy yellow body ... my classic lemon meringue pie look for a Belgian blond.  Good mouth, good balance, bready yeasty malty citrus, with a long finish of lemon and bitter hops.  Great.  And its less than 6% alcohol; that much flavor in a relatively low alcohol Belgian deserves a bonus point.

Tasted at the In De Vrede cafe over the road from the brewery. Presented in a Westvleteren challis, hazy straw yellow with plenty of bright white compact head perfectly filling the challis. Aroma is of honey and feint cloves, with the very slightest hint of flowery hops - subtle and nicely balanced. Taste is so well balanced it is hard to pick out individual flavours, maybe some orange peel over the malt background, with a little light clove spiciness. Finish is nicely balanced with crisp refreshing bitterness from the hops, but beyond that there is no hops flavour dominance noticeable. Mouth was light and fluffy, but not watery. Complemented the flavours nicely. Very drinkable on a hot day (which it was when I visited). A pity I was limited to only one as I had to drive back to Paris. Looking forward to trying the 8 and 12s I have brought home.

This has got to be the best blonde ale that Ive had, nice hazy amber colour, lasting head with a taste that I cant quite put my finger on? Hoppy and fragrant without any bitterness,this seems a great way to begin tasting Westvleteren....the only trouble is getting hold of an 8 and a 12!!

A Mes rate: 
Blondes are not my thing really but as they go this is as good as I have had. Full fruity hoppy great palate. Head lasts well. Just great all round really.

Thanks to Kevin who got the bottle from Duane. Thanks a lot to both of them. Poured a hazy gold. The aroma is certainly Westy with some fresh grass, pears and light flowers. There is also a very subtle citrus hint. The taste is bready and sweet with some spicy clove. There is also some subtle Red Delicious Apple. Nicely done.

Grassy, hoppy aroma with a little fruitiness. The taste is very similar, thpough slightly sweet and very drinkable. Need to get some more, one of the best blondes iv had, though grassy top an exsteme level.

8 June 2005 - Luscious fruit hops.  Cloudy golden-orange colour, great lacing and good head.  Light malt with complex hop flavour.  Crisp finish with lingering fruit hops. Overall - Very good for a blond beer.

bottle-pours pale yellow with vigerous carbonation.  light funk, spicy, twangy hop notes that is reminiscent of a decent pils.  Flavors have belgian yeast character, nice sweetness, but an underlying hop presence like a german pils.  I would imagine the hop character is much more aggressive here if this beer were more fresh.  Long dry finish from the yeast character and the aggressive carbonation.

bottle recently brought back from Belgium by some friends.  an appropriate name as it is definitely blond un the pour.  a big white fluffy head takes awhile to settle down to lace.  reminds me of a german wheat beer but with more carbonation and yeast notes.  not as complex as the other Westvleteren brews but as it warms, more flavors become apparent.  solid and well made but too much fizz for me.
Hazy gold w/ a little white head. Smells a little like sour apples. Spicy flavors. Lots of depth in the flavor. Light dry palate. Seems lighter than 5.8%. More bitter finish than I expected.

Shared a bottle with Humulone Red...thanks!!  It is gold with a slight haze.  It has a georgeous white head.  The aroma is spicy, peppery, grassy, and has some green pepper.  The flavor is pretty bitter!  It will surprise you but it is delicious in combination with a slight tartness, some leather, earthy and some funk.  Amazing beer.

Bottle - Pours blonde with a huge white sudsy head that laces quite well.   Aroma is some hops, yeast, and a touch of lemon.  Flavor is quite yeasty as well with notes of spice/pepper.  Some citrus notes in the flavor as well..  A little orange and some lemon.  Many different things come through and make this a complex beer for its color.  The mouthfeel is great on this one.  Just perfect carbonation and a wonderful dry finish.  Not bad.. I look forward to the other 2 Westys in my basement now.

(Bottle 33 cl) Its rare but it does happen: a new Trappist beer. Pale golden with a huge head. Quite lightbodied with a very, very pronounced bitterness throughout. Fruity and fresh but also a bit sharp. Rather unusual trappist - perhaps Orval is the closest relative. But this lacks that beers refined spicyness. 220501

Bottle, puirchased at the abbey and packed back to SD!  Pours cloudy whitish gold color with some noticible particulates and a creamy white head.  Yeasty, bready, citrus aroma with lemon and spice, tangerine, white pepper and herby hops.  Light and complex flavor, yeast and lemon, more white pepper and spicy hops.  Smooth and medium body, creamy carbonation.

Courtesy of Wohlfs. Pours blond with white head. Lots of citrus and spice/pepper in the aroma. Flavor very skunky with a harsh metallic tatse to it. Very harsh aftertaste. Dissapointed to say the least.
Pours hazy yellow, big white head.  Spicy aroma, somehwat floral. Taste is spiced malt, sharp hops. Good body which leaves nice lacing. Great balance. Great beer, high price.

Well I have worked my way "down" the Westy ladder and enjoyed the trip! While not as good as the 8 or 12, you can still tell that this beer is crafted with skill and care. Hazy golden yellow with a super thick white head that lasts a long time. Thick sheets of lacing. Aroma of citrus and floral hops. Medium-bodied and dry with spicy hops and citrus flavoring. Wonderful balance throughout. The finish is lightly bitter with yeast and spice flavors. Id love to have any of the Westy brews again but considering the hefty price tag Ill probably stick with the 12 from here on out.

hazy blonde, lacey white head.  yeasty, biscuitymalt, mild apple and ropical fruit aroma.  flavour had more tripoical fruit, pepper, pear, fresh doughy malt.  lingering spicy bitterness.  thanks jan primus

Complex taste.  Starts sweet then ends with a medium bitterness.  On the way it has a very complex array of taste notes that dance around.
Available at Belgium Shop in Brussels.

Slightly murky golden hue with immense creamy head and silky lacing. Spice (coriander/citrus) and malt aroma with notes of tobacco and leather. I also get hints of black pepper and fresh green chilies . Hoppy grapefruit bitterness that is not overwhelming but balances the flavor and  fades into a nice  malt and spice background. This bottle is from Belgium Shop and seems to be young. It is a great beer now and I only see it getting better.

Bottle:  Courtesy of wolhfs.  Lemony and yeasty aroma that is also lightly spicey.  Pours a cloudy dull yellow with a small white head.  Lighlty yeasty and light lemon with a moderate hop and spice finish.  A nice beer, but nothing great.

hazy blonde with white head.  Aroma is of coriander, yeast, spice and slightly citrus.  High carbonation, bitter start, grapefruit bitterness.  Bitter citrus, some coriander, easy drinking and different.

Pours hazy light honey with a big white soapy head. Aroma of yeast, sweet bread dough and apple. Slight passionfruit-like tart. Definite tropical fruit notes. Very clean tasting despite all the residue at the bottles bottom. Very balanced with hops being more assertive than expected. Mostly soft fruits and a dry acidity make up the bulk of the flavour. Some light toasted nut and biscuit. Not overly complex but well constructed.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2007 At In De Vrede cafe.  Sweet apricot and apple aroma.  Cloudy medium yellow color with small head.  A complex flavor - taste peach, apple, plum, and malt with moderate acidity.  A great beer and worth the effort finding the abbey.

Bottle, thanks to my brother ChazyRPH...Creamy, milky aroma with hints of citrus and bananas.  Slightly peppery.  Aroma is pretty faint, though.  Hazy blonde color with a nice long-lasting white head.  Crisp, clean milky flavor with a nice pepperiness in the middle.  Very very smooth finish.  Incense and smoke appear in the finish.  This is very interesting and very drinkable.  Well-crafted beer.
It is surprisingly refreshing for this kind of beer, rather mild. Well rounded. Just bitter enough, not too yeasty. Fruity.

Thanks to Jan Primus for this bottle. Pale gold in color, slight haze, incredibly retentive snow white head. Delicate, yet firm flavors. Nice complexity, malty, yeasty with some welcome bitterness. Grassy, fruity, very mild spice. Creamy texture although having a smaller body. Some love went into making this beer. Excellent.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2005  Bottle at In de Vrede, Westvleteren.  One of my favourite beers in the world. Hazy golden blond colour, with tight white head.  Hoppy citric creamy nose with yeastiness.  Fullish in mouth iwth tart drying lemony citrus finish. Refreshing and wonderful. Had to re-rate again. Excellent yeasty/hoppy/citrus nose  with grapefruit. Cant express what a good blond this is

Huge thanks to IPFreely for sharing this.  Aroma of lemon candy, hops, grapes, funk, grass.  Flavor has lemon, wheat, grassy and bitter.  Some saison qualities.  This would be great with a well peppered roast beef.  Mmm.

No label -green cap.  Hazy golden pour, with a huge dose of yeast in the nose.  Alochol is present throughout, as are subtle grapefruit   and lemon parts.  The predominant characteristic is hay (not fresh grass, but dry hay).  Still - the craftsmanship is there - with each sip revelaling a little more.  The cobwebs and must of the revered yellow-capped 12 are evident as well.  Thanks Aracauna!

Bright blond with a little bit of yeast haze.  Very foamy white head.  Pilsner malt and grassy hops in the nose with a slight touch of tart yeast.  Very smooth, pleasing flavors.  Lots of  almost sour, earthy pilsner malt flavors.  Yeasty finish with a touch of grassy hops.  Great Belgian session beer.
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2007 little head, mild floral aroma.  light bodied, golden color.  slight bitter aftertaste.  very different from 10 and 12.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2009 Pours gold an clear with a brilliant white head.  Smells of dry malt, a touch of lingering wild yeast, some pepper, some perfume.  Tastes dry with a nice bitter hint, lots of spicy hints, touches of salt.  Mouthfeel is full.  Finish is peppery.

A cloudy yellow appearance with a large fluffy head. Did I just say fluffy? The aroma is floral and mainly lemons. The flavor is lemony with some vanilla, and hay. A semi sour flavor and a little funky in a good way. Overall its not complex but still "goodly" made.

pours cloudy light gold with a fat white head. aroma is sour hay with some dark fruit. taste reminds me of a pilsner somehow. oatey notes with a strong almost astringent bitter. some corriander is in here also, but the field flavors are dominant, lots of hay and whatnot. this improves greatly as it warms.
Bottle. Dark straw with a foamy head. Taste has alot of straw, earthm and cardboard. Really, this is nothing special. This is how I would imagine an Imperial Pilsner would taste.

Golden yellow color with a thick and creamy head, the nose is one of hoppy perfume, herbaceous and floral, with a citrus fruity aroma follows by a citric fruity flavors of grapefruit and lemon, who take us to the dryness of his bitterness finish

Bottle.  Very light blonde in color.  Decent white head with good lacing.  Aroma is a touch funky, perhaps uric/ammonia.  Cap date is 24-9-05 so this is still "fresh". Flavors are spicey, yeasty.  Somewhat drying.  Light bodied.  Well carbonated. Suprisingly bitter in the finish.   Decent beer.

Bottle thanks to wohlfs, hazy yellow color, nice white head with excellent lacing, aroma of yeast, taste of citrus and hint of flowers which leaves a little bitterness at the end.  A fairly good brew.
