UPDATED: JUN 7, 2005 The green cap on my bottle has an exp. date in August 2004. (I bought the bottle myself at the brewery a few years ago... My bluecacps (8) still has promissing exp. dates :-)
The beer has lost it´s haziness and a lot of it´s taste too. You can still smell and taste the flowery notes but it doesn´t seem to be a good idea to store this one too long. 
Rating stats are based on previous tastings.
Hazy yellow colour with a thick white sparkling head. Fresh clear hoppy flavour. Full rounded body. Sweet and fruity. Hints of yeast with a bitter aftertaste. I might even move to Belgium!!
Bottled.  Pours a very clear pale golden color.  Yeasty nose with some banana and grass.  Light malty flavor with a somewhat lingering sweet finish.
Dark golden in colour. A very clean/crisp tasting beer with a slightly bitter finish. Nothing about it was overpowering. A well balanced beer.  -Green bottle cap.
Hazy yellow with bit white head. Hints of citrus in the aroma. Feels soft in the mouth and has a nice bitter/dry aftertaste. A want again beer.
Sometimes hard to get, even in Belgium. In 2004 they just stop brewing it for almost a year. Superb blond ale, fresh taste.

No label, just the green cap says it all. A unique and masterly crafted beer. Yeast and malt that is consistent in a medium grainy but smooth mouthfeel. If only I could have this all night. Very fresh

Poured nice golden yellow with a dense white head...smell is ultimately unimpressive...yeast, hay, grain, hints of cirtrus and some clove...taste is sweet malts with a nice doughy quality turning a touch bitter toward the finish...very good but seems a little overrated...

A wonderful beer to begin the daybeautiful big pillowy head with nice gas release.noste of jasmine flower and grassy hop scombine with a slightly honeyed and dry malt character. Had thisoriginally at the cafe "in de vrede" across from the monastery. My first ever religious experience.
Very light looking Belgian beer with a light fermented fruity aroma and a relatively dry flavour that is fairly strong and sustained in its finish.  Overall quite a disappointing beer.

Cloudy orange beer with a large head. Aromas of citrus, yeast and spices. Flavours of bitter dry hops are noted too. The aftertaste gives a hoppy bitterness that keeps on going. The fathers know how to brew big stuff. Somewhat discouraging how they handle there distribution strategie...

(no label,cap read 24-09-05)thanks to enniskillen for giving me this brew.the blond poured a SUPER MURKY  yellow that let no light through.id say this is the first "yellow" beer i have ever seen that didnt let any light through.the head was very thick as well.like a marshmellow sittinge on top of a bail of dried out hay.as the head simmered it coated the trappist glass so thick you could not see the other side.the aroma gave me straw,yeast,some faint malts,and caramel.the first sip was very well balanced with a nice but smooth mouthfeel.its alot like a tripel,but without the carbonated bite and lemon bitterness.its a balance of a bit of lemon,some yeast,the mouthfeel is still very thick,but still soothing.this is the best representation of this style.
Hazy, golden colour. Massive, thick head. Yeasty, fruity citrus-aroma. An elegant beer with a long, really long grapefruity pine- needle bitterness. Great stuff!

Café de Vrede, Light hazy shine in this great gold-blond beer. good white foam and dry malty accent in the nose, also touches of fresh fruits and vegetal bitterness. Taste is not so dry as i expected but it hes a refreshing caracter. some citrus in the taste, dry malts sugars and hoppy bitterness.
Consumed at In de Vrede in Westvleteren. This cloudy yellow ale pours with a generous white head. Crisp carbonated hoppy flavor with a spicy finish.

Rich yet subtle yeasty-citrusy nose, outstanding smoothness and a most satisfying fulness that ends on hoppy happiness. A stunning golden ale. The Westvleteren range, limited though it is, is probably the only one I could imagine imbibing in the morning -- their beers go down that well. Theres an unmistakable healthy character to all three Ws as well, and these are rares cases of beers that really are all theyre made out to be. Hail!

Pours bright yet hazy yellow in colour with a big, foamy head and loads of sediment. Taste is surprisingly simple and refreshing. Nice tart, crisp and mildly citric taste...this would be my session beer if I lived near the abbey, and, unlike most beer its great with food.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2005 Pours a hazy "electric" yellow color, some sediment on the bottom, and a small but lingering white head on top. Aroma is bannanas and spices. Flavor is very tart, banannas, cloves and other spices round out the flavor of this one.

Cloudy yellow/orange with a large head of foam.  Aromas are citrus fruit, yeast, spices, peppery, fresh hops - good.  Flavours are grain with bags of floral, bitter, dry hops.  Grassy and aromatic in its hopping.  Has a grapefruit pith bitterness on the finish that lasts....and lasts.  Its a simple beer made very well.  Incredibly addictive.

Yellow/light orange color, thick head with millions of small bubbles in it. Peppery, fruity and yeasty aroma. Spicy, dry and somehow metallic flavor with a crisp bite. Dry, long lasting finish. Medium bodied. Although Im not a big fan of Blonds (as far as beer is concerned) I was expecting more from this. Slightly disappointing after 8 & 12.
Cloudy orange colour with small white head. Aroma has a slight maltyness and a nice fresh fruity hoppyness. Flavor has a slight sweetness with a bitter finish.

Pours effervescent and golden with a fizzy off-white head.  Smells of a belgian wit - pear, grapes, and spices.  Taste is of white grapes with a hint of spice.  Very dry, with a long bitter finish.  Refreshing.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 Light yellow cloudy color, big white lasting head. Spicy, peppery aroma, some citrus comes up too with mild yeast, nice aroma. Medium to full bodied. Strong flavor:starts with spices and fruity tones, ends with strong dryness, bitterness, pepper, hops and yeast. Excellent bite in the end coming also from carbonation. Lasting aftertaste, yeast dominates it with hops too. Excellent blonde!

UPDATED: APR 8, 2005 From A Bottle.Pale murky yellow in colour,I like how the sediment hangs in the middle like the inside of a glass marble,small head,aroma of spicy lemon,taste is of citrus and hops with a nice bitterness.
light hazy golden beer with whith foam. citrussy smell with hints of malt and hops. Full taste fruity accent a graet bitterness.

Hazy gold with long lasting white head. Nice lace too. Spicy aroma with citrus(lemon) and dougy. Mild brown sugar smell there too. Sweet honey dominates the start with a long spicy dry finish. Medium refreshing feel. Great session beer.
Bottle. Slightly cloudy, yellow colour. Citrus aroma. Quite good bitterness from start to finish. Aromatic hoppy aftertaste. Reminds me more of an English than a Belgian ale.

Very nice and original blonde! After tasting their "12" and "8", I was wondering how good they would be at making a blonde. I was not disappointed. It hasnt got much head but it leaves a nice lacing on the glass. The body is bright yellow. The flavour is complex : malty, yeasty, with hints of spices and even flowers. It has along finish, the tastes survives pretty long on the tongue. Excellent beer, too bad its so rare.

Bottle at Dulle Griet, Ghent. Extremely delicious Blond Ale - the best of the night! A perfect combination of fruit and sparkle, smoothness and hoppy bitter crunch. Slightly tangy aroma. Bright yellow beer, with a smooth, swampy (small) head and Belgian lacing. Superb stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 Cloudy blonde color with yeast in suspension, thin white head. Seductive aroma of earthy yeast, barnyard and spices. Mild flavor of hops with an amazing flavor of earthy yeast, barnyard and spices, bitter finish. Full body, slightly creamy texture, soft carbonation. Wow, this stuff is absolutely amazing, it has an assertive yeast character but remains easily drinkable.

Bottle Conditioned at The Waagstuck, Antwerpen. Sl hazed Orange with big white head. Sharp zesty citric flavours with a spicy undernote. Faultless really for the style, its just that these blondes seem to leave the flavour a little short. Bitter hopping and a long finish.

Light yellow, hazy, beautyful rocky head. Smells like very much Duvel - maybe a bit sulphuric. Excellent carbonation and light but good mouthfeel. Very, very dry, with a bitter finish. Reminds me of a lightly hopped Duvel. Refreshing, bot my favourite beer style.

Lovely pale orange hue, cloudy, resting under a thick, tapioca-ish, creamy crown of foam...angelic aroma, a zesty, spicy, but still mellow blend, soft and slightly citric, bits of lemon rind and ginger flit about...good stuff.
Sweetness on the tongue, too, rich and creamy mouthfeel, wondrous texture, really fills the mouth, and stays long on the palate. Light bodied, exquisite drinkability, a beer any good monk (and Im tryin to be one, lord, I am!) should surely deserve to luxuriate with throughout the remainder of a well-won day.
Probably the finest session ale ever brewed...no stretch here!
A superb little beer, absolutely delightful!
Hazy golden color, light fruity aroma and bitter taste, full body, heavy dry bitter finish.

Surprisingly strong, perfume-like, floral hop nose with underlying doughy yeast aroma. Opaque, deep blonde with a finger of white, fine-bubbled head that recedes slowly. Citrus-lemon notes, cookie dough and big sweet malt flavours with a fair bitterness and plenty of spices in the finish. Soft mouth and fine-bubbled carbonation with a crisp bitterness. The monks working beer certainly gives pause for reflection. Bottle enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere at The Moan and Dove (Amherst, Massachusetts).
An awesome beer that you can easily tell is from the people that make 12. Dry, yet malty sweet with some floral hop bite to it. Smooth but just a tad sweet.

Bottle at the Moan and Dove. Nice pour. Its a mysterious cloudy golden, obviously bottle-conditioned. The nice lasting 1cm cover of moon white head makes the westmalle chalice looks particularly attractive. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy, Im first striked by a wave of floral goodness complemented by grassy undertones. Definite champaign qualities despite the big malty sweet components. Candi sugar is not used with moderation for a 6% ale, malt is honeyish, pilsner malt? and imparts coconut and bready aromas. Very yeasty palate all around, dry all the way. Spicy (pepper, mint, sage). Delicately flowery. Balancing mild tartness, mostly on the citric lemon side, salty finished with very restrained bitterness. Youre welcomed in my glass anywhen my dear. A good dose of various herbs is always a pleasure to taste as long as its more of a complement than the unique focus. No alcohol is noticeable in there. Thats their session beer? It just made a monk out of me.

Poured a hazy golden color with a medium white head, very nice.  Lightly hopped, yeast, fruity aroma.  Citrusy, hoppy, lightly bitter.  Fruity mild tripelish qualities.    Light alcohol and nicely carbonated.

Sampled at Beer Mania in Brussels, Belgium.

Golden.

Commanding and focused aroma. Quite floral and sweet, with honey, lemon, herbs and banana.

Enormous for its size and full of flavor. Dry malt, very pale, with a unique fruitiness of banana, lemon and clove accompanied by various spices, candy sugar and bready yeast. 

Lovely, but this replaced the red cap? Why?

The Blond is a very fresh and light beer (not light like piss-beers), but with a fresh aroma woth hints of herbs, apple and "hyldeblomst". It has a light and hazy body with a very white head. It tasts very much og yeast with a bitter finish. It is a good beer, but a little borring for my taste. The expirience is not multi dimentional as it should be.

Poured a light hazy yellow with an averaged sized white head. Fruity, apple, spicey and yeasty aromas and tastes. Lively carbonation. Definitely out of league with the 8 & 12 but as a blond, stands OK on its own.

Bottle from Onlyfine beer. Poured a hazy straw colour with a good sized white, bubbly head. Aroma is hops and coriander with fruity esters. Taste is hoppy, wheaty and citrusy with a spicey slightly bitter finish. Very refreshing and thirst quenching. Fairly highly carbonated with a foamy mouthfeel, quite watery palate wise. Pretty good.
Sampled in a beer tasting at Plan B, Copenhagen. Extremely full palate and an impressively dry bitter finish. Excellent complexity and balance.

Euro size bottle with freshness date of 12/11/04.
This beer pours a straw color with some chill haze and plentiful carbonation rolling up from the bottom; the head is bright white with fair retention and slippery lace.  Aroma is of fruity esters (citrus) and malt, with a crisp fresh aroma hop background. Flavor has a sharp hoppy start a tart middle and a biting hop finish.  Mouthfeel is effervescent and crisp.
IMHO:  Not well balanced ? not what I expected.

Bottle date coded 17 10 03: Popped the top and it overflowed. Poured a hazy pale peach color with a generous white fluffy head. Wheaty apple aroma. Flavor starts tangy and fruity with a touch of lemon. Finish is dry with a light citrus tartness.  Very nice.

on draft in de verde westvleteren across from abbey:
looks just heavenly in the silver rimmed westy glass.  huge rocky snow white head with a  yellow hazey nectar below. nose of crisp apples and belgium hops, slight vanilla bean and spice.  on the palate earthy hop flavor dominates with wood and citrus notes. lots of tingly bubbles. the crunchiness of the hops gives a nice bitter side that lingers into a suttle sweet wheat honey flavor.  This is like no blonde i have ever had. crisp refreshing although not as complex as the others still has lots of depth.  rather different for a belgian beer more hop character then usual. much better then the rates suggest. after drinking about 150+ belgian beers this one stands out....simply divine.

Thanks to my buddy out in CA, Snoot, for sending me this brew! Snoot is top-notch dude.. I tell you.. it's TRUE! 

Pours a pale golden blond body with a chunky white three finger head! The is brew is damn floral! Nice spicy note of black peppercorn, clove, note of coriander, and a dash of rosemary! The flavor brings a sweet and beady taste. I note banana, orange zests, all the spices that I mentioned above.. along with some cardamom. There is a spicy tartness along with biscuit and doughy-ness.. accompanying a large dry musty citric flavor.. all found in the finish.  Pretty damn tasty!

Hazy flaxen with a frothy head and sheet lacing. Wheaty and musky malt aromas. Lemon citrus. Bitter and sour notes. Hints of bread and some spice. Citrus in the flavors. Good malt backing. Yeasty. bitter orange and lemons. Musky and spicy. Slighty dry palate, musky. Finishes spicy.

Clear yellow color with a light film of head & lacing. The aroma is malty, notes of wheat & citurs, bready. Flavor is complex with lots of belgian yeast & malts. Good balance too. This is a damn good session belgian, borderline saison.

Aroma is very yeasty, farily hoppy, fruity, some elderflower and apple notes. This beer pours cloudy orange to yellow with a medium off-white fluffy head. The flavor is quite hoppy and leaves a good bitterness, although its not as distinct as the aroma. Very good balanced, i would almost call this beer and Belgian IPA.

Very grain wheat aroma, light on the hops. Nori. Pale yellow clear with white foamy lacing head. Silky watery body with light carbonation. Starts with light sweet malt, mild hops. A decent blond ale. Not that impressive compared to 8 or 12. Light after.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2012 Bottled.  My first ever Westvleteren beer in spite of sampling over 4000 beers over the years.  The beer is very blonde with a nice haze and a big clean white head and a little brown patch from the yeast being poured in.  The smell is spicy and lemony but thinner than expected.  The taste too is spicy in a subtle way with nothing over bearing or scary for non-conossieurs.  This is a beautifully brewed beer and is of course quite weak for a Belgian beer so although it doesnt have as full a character as I would have liked, it certainly sets out to do what the monks no doubt intended which is for it to be a refreshing quenching quality brew.  Score 3.8Subsequent rating scored 3.2. Average becomes 3.5

Great gold-blond beer with a light hazy shine and a creamy foamy head. It has a fine and refreshing smell,with notes of light malts,citrus,yeast and hops.The taste is dry and refreshing, it is light to medium boddied and it end in a nobel bitterness of fine dry hops. I had yesterday in Westvleteren ( café de vrede ) It was a young brew.Leave it for a month or 3, the taste and smell  will become rounder and more elegant

Thanks to Aracauna for this trade!!
This pours a cloudy dark lemon color with a rich frothy head. Nice Belgian lace in the glass. Mellow malt aroma.
Dry palate, very distant sweetness, subtle complex spice with the only bitterness coming in the finish. Interesting, but somewhat over rated IMO.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2007 Bottled.
Apricot colour. Fine, white and longlasting head.
Fruity aroma from elder and citrus.
Surprisingly thin with only some bitterness.
Apricot color, lasting offwhite head. Aroma is fruity and herbal. Flavor is herbal and grassy but also spicy ina kinda unpleasant way. Not even close to the other Westvleterens.

BEER #499. Served in a Chalice. Cap marked 17th October 2003, which means its more than 6 months past its best before date. I would guess that the 8 or 12 would benefit from some ageing, but this probably shouldnt be aged. It would be a fair assumption that they only put about a year on the blonde bottles anyway, so this did not appear to suffer. Moving on to the beer itself, it pours cloudy yellow, with a small, fluffy white head, sediment is fine. Light aroma, slight alcohol, slightly spicy. First taste is light bodied, yet it rich and complex. Despite its light refreshing character, it never feels watery. Subdued sweetness, slightly dry, spicy and ever so slightly vinous. Aftertaste is light and refreshingly bitter. An incredibly good blonde that manages to live up to the Westvleteren name without the richness of the abt 12.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2005  Bottled. Rerate. 
Grassy, flowery nose, big creamy head. Smooth mouthfeel, notes of grass and herbs. Very dry finish. 
 Previous rating 5/3/5/2/10. Was it the age? Weird! 
Best by date on the cap says 25.01.06. This ought to mean that its still all too young to be consumed. At least from where Im standing, I found it a bit too yeasty and it had this peppery, sulphury sharpness. All in all blaha-blaha...

Hazy golden hue with initial fuffy head which fades and leaves a good lacing. The araoma has notes of barnyard and dusty yeast, herbal and aormatic hops, pear and crab apple, lightly toasted pale malts. The taste is balanced betweeen the malt and yeast with a grassy bitter and lemony twang added in. A hint of spice and wheat on the finish, The mouthfeel is lively and very dry, not much going on here however. A good beer as far as blond ales go... but rather boring in the end, not refreshing on the palate.

Pours a cloudy bright orange color that leaves a small off-white head.  Lacing is minimial.  Aroma is a light sweetness with some spicy yeast notes.  Flavor is "fresh" tasting, like springtime, whatever that means.  Very good bitter bite on the swallow.  Nice sweetness with a excellent yeast notes.  Body is medium and lively in the mouth.  I think a little more sour notes would improve this beer but it is still a work of brewing art.  I could drink this one very often.

Body is clear yellow with a foamy head. Aroma is somewhat cheesy with tones of yeast and fruit. Quite sweet and full. Flavor is dominated by Westvleteren yeast and fruit and is a typical blonde. Fresh but too light and a little dissapointing compared to the other beers from Westvleteren!

Bottled.  When purchasing the Westys for the boys down under I took the liberty of buying my own stash for tasting with the correct glassware and the capacity to enjoy it. Not saying that Sully and Pogo were lashed on the night, quite the opposite, but whether we admit it or not, we were pushing the rating along quite a bit on the night. Golden Belgian style ale with a large fluffy white head, settling down to something more modest. Sour, dry aroma with some sweet malts deep down in the aroma. Sufficiently complex to keep you coming back for more.

Bottle: Poured a beautiful lightly hazy blonde with a huge bubbly head with perfect retention. Aroma is floral with some light spices in the undertone. Taste is very refreshing with the malts coming out first followed by some hard to distinguish spices followed by a sweet ending. Body is medium with great carbonation and alcohol is not detectable. Wow! This is one great light Belgian ale. Too bad I cannot get my hand on this stuff more regularly.

after hearing duff and eczematic tell me this was better than westy 12, i was really thrilled that spiesy brought a bottle of this over. but, alas, like sully i was pretty disappointed. cloudy blond, light lemon pip aroma, salty yeast taste with mild bitterness. pretty gutless. way inferior to the abbaye des rocs altitude 6 but more on that elsewhere

I think this is going to hurt. My first tilt at a Westy and it had to be this. Great presentation in the glass, albeit not a trappist one. The head appeared to be creamy and well formed. The nose presented with a bit of understatement, what I wanted it to say is unclear but it didn't yell "I am Westy, I am great". Instead it sat there with a degree of Belgian indifference. Come the taste test, bugger. This was thin and largely uninspiring. Even though it had made the long journey to Australia it was via Spiesy's carry on luggage so it should not have been too upset by the journey.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: The Wharf, Aalborg. Golden colour, nice head. Grass, malt, some acidity, pleasent bitterness, dry. Very nice.

Obviously much less complex than the more powerful Westy 8 or 12. Golden body, medium carbonation; soft, medium white head, mostly lasting. Very refreshing aroma (herbal, citrus, spices, straw). Taste is clean, malty and with a sweet orange  touch, with a hoppy and almost bitter finish. Balanced and tasty. The only problem with this beer is its price, and that's why I think I'll stick to Orval.

Bottled @ Helsinki Beer Festival 2004Orange and light brown in color, thick near-white head. Fruity, spicy (pepper), sweet and smooth nose. Medium to full body, smooth. Flavor is fruity, a bit sweet, spicy, a bit peppery and there is also notes of yeast. Nice trappist.

A very unusual Trappist beer that replaced another unusual beer, Westy 6.  All that is history though, and blonde is the present.  As I don’t really like Blonde beers, finding them rather plain and boring, I wasn’t really looking forwards to this one – until I poured it.  Immediately the strong smack of lemony hops came out of the glass and I knew this wasn’t an ordinary blonde beer.  Lovely golden colour with a bewitching hop aroma.  Excellent bitter, very bitter, and hoppy flavour balanced by maltiness and a balanced yet bitter finish.  A classic blonde beer for others to strive for.  (bottle in De Torre, De Haan an Zee)

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2005 Bottled, BB 2.11.04 (Helsinki Beer Festival 2004)
HAzy golden. Small but firm head. Aroma is malty and flowery. Taste is malts, citron and hops. Mouthfeel extremely smooth and freshing. (7/3/9/5/17 4.1)
Re-rated, bottled (BB 24.9.2005)
Hazy yellow, big creamy head, lots of lace. Aroma has lime, watermelon, horse blanket and tobacco ash. Citric flavors burst into mouth first. Citric hoppy, medium-bodied, extremely well-balanced blonde. (7/3/9/4/15 3.8)

A big frothy white head on a light goldern body.  Little haze present and numerous small bubbles.  Aroma is very nice with a yeasty presence along with flowery hopps.  Flavor is lightly sweet, well balanced and finishes somwhat bitter (grassy).  Good mouthfeel on this medium bodied beer.   Good effort Monks.

Finally I have got my hands on some Westvleteren beers and am looking forward to finding out whether they are as good as people make out.  Golden hue with a foamy white fairly large head that on my beer had a peppering of sediment from the bottle.  Strong herbal hoppy aroma with a hint of orange.  Wonderfully complex but soft and smooth taste.  Has an intense dryness and a very pleasant bitter bite in the finish.  Flavours of citrus and a hint of pear and orange.  Simpley sublime, a truely great beer.
Cloudy dark yellow color, huge frothy head.  Clove, citrus and yeast doninate the flavor.  Watery mouthfeel and a dry, bitter finish.

I believe the westvleteren monks are magicians.  Westvletern is the triple threat of beers.  it's really not fair to compare this blonde to the other two so I'll compare it other blondes instead, and guess what... it wins, big time.  i sampled a 11.2 bottle with a stamp of 25 03 02 i think.  aromas of
 awesome citrus and then a huge fading head.  beautiful cloudy golden color and great lacing throughout.  Very malty for a blonde with a delicate hop kick.  body was awesome and soft flavors of lemon and grapefruit were noticed.  the finish was strong and zesty without being to crisp.  A perfect summer blonde and truly a world's best.  Appearance was distracted by the yeast sediment, especially in a blonde, but beauty is in the eye of the "beer" holder.  i could see myself drinking this one daily and never getting tired of it, but then i wouldn't afford internet access. slainte!!!!

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2007 (Bottled, rated 12/2007) Hazy golden with a smallish, lacy and lasting head. Honey-malty and acidic aroma with grassy hops. Acidic, pale-malty and grassy-dry-hoppy flavor reminds me of La Chouffe - only with less alcohol and more hops. Earthy and much smoother with yeast. Still grassy bitterness in the finish. Almost medium-bodied, smooth-carbonated palate. A nice and balanced blonde, although a bit too acidic.
(Bottled, was 8-4-7-4-15=3.8) Hazy yellow-golden color with a large, white and fluffy, lasting head. Very lemony, yeasty and dry aroma with lavender and flowery hops, but also some caramely malt. Very bitter-hoppy, lemony and quite acidic flavor. The yeast makes it quite a bit smoother, but with the acidity remaining. Medium-bodied, dry and acidic palate with a bit foamy carbonation. A very saison-like, dry and hoppy blonde. Cant quite compete with the best ones, like Saison Dupont, though.
(Bottled, at HBF 04, was 8-4-7-4-17=4.0) Murky, blonde color, small head. Yeasty, flowery citrus aroma. Very neutral and soft flavor, although carbonated and hoppy. A very enjoyable blonde, but must taste this one again in a more suitable environment.

A hazy yellow body with big clumps of yeast floating about sits under a towering, chunky white head.  Aroma is very 'bright', with passion fruit, citrus, and coriander.  A nice lacing is left on my glass as I wait for the head to settle.  Flavor full of clove and orange, with a bit of carbonation bite.  Dry, herbal finish.  I could drink this all day, but I'd get broke really quick.

A very nice cloudy yellow color with a white head.  The aroma is sweet, fruity, and some nice hops aromas also.  A very smooth beer with lower carbonation.  It's slightly sweet with a dry finish.  Nice complex malt flavors balanced with the hops. Very drinkable and enjoyable; really good.

Awesome Belgian blond ale, straw & hazy golden color, soft & fluffy white head, banana, yeast & clove in the nose, yeasty flavors that also included banana & a hint of corriander, very smooth & very drinkable, spicy & yeasty finish, awesome blond, another great beer from Westvleteren

Have to thank Shelton Dist. for this one.  I was expecting more from this one because, I loved the 8+12.  This one falls short alittle.  Grassy, malt, and spicy flavor.  Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.

A Christmas gift from thedm and my 800th rating. This beer formed a medium sized white frothy head with fine-medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting. The body was hazy with fast rising carbonation and a pale yellow hue. The nose was malty, fruity and spicy. The flavor was sweet, some hop notes, yeasty and fruity. The mouthfeel was mostly smooth and this beer had fair lacing.

This bottled brew came direct from the Belgian Shop without a label.  It poured a large head of foamy white colored finely sized long lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lace as it receeded.  The body of the beer is a hazy yello with a pretty brown swirl of yeast in it.  This brew was poured carefull so as to not disturb the yeast.  The bottle was actually quite full of yeast sediment.  Its mouthfeel was initially smooth and tingly then finished with a slight bitterness in its mild hop bite whiled ending with a lingering malt yeast aftertaste.  THe flavor was malty yeasty doughy and had a slight orange hint to it.  It goes down very easily too.
Hazy golden/yellow color with a white head. Nice complex taste of fruits, yeast and hops.

Very cloudy golden color with a nice smooth white head. Smooth aroma, some yeast and fruit were detected. A hint of hops as well?? Malty taste. Some spice and citrus. Very complex. All around a very nice brew. Definitely worth having on a nice warm day. Bought this bottle at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA.

hazy golden color,medium sized head that lasted for some time before fading to a nice lace.Fruity yeasty aroma with a light citrus and spice.The flavor was Spicy and citrusy with a decent amount of hops a little bitter but not to bad.Fairly spicey all around.Very nice brew it's not exactly what i was thinking it might be but,it still was decent and well worth trying again,but the chances of getting another one are slim since i've been holding on to this one for awhile with little success of procuring another.Still if i had a choice the Westy 12 wins out over this brew.

Hazy, golden honey body with a large frothy white head. Nice aroma of wheat, European hops, and esters. Complex flavor of wheat, light honey, nuts, and fresh, intoxicating grassy hops. Crisp palate. Highly enjoyable.

Poured a cloudy golden color with a thick fluffy white head. Very herbal in the aroma with a touch of fruit. Flavor is spicy with herbs and hops. I drank half of this and poured the rest into the cream sauce I am making with pork chops. Hope it works.

Shimmering dark golden appearence with beautiful creamy white head. Hops, citrus, herbs and spices in aroma. Very refreshing. Floral, yeasty and citrusy flavour. Hints of spices and vanilla. Dry and spicy finish.
Cloudy straw color on the pour, large white head. Spicy, yeasty aroma. Lots of yeast and spicyness in the flavor as well, nice hop bite.
UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 Bottled: Shy aroma, juniper, candies. Hazy, light orange color. Medium bodied, intensive hopped with herbal and bitter hop notes. Quite dry with juniper notes.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2005 Pale yellow with white head.
Herbal aroma with notes of malt and hops.
Sweet flavor with notes of rocks and fresh hops.

Bottle pours a slightly hazy yellow golden color with a medium size rocky head and little lace.  The aroma is somewhat musty and floral.  The flavor is rather bitter in the finish.  I'm really not sure what it has going on in the front.  The body is light and somewhat carbonated.  Overall, it is OK.  It is quite balanced.

Pours a sort of dark, golden blonde, with a huuuge head.  Smells musty.  Not much going on for aroma or flavor, and the palate seems a bit watery.  Sorry, but it was hard for me to get excited over this one.

Fruity (peach, citrus) belgian yeast aroma 
laced with spices and a very sligt bitter note.
 Slightly hazy amber, quite a bit carbonation and a big rocky head.
Taste starts out a bit neutral, getting a bit of the sediment in helps. Notes of
Pine-needles, honey and spice.
Fairly light body and a slightly watery mouthfeel.
Spicy aftertaste.

Clear sparkling golden body topped by a very nice frothy white head. Lots and lots of lacing. Aroma is grassy and yeasty. THe malt comes through after the dominate grassy aroma. Flavor is bready and flowery. The malt comes through more on the palate then in the nose.  Quite bitter, and the bitterness lingers. Very dry on the palate. Body is medium and has a little bit of a zing to it. Quite a nice beer.

Bottle conditioned. Gold coloured, moderate rocky white head and good condition. Strangely pilsnerlike hoppy aroma with some sweet maltiness. More malt in the mouth but tempered by a perfumed hop note. Finish becomes happily hoppily bitter with a fruity yeastiness lingering. Not bad, but just not Westvleteren.

from 8/24/03: dark  yellow almost copper color with a suprising large and very thick head.    i'm not sure what to saw about the aroma,  i think i'm capible of only pulling out 3-4 flavors, and i'm sure there are at LEAST six.  Same with the flavor,  the alcohol is present as are the spice,hot, and citrus flavors.  the intresting part is that  the flavor crawls down the back of my throat and hits me much differently then most beers.

Yeast, citrus aromas. Hazy peach colour, firm white finger of foam, some large floaties, fine lace. Bready flavour at the begining, grapefruit in the middle, hearty malt too. Very dry bitterness at the finish. Medium bodied, great mouthfeel. This seems like the same yeast as Orval. Fantastic!

Aroma is excellent, yeast, fruity esters, very rich.  Appearance is golden with huge fluffy white head and tons of lacing.  Complex flavor, somewhat bitter, not fruity.  Taste of hops and yeast.  Finish is very nice and mellow, kinda fades into the sunset.  Very nice.
A hazy yellow color with LOTS of head.  Aroma of citrus and cloves.  Not a bad Belgian ... but not spectacular in any way.  Perhaps a bit more bite than most.

Slight sour smell. Nice light bubbly body. Taste of grain and slight clover. Very refreshing, a good summer beer. Very good but there are many micro wheat beers that I feel have the same qualities and are about a fifth the price. Very nice though.

Nice, nice, nice! The second sample from my BelgianShop package. The beer is a cloudy medium copper color. Wonderful "light" but hoppy flavor, uncommon in other Belgians I have tried. Yes, at 5.8% this one is on the lighter side, and that's the way I prefer it! How can I get to Belgium???

Pretty beer, medium hazy gold with pillow white head of little bubbles.  The aroma was horse sweat, no other way to describe it.  The taste was initially of light malts, but was then smacked by a dose of bittering hops and an intensely dry finish.  One of the driest beers I've had, and also surprised by the lack of flavors imparted by the high hopping rate implied by the bitter nature of the beer.  An old country apertif.

Nice amber color with a nice thin head.  smells mildly sweet and malty.  Tastes a bit sweet and fruity, but has a sharp initial mouthfeel, almost like too much carbonation or spiciness.  Still, a pretty good Belgian, but I'm a bit disappointed.  But I've still got the 12 to drink

Found this one at the grapes of mirth in colombus if anyone is interested.  DOesn't smell very impressive, more or less a standard of a good belgian beer.  COlor is a nice golden, whit some head that went away a little too quick. FLavor is good and has definate notes reflecting the aroma like fruit and some slight spicyness too.  A little too sharp in the palate i'd say, otherwise something that is damn fine, but nothing too memorable
Earthy aroma.  A light Wit looking beer.  Fresh tasting, light and excellent.  Well balanced beer with a fruity flavor and hoppy finish.  Not worth $9 though.

I am on a roll iwth beers of this style: Affligem, Val De Dieu and now Westy.  This is pretty delicate, with some spice and floral notes, but with a rather firm bitterness underneath.  I suppose however that I prefer the more generous flavor of the Val De Dieu.

I drank this one in de vrede, also took some at home. This beer is simply awesome. Perfectionised up to the little details. The appearance is a little orangy, nice perly head. The aroma is the one of an average blond beer, but the flavour is fenomenal. Initially a little bit fruity, later on more dry and hoppy. Interesting beer until the last drop.
At In de Vrede. Slightly hazy yellow, nice head that fell fairly quickly. Great spicy hop aroma. Dry, hoppy, spicy. Excellent.
Came off as a pretty standard blonde. Great head and lacing, with an alcoholic aroma. Ho-hum color. Taste is a little spicy, with some oak notes (?). Average belgian finish.

I love the fizzy smooth head characterized by westvleteren brews. nice golden color and white head...pretty lacing. I was initially struck by the hoppiness of this westy. Great all around belgian ale, but I will stick to the 8 or 12.

Perfect pillowy head, aromas of frankincense, leather, distinct bitterness -- crisp and straw/heathery. Feel is lightly creamy with a fair amount of effervescence. Finishes shockingly similar to the middle of St. Ides. Pan flavors? No. This is fantastic and brutal. The finish is velvet.  Still, this feels like less than the sum of its parts.
Big malty blond beer with a stout bittereness and complex hop character that reminds of Orval but doesn't quite reach it.

Finally, the last of the Westies is complete. I've had all three Rochies and all three of these, and its safe to say that I'd prefer any Westy over any Rochie. The colour of this beer is a nice blonde (no kidding, huh) with hazy highlights and a soft fluffy white head. If you look hard and really notice, you can see trillions of small bubbles rising on the side of the glass. The aroma is very nice for a 'white', with definate yeastie smells and then some of the banana variety. The taste is light bodied with drying characteristics. Good flavour with yeast, fresh characteristics (one might think of coriander), and a soft white pepper kick. The palating of this beer includes definate drying characteristics as well as some hop bitterness, which is very nice...especially on a warm summer day. A warm welcome from a trappist that cannot do anything wrong. A great beer that really everyone should try if they like their belgies.

Beautiful deep amber body with an effervescent rocky white head. Nice spicy and slightly yeasty nose. I can smell Belgium! Slightly bitter taste with a little more hops kicking in. Leaves a little of the bitterness on the tongue and has sort of an earthy quality about it. Wonderful beer and totally different from the 8 and 12. Perhaps their table beer, a la Chimay Doree or Petit Orval??

Pours with a clear golden body topped by a meium thick frothy white head that leaves lots of lace.  Slightly sweet yet sour somewhat smokey (marijuana?) aroma with slightly spicy grassy notes.  Bitter slighlty hoppy flavor with a touch of sweetness and grainy, grassy notes.  The finish is slightly bitter and salty.  Medium to full bodied and slightly tingly.

Veeeery interesting.  To make the standard claim, #600, whoohoo, all that crap.  Clear golden, nice thin, sticky head.  Nose is toasty, a bit sweet.  Interesting taste, but not phenomenal.  Quite yeasty, some nuttiness, a bit of spice.  Very dry, apricot fruitiness, not much.  Palate is a bit hefty, quite nice.  A good brew, but the only reason it gets ranked so highly is it's a Westy.  If this is 98th percentile I will eat a bug.  And then drink a Bud.
A simple, elegant brew. Very yeasty with a touch of spice. Very soft mouthfeel. Very, very easy to drink. A great session beer.

Aroma reminiscent of a tripel. Rich notes of toffee/caramel in the malt combined with a light yeasty/lemon flavor, almost wheaty. Soft nose and mouthfeel. Finish seems way too bitter and out of balance to me, which is too bad. Oh my God, I just made a complaint about a Westy beer. Complex nonetheless.

Wow, what a great brew!!! Obviously a bit more delicate, that the 12 and the 8, but it has lots of character. very floral hoppy nose. Slightly burnt malt character and nicely hoppy and bitter finish, pretty spot on i think, and nice and dry, i dug this a lot. Now this is a session beer.

Pour is a medium golden with a thin dying white head.  Lightly spiced Belgian yeast aroma.  Smooth bready biscuit malt flavor with a medium bitter finish.  Mellow, crisp body.  This is a good session ale and quite unique.

Hazy yellow with a billowing white head.  Spicy, yeasty notes in nose and flavor, but very clean.  Almost too clean for me, and the beer tastes like it was missing important spices, at least they should be more pronounced.  Slightly thin with a grassy, dry finish.  Not nearly as solid as their other brews.

Bottle (green cap).  A hazy golden color with a white head.  The nose yeilds grapefruit, apples, and herbs.  A dry butterscotch, flowery, and grassy flavor.  It is crisp/coarse and bitter with a few layers of depth.  My bottle may be a couple of years too old.
It definetely has a character, bitter and dry aftertaste, very nice hops. Very nice brew. Thank you Haukur for bringing this delight to me.

Great appearance. Bright gold with a huge rocky head that is not out of control. Interesting sweet cherry aroma. Flavor is dry malt (hay, sand), cloves and a surprisingly bitter finish. The dryness was surprising and could almost pass for an experimental pilsner with some of the fruity, spicy flavors going on.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2003 was a bit surprised how cloudy it was. Taste was sweet,a little peachy and very bitter. Friend told me this was the bittest blond he had ever tasted, and the strange thing was, it bitter, fresh and sweet at the same time.. very nice brew

Pale yellow in colour.  Very nice rocky white head and great lace.  The aroma is very flowery, cirtusy, some yeast.  Flavour is quite bitter, almost grassy.  Finishes bitter, slightly hoppy and dry.  Fantastic.

Here's what I got from the aroma: peach, lightly sour, fresh cut grass, sugar. The flavor mirrored the aroma with a nice malty core added. Pale yellow color with a large, thick white head. World class.

Oh dear god...i would like to totally agree with beerguy101 as we spent a good 5-10 minutes just smelling the aroma this beer had to offer. This was the MOST entrancing aroma out there at the beer fest...and is definitely in my top 2 or 3 best aroma's out there if not the best. The aroma hinted at yeastiness, a barnyardiness, some lemon and honey, with a hint of tartness and a contrasting sugariness. It pours a cloudy yellow with a nice sized white creamy head. The taste is a sourly and yet heavenly thing. Definite peppery finish that made this sweet yeasty fruity gem just the most well balanced beer at the fest. Medium levels of carbonation, a VERY smooth beer given that wildly perfect aroma..a good bittering aspect in the dry finish. Damn these monks make some damn fine beer!

Light gold color. Medium head. Aroma is floral, honey, lemon and yeast. WOW this is the BEST smelling beer I think I’ve had to date. Floral and refreshing. Very clean taste. Fruity, lemons, floral, candy sugar and yeasts. Very nice beer. It took me several minutes before I tasted this beer, because it smelled so good. Very clean. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Honey colored pour with a wispy head releasing an aroma of yeast,grass and spice. Coming from Westvleteren I was expecting something exceptional, what I got was a solid Belgian blond.

I was much excited to get the chance to sample this one.  A nice ocean breeze flows out of the glass.  Fruits, flowers, yeast are all present.  A light blonde color. A nice refreshing crisp and clean brew.
Hazy orange colour. Hops, yeasty and refreshing citrus in the nose and flavour. Good bitterness in the flavour and finish. A medium-bodied, complex and very good balanced beer.

nice freakin' head on this cloudy schoolbus colored monster..yeast, hay, warm lawnmower blades, and lemon zest..flavors of orange zest, yeast, cow-chawed grass..slighly acidic in the middle with a dry yeasty finish and lingering bready aftertaste..semi-full body..but as belgian blonds are not my favorite, i cannot fully appreciate what it is i may have here..

This beer I almost missed, since the only difference is the cap. It poured a very foamy, bubbly light gold color and formed a foamy head that left a fairly thick coating of lace. A good deal of carbonation and sediment was present(but due to the foam, I probably poured too much of it from the bottom). An aroma of hops and grain with a slight hint of clove. A flavor of hops, grain and a bit peppery. The finish also hint at the pepper. A good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 I had the #12 first, #8 next and finally the Blonde.  I think my favorite of the bunch is the Blond.  Yellow as straw, pours with a wonderful head.  This what beer should look like.  Yeasty, bread aroma and flavor.  Not over powering.  Wonderful balance.  Enough bitterness as to keep me interested.  I hate paying $8 for a beer, but I think I going to have to do it again.
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2014 Not as complex as Westvleteren 12, but I like this one even more. The sweet fruit, powerfull bread and bitter hoppynes fits perfect in my mouth. Extremly pleasent.
Bottled. (off course)  Beautiful blond colour.  Almost a white beer.  Little bit sweeter aroma tha the 8 and 12.  Bitter flavour, but amusing bitter.  A little bit a sticky palate.

I haven't yet signed up for the Belgian Blonde Appreciation Society, the application form is still in the drawer alongside my New year resolutions. However this beer made me get it out to reflect on it once more. Orval, De Koninck and this Westy Blond are probably the three most famous and acclaimed. My experience of Orval was not favourable, but I had to try De Koninck a few times before I started to appreciate the subtle darjeeling flavours. This Westy is a gentle drink, quite soft, despite the late hop bite, full of pleasing citric flavours. There is
the distinctive Belgian yeast blanket that marks it out as something apart from a British Golden Summer Ale, though it has a lot in common with that style. A pleasing drink, and one to compare someday with Orval and De Koninck.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2007 33cl. bottle:  Got this with the 12 & 8 that I bought from Belgian Shop.  Hadnt read the reviews, so I wasnt sure what to expect.  This beer pours a hazy golden color, with a small white head.  Has quite a bit of hops in the nose and taste, but not over the top.  Very well balanced.  Dry finish.  Certainly different from the 8 and 12, but still very good.  How can I join the Abbey?

Pours a very cloudy, pale yellow gold color with a big, lingering white head. Chunks of yeast are visible throughout the beer and even in the head. It has a mildly hoppy aroma with a good spiciness and yeast smell to it. Full bodied, with some decent malty/spicy flavors up front, which then disappear in the finish, leaving a lingering hop bitterness and strange breadiness from the malt. Interesting Belgian ale, very unique and quite tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2007 Pale gold. Lacy head. First nose is grain, then a massive aroma-hops attack. Taste is beautifully hoppy - not as a massive American IPA, more like a good British cask ale. Raisins-aroma, without the sweetness. intermediate mouthfeel, some alcohol. No real new aftertaste. Impression of hops again - not necessarily whole hops.

Extremely nice hopsaroma, but would be even better with a bit more body.
Watery and too bitter, needs more malt.

Mon favourite des trois Westy's.  Brilliant golden yellow colour with intense rocky white head that just sits about a foot over the brim of the glass.  Sweetish aroma and well hopped, yet distinctly Belgian flavour.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 Date on cap:17.10.03. Extremely inviting,clear,golden liquid with a frothy,rocky creamy head. Tiny bubbles are constantly racing to the top. Huge hop(floral,lemon grass) and honey,malt aroma. Mouthfeel is spritzy and very suffecient for this delicate beer.Sweet malts,peppery yeast, and a long grassy,hoppy finish. A elegant sweet,crisp,tasty ale. This might be my favorite of the three. Tasted a expired(month)one last year and it was just as good as this one.
Has the kick but the smoothness offsets it perfectly, definitly the best of the Trappist singles.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 At the cafe close to the monastery. Beautiful head, good lacing. Hoppy nose, some yeasty, flowery, very nice. Hopbitter flavour, again the flowery notes. Very suitable for drinking many in row without getting bored. Absolutely one of my favourite Belgian Ales.

gave head like a first class hooker.  Cloudy beige color.  Slightly spicy, slightly yeasty aroma, nothing too special.  VERY easy to drink, very tastey and definitely a great representation of the style with its slightly yeasty and alcohol flavor, but nothing really jumped out at me.  A very good beer, but not worthy of a top 50 on this site.

This completes the Westy trio for me.  Tastes like a cross between a triple and a witte.  Honey-wheat taste with a nice fruity complexity that shows itself prominently toward the finish before disappearing, leaving you slightly thirstier and wondering what it was that you just drank.  Nice pour with  a big head that rapidly disspiates.  Doesnt approach the other Westys, but still good!
cloudy yellow w/ a huge white head. spicy flavor,clean finish. Next time, Id have this one on a hot day

Honey, spice, a light touch of white wine and muscat grape in the aroma, along with a surprisingly cereal-like maltiness.  Golden blond color with a bit of dusty grey sediment and a reasonable head.  Bready, cereal malt flavors here, with a light fruitiness, spice and a light amount of complex sweetness.   Palate is lightly carbonated with a  soft body.  Aftertaste is mostly malty and spice, with a little sweetness. This beer was something of a surprise to me, I suppose it just didnt fit the mental picture I had formed of what Westy Blond would be like.  Thats sure not a bad thing, its just that this beer is rather unlike anything else I have tasted to date.  Its also very, very good.

A slightly unclear golden beer with at very good head. It has a very powerful aroma of fruit and ale yeast. The flavor is fresh at first and then woody and finishing with some sharpness on the back of the tongue - a for me unrecoqnizable spice. A very complex  flavor.

Very very tasty indeed - the only beer I can think of that tastes anything remotely like Orval. Heaps of heavy coriander hits you, then evaporates in a really dry, salty and bitter finish, with a touch of passionfruit or something from the yeast. I like this maybe even more than the other Westies - sacrilege I know.

Cloudy orange blond colour, lasting head. Spicy aroma with citrusfruits. Taste is typical for a blond, well balanced westy style is definately there. Spicy and oranges in the taste. Finish is more bitter, dry. Very good blond  brew, but I am very sure that this  beer has 4+ average due to his big brothers.
UPDATED: AUG 12, 2011 Blond color, with creamy longlasting head. Spicy aroma, oranges, melon. Best Westvleteren around, hands down.
Quite different from the other Westys. Has a cloudy orange colour, and a magnificent head. Aroma is yeasty and spicy. Has a somewhat more bitter and alcaholic taste, but still a very good beer.
Blond beer with a medium head. A lot of hop and yeast in the aroma. Very bitter aftertaste.

Some similarities to other blondes with cereals and plants.  Curiously, I spotted no fruit.  It tasted like the outdoors, I guess that barnyard type taste.  However, it was very refreshing on a warm summer day.

Westvletern - basically what beer dreams are made of.  The blond was a wonderful conclusion to a three glass tasting I had at the monastery bar this summer after riding a bike from Yerpes.  Amazing floral hop aromas met my nose before great flavours of green apple and spice met my tongue.  A close to perfect clean dry finish.  I wanted to stay forever.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2003 One of the better Wits out there. This is a Wit, isn't it?
The aroma is moderately malty and heavily yeasty. I also detected lemon, coriander, pepper and, of course, alcohol.
A murky, medium yellow color. Small, fizzy, white head.
A lightly malty flavor to start and then the spice kicks in to bitter things up a bit. Hint of black pepper in the mouth. Medium bodied with a dry, fizzy mouthfeel. Nice crisp, dry finish. Excellent effort from those wacky trappist monks.
Flower buquett. Also hops, apple and grain. Apricot like body with a little frothy head. Very hoppy and peppery aroma. Very bitter finish. Fizzy carbonation. Nice unexpected hoppy liquid.

Big fresh hop floral aroma - love it! Like a West coast IPA.  Hazy light orange-gold color and a lovely tight white head. Bright hop taste with hints of citrus (lemons) and a very long, dry bitter finish. Medium bodies and bit gritty in the mouth. Slight cardboard aftertaste. Im not convinced of the balance, but I just the aggressiveness of this brew: it is very un-European in that respect.

Excellent pour with a soft pillowy fluffy white cloud-like head that slowly retreats to the beer. The aroma is very citrusy with a hint of orange or lemon peels.  The color is a hazy yellow-white beer.  The taste lacks the sweetness that I would have thought making it much more appealing to me. It is also not overly cabonated.  Light to medium body with a crispness that tastes great.  There is a slight bitter taste that really stand out but doesnt have a long lasting kick.  Overall, a very nice refreshing blonde.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2013 Bottle at Akkurat (cap date is 03.12.11).

Head is initially large, frothy, white, fully lasting.
Body is hazy light yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted bread), moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of lemon/lime peel, pepper.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Despite the seemingly old bottle (4 or 5 years old?), this thing is still lovely and vibrant, very brightly herbal and lemony, with no baked apple or other typical pale beer oxidation smell. And its still quite soft and clean and wonderfully balanced. Hope someday to have this fresh in Belgium again (where its probably still 4+), but that will probably be many years from now...so a wildly expensive bottle in Stockholm will have to do. This blew away a fresher bottle of the 8, if thats any indication how surprising this is.
Spicy and flowery aroma.  Flavor is tangy, somewhat sweet but with surprising amount of grassy bitterness.

Might be the best blonde Ive tried. Strong hoppy both taste and aroma with a clear alcoholic and yeasted flavour. Beautiful amber/yellow colour with a milky-white head. Very well balanced with both the hints of fruit and the bitterness of the hops. Very tasty, even at 5.8%. A masterpiece!
The best of the trappist singles.  That makes a hat trick for Westvleteren.  Tons of strong flavour without being overpowering.
A fantastic light Belgian Ale. Very hoppy and flavor-full. Is a nice alternative to eg. Westmalle triple and other Belgian light beers.
Had only at the abbaye.  Very refreshing and would be nice to drink every day!  Nice spice, somewhat hoppy.

Faint hazy pale gold under a medium size very fine bubbled wonderfully lacing head. Aromas include; spices, light fruit, celery hops, and that tangy chicken stock soup thing you get in some of these Belgians. My one complaint about the aroma on this one is that its too faint. Medium body with a medium hoppy bitter start. Excellent range of subtle flavours; spice, mild yeast, perfumed soap leading to softer sweeter malty fruitier middle. Light dry bitter refreshing finish and shortish aftertaste.

An overdue rerate of an old bottle.  Beautiful creamy dense foam with extra cling power.  Clean aroma of pepper, perfume, barnyard, flowers, and spicy hops.  Spritzy palate.  An absolutely abundance of flavor; lots of pale malt, subtle hop fruitiness, pepper, grass, and medicine. Dry salty finish with lingering soft malts.  Nothing but quality ingredients here.  A nearly perfect Pilsner.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: A great light Belgian ale, tasty.

I imagine that some people drink this special beer while on their patio watching a red summer sunset.  Some likely eat a delicate meal, perhaps sole with lemon sauce?, with this as an accompaniment.  Myself, I drank this while cleaning my house and, after I had had about two-thirds of it, I ate fish fingers on toast with Jack Daniels-brand BBQ sauce.  Call me a heretic, or maybe a lunatic.  The appearance was excellent: very uniform white head, nice hazy yellow beer, and streams of bubbles starting so incredibly tiny.  Aroma was surprisingly subdued: some citric and yeast notes.  So overwhelmingly easy-drinking...just pouring down my throat.  Excellent texture: bubbly yet smooth and rich.  Increasing depth of flavor as it warmed over half an hour, yet still rather tame.  Gentle bitterness apparent in the finish.  Really well rounded, although I can see how its tempered flavor suppresses calls for it to rank higher.

Re-rate:Wow, what a great brew!!! Obviously a bit more delicate, that the 12 and the 8, but it has lots of character. very floral hoppy nose. Slightly burnt malt character and nicely hoppy and bitter finish, pretty spot on i think, and nice and dry, i dug this a lot.
UPDATED: OCT 15, 2004 Peppery clouds of heavenly doughy yeastFlying amongst luxuriant piney, Spalty hop plantsA creamy pillow paradise in the vicinity of Orvals

Light and cloudy yellow colour with a very creamy and lasting head. The aroma is not very big, but you can sense some flowers and citrus. The flavour is surprisingly fresh and fruity, but still complex. The aftertaste is short, but with a pleasant bitterness.
Very pale yellow, only slightly hazy. Grassy dry hop aroma. Medium bodied, dry with just a hint of toffee, clean firm malt profile. Like an elegant north German pilsener!

Very nice aroma with flowers and citrus. Golden, white frothy head, beautiful lace. Complex flavors with citrus the strongest, light sweet, soft but still hoppy. Long hoppy finish with some bitterness in the end.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 2009-08-20, parallel tasting -Fresh, bb 2010/05/19, 7-4-8-4-16=39Cloudy deep blond color (the bottle has been sitting for a couple of months) medium sized creamy head. The aroma is spicy (pepper and coriander), but also a bit papery, dusty. The mouthfeel is quite smooth; there is some flavor of spicy malt; the bitterness slowly finds its path, and in the final is quite strong; the hop impression would stay in the palate for long. Well brewed, well balanced; more intensive and sharp than the aged bottle, but it doesnt have the intensity of Orval. -Aged 8 years, bb 2002/02/13, 8-5-7-3-16=39The color is light amber, just a bit hazy (the bottle has been sitting for 4 years undisturbed). The aroma is a bit spicy too, pepper, but with a curious note that reminds me the kitchen of my friend Wang Qing (black bean sauce probably) then there is also some caramel, light Madeira wine; at times floreal, and fruity without being fruity. The mouthfeel is still well smooth like the fresh version, a bit rounder; there is caramel flavor, dry, with strong bitterness, a bit dusty; there are just traces of oxidisation. The final starts losing some bitterness, compared to the fresh version. A positive experience; less easy to drink than the fresh version, but with some more complexity.2002-05-14, 9-5-7-5-17=43Gold ale; wonderful thick head; misty. Very nice hop aroma, herbal. Strong hop in the mouth, enough bitter, not balanced by the malt. Strong and aromatic hop palate.
Nicely done,refreshingly dry finish,floral/spicy,slight malt charcater blances things out.

Cloudy, light yellow color.  Sweetish, bubblegummy aroma.  Slightly yeasty, piney/woody, slightly sweet body.  Spritzy, dry finish, little bitter hop finish.  Ill have to have this again at a later date since i only had a little thimble full, which Im sure didnt do the beer justice.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2003 What a beautiful trappist ale!
Very complex herbal aroma, flowery with hops and citrus. Strawberries even. Hopbitter taste with citrusfruit, some cinnamon and pepper. Some maltiness to smoothen the taste. Without any doubt one of the best beers in the world. Still my orginal rating was a bit too high (9 5 9 4 18: 4.5). Now a well deserved 4.3
Light hazy yellow color with a huge flowery aroma, and slightly spicy taste.  Ends dry and refreshing.

Appearance:  very clear, light amber, lots of bubbling action in the center, big stable creamy head; looks most like a great Pils to me.  Nose is mostly sweet and yeasty, with hints of orange, lemon, and cut grass; its very nice but on the weak side.  Flavor nicely balanced between the dry, bitter, herbal side and a more malty-sweet earthy character.  As mentioned before, a great body; might be a bit too harsh at the end for a Blonde, I think.  Still a high-quality brew, but like Trap I expected a lot, and am just a little let down.  But I have the 8 and 12 to try soon...

Just ditto ecrvich completely on this, but I would say in my bottle the bitterness beats the sweetness by a lot! A great bitterness, in addition to all of the floral/lemon+orange/pine components. Body is big, as has been said, appearance is about as beautiful as possible.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Cloudy yellow color, nice white head, lots of lace. Citrusy nose, malts quite evident. Start is malt, the middle is light, the finish is nicely hopped, acidic, moderate carbonation, dry, clean and spritzy.

hazy straw color with a nice head
zesty aroma. 
taste is citrusy and has a pepper flavor.
very smooth creamy palate for a blonde ale.

Tasted today (together with the 12 and 8) at the abbey of Westvleteren In de Vrede café and cultural center...
Beautiful white head of foam tops a golden colored brew with lively fine bubbles...a sight!
Fine hoppy aroma, fresh and fruity.  This is like the nose of a fine white wine, superb.
Very fine foam in the mouth, with subdues but excellent hop flavor, balanced and exquisitely fine.  Long in the mouth and fully satisfying, and not heavy in the least, yet with a complete body.
Sub re-tasting, I believe the blond may well be my favorite beer of the trio!
The colour is a superb cloudy golden-yellow. Very nice creamy head. Aroma: floral, fresh and slightly citrusy. The taste is well-balanced, fresh with a touch of acidity. Pleasant and long aftertaste.
Westvleteren is just my favorite. The 8th is better, but uncomparable. This is one of the finest ever brewed!
Great beer! One of the trappists Ive ever drunk. I think its better then Westmalle triple.
This is a fantastic beer.  Very flowery, complex, great malt profile.  Brilliant work.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 cloudy dark orange colour, big creamy head and a beautiful lacing, citrusy, estery nose with notes of cream, fresh, medium-bodied, slightly oily with a solid bitterness, the finish is dry with a moderate maltiness and a fruity hoppiness - very balanced and very well made
